XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, I wish to remind you that an official photograph of members in the chamber will be taken tomorrow at 10.20 am. It is requested that all members are present in the chamber for this.

Mr SPEAKER: In December last year a committee of this House, the Committee System Review Committee, handed down a report that recommended major changes to the parliament’s committee system. Those recommendations fell within the committee’s terms of reference and, like most members, I welcome and support the changes that are designed to reinvigorate our parliament’s committee system and thus enhance parliamentary oversight of legislation. The report also recommended major changes to the way this parliament is administered and managed. In my view, these recommendations fell outside the committee’s terms of reference. I ask honourable members to think about that.

As Speaker, one of my roles is to speak on behalf of the parliament--that is, not only on behalf of this 53rd Parliament, of which you are members and I am Speaker, but also on behalf of the institution of parliament, which is one of the three arms of government within our democratic system of government. Today I want to speak briefly on the proposed changes arising from the committee’s recommendations that fall outside its terms of reference, that is, the recommendations that will fundamentally change the way this parliament is administered and managed. These recommendations have far-reaching consequences for the role of Speaker and the sovereignty of parliament. The Speaker is specifically excluded from the new management committee of the parliament. Instead, it is to be chaired by the Leader of Government Business in this House and will include the nominees of the Premier and Deputy Premier among its six members. In other words, in my view, it will be a committee controlled by the executive which does not have the Speaker on it.

I make the following points in regard to these recommendations. In my view, the committee should have sought a widening of its terms of reference to authorise its inquiries and legitimise its recommendations. However, it did not and because there was no widening of the terms of reference no-one was aware that the review committee was considering changes to the way the parliament is managed and administered. No-one had the slightest idea that these recommendations were on the cards.

On 20 August last year I appeared before the review committee to speak to a submission I had made to the committee. In my submission I did not canvass matters relating to the management and administration of the parliament. Why would I? They were not included in the committee’s terms of reference. Did the committee raise these recommendations with me on that occasion? No, it did not. Did it do so on any other occasion? Again, no. I have been criticised for showing discourtesy to the committee by speaking out against its recommendations in December last year--recommendations, mind you, that in my view did not fall within the committee’s terms of reference. However, what courtesy was shown to me or, more importantly, to the office I hold?

Secondly, what reasons have been given? There was certainly nothing substantial in the report. For the past four years a Speaker’s Advisory Committee, with representatives from both sides of the House and the Independents, has met, but none of the matters of criticism have been raised as complaints. Thirdly, the hallmark of the review committee’s offending recommendations, shortly to be translated into legislation presented to this House, has been the complete lack of consultation surrounding them. Members may have gained the impression that I had been consulted on the changes. I advise honourable members that that is not the case. I was told what the changes would be. They were presented to me as a fait accompli.

However, of greater concern to me is that no-one else was consulted about these very significant and substantial changes to the way the parliament is administered and the role of the Speaker in that regard. This is the people’s House. We talk about it being everyone’s parliament, but the people whom we are elected to represent in this place have been left in the dark every step of the way with regard to how their parliament is now to be managed by a committee that excludes the Speaker, is chaired by the Leader of Government Business and includes nominees of the Premier and Deputy Premier.

In my initial response last year I described these particular recommendations as wrong in principle and dangerous in practice. I do not resile from that view and I state it again today. The transfer of management responsibility for this parliament to the new Committee of the Legislative Assembly, given its composition, in my view represents a serious violation of the separation of powers that underpins our democratic system of government. The decision ultimately for this House is whether it wants the Speaker or the Leader of Government Business to chair a committee to lead and administer the parliament. I believe very strongly that the best interests of the parliament are served by having an independent, impartial Speaker chairing the management committee of the parliament. In every other Westminster parliament--I stress, in every other Westminster parliament--including the examples cited in the committee’s report, the Speaker chairs the management committee of the parliament.

As Speaker, I am the voice of this House and I agree that I am also its servant. Once the House has spoken, I communicate its will. If it is the will of this House to accept the changes, of course, as its servant, I will accept the decision. However, the House has not yet spoken. All I can do, and all I am doing today in placing this statement on the record, is warning the House of the eventual consequences of overturning what 52 previous parliaments have considered sacrosanct, that is, that the parliament is presided over and administered by the Speaker.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.38 am): I am sure that others will join with me in sending our thoughts today to the parents, family and friends of young Cairns boy, Declan Crouch. For four agonising weeks they have faced a heartbreaking wait for news. Today marks Declan’s 14th birthday and I join with police in calling on anyone with any information, no matter how small or seemingly trivial, to provide it to the police on the Crimestoppers number, 1800333000. It will be a very long day for Declan’s mum and today we hold her and his family in our hearts.

(South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.39 am): Today politicians across the chamber are wearing red in support of the Heart Foundation’s Go Red for Women campaign to raise awareness of the risk of heart disease in women. Most women do not know that heart disease is, in fact, their No. 1 killer. It kills four times as many women as does breast cancer and in Queensland it is responsible for about a quarter of premature deaths in women. In fact, around 47 per cent of people who die of heart disease are women.

XML.Hansard-Body: While women have developed a very strong awareness over the past decade of their breast cancer risk--and many are taking appropriate steps to have regular checks--many still remain unaware of their risk of heart disease. For a long time heart disease has been seen as a disease that affects mainly men in this age group. More than 90 per cent of women have a risk factor for heart disease and around half have two or more of these factors. Lifestyle factors aside, many women have few of the symptoms. However, heart disease is largely preventable. By keeping a regular eye on our blood pressure, maintaining a healthy diet and weight, staying physically active and spreading the word to women of the importance of regular check-ups, we can stop this silent killer.

I congratulate the Heart Foundation on the great work it does in our community throughout the year, but I particularly congratulate it on the Go Red for Women campaign. I think it is a very worthy cause. I am very pleased to support it myself today. I congratulate everybody else in the chamber who is sporting a bit of red today. Even if they did not know they were doing it for the campaign, they do now.

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.40 am): It has now been more than 100 days since the events that shaped our summer started to chart an angry, destructive course through Queensland. Although we will continue to reflect on those frightening weeks during which we watched as floodwaters engulfed our towns, our farming communities and our capital city, it is also valuable to reflect on what has been achieved since then as we pull together to rebuild, and rebuild a stronger and more resilient Queensland.

XML.Hansard-Body: Operation Queenslander is now in full swing. Operation Queenslander is pulling all of our resources together to build a more robust Queensland, a Queensland that will emerge bigger, better and stronger from these disasters. In the short period since the floodwaters receded and since Cyclone Yasi blew inland and dissipated, we have already taken giant strides forward. Make no mistake: we still have a long and difficult road to travel, but it is a credit to every affected community, to every emergency worker and roads labourer and, indeed, to each and every Queenslander who has pitched in to help that we have come so far so quickly.

We have paid out more than $29.7 million in grants under the Personal Hardship Assistance Scheme operated by the state government to help Queenslanders repair their damaged homes. We have paid grants to 3,042 small businesses and to almost 3,000 primary producers to help get these essential Queensland sectors back on their feet. Over $8.9 million has been provided to sporting groups for repairs to clubrooms and to buy sporting equipment. The Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal, which has raised in excess of $250 million, has so far allocated more than $55 million in round 1 payments to about 30,000 Queenslanders. We have now received 172 applications in round 2 from those people whose homes were totally destroyed and cannot be rebuilt.

We are getting money out the door to our councils, which will be critical in rebuilding the state, at speeds never before seen so that work can continue. Forty-four of our councils are now sharing in $387 million in joint state and federal funding, and that amount was allocated in a period of just two weeks. This is without precedent in disaster recovery. It is good news for our councils, which are facing a damage bill ultimately likely to top $2 billion. It means they can get started on the work needed to repair their communities immediately. That is because the funding has been accelerated by the Queensland Reconstruction Authority using this new process which, for the first time, speeds up payment. More than 80 per cent of this money will go towards our massive road network, the lifeblood of our state.

During the floods and the subsequent tropical cyclone, more than 9,000 kilometres of Queensland’s state owned road network were affected; in many cases they were simply washed away. As of yesterday, 6,800 kilometres of those roads had been restored. Of course that does not go to the question of the thousands of kilometres of council owned roads, which are also well on the way to recovery. It is a gargantuan effort and is a credit to those crews who are working so hard to bring normality back to affected communities.

Similarly, our rail network suffered major damage, with almost 4,750 kilometres wiped out. More than 4,200 kilometres of that flood affected rail has now been repaired, including the western line, which was opened three months ahead of schedule. Of the 387 schools that were affected, 385 are now operating normally. Of the 89 state owned bridges and culverts that sustained major damage, 55 have now been repaired--and the work continues.

Less than two weeks after Tropical Cyclone Tasha hit Queensland, our government appointed Major General Mick Slater to head the recovery and rebuilding effort. A little over a month later we legislated to give the Reconstruction Authority the powers that it needs to get on with the job. Late last month we released Operation Queenslander, our recovery and reconstruction blueprint. We are getting on with the job of rebuilding Queensland. It is a big task but it is a task that we are determined to conquer.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Queensland Reconstruction Authority; Brisbane Basketball Centre

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.45 am): With Operation Queenslander we are engaged in a great mission to rebuild Queensland better and stronger than before. The task is huge and we simply cannot do it on our own. The reconstruction will take massive cooperation among all levels of government, the business community and Queenslanders themselves. An excellent example of that spirit of cooperation in action can be seen in the Queensland Reconstruction Authority’s Join Forces program. This program is aimed at matching up the generosity of corporate Australia with the needs of community groups that require help after the floods and the cyclone.

XML.Hansard-Body: Today I am very pleased to announce that the National Australia Bank has committed $250,000 to the Reconstruction Authority’s Join Forces program which is the largest single corporate donation to date. That donation will be part of the National Australia Bank’s $1 million Community Development Fund. The money will go towards getting the Brisbane Basketball Centre at Auchenflower up and running as soon as possible.

This is a great partnership between the National Australia Bank and basketball in Queensland. It is a huge boost for Queensland basketball. The Auchenflower complex is one of Queensland’s most utilised sports centres. It is where state championships are held and the place where our best young players from Mount Isa, Cairns, Rockhampton, Townsville--all over the state--dream of playing.

This is the spiritual home of basketball in Queensland. During the floods this sporting mecca had nine feet of water through it and it remained there for 36 hours, gutting the entire complex. The ‘Auchendome’, as it has been called since the early days of the Brisbane Bullets, is a community focal point used by some 6,000 to 7,000 Queenslanders every week. The association has over 1,600 junior members, with kids playing in both social and school competitions, and over 2,400 senior members. The centre has a huge roster of local schools that use it on a daily basis and, of course, it is also where the junior and senior level state and national championships are held. As I have said, the facility is regarded as the home of basketball in Queensland. With such a large junior membership, the centre is a breeding ground for our next basketball superstars.

Brisbane Basketball and the NAB have a tough task ahead of them. In just two weeks time, 30 under-14 teams from across Queensland will descend on the centre for the Queensland under-14 state championships. There is no doubt that today’s announcement will put a smile on the face of many young up-and-coming players. We wish the NAB and Brisbane Basketball all the best as they join forces to get the centre up and open for the under-14 championships in a fortnight.

There are many other corporate citizens coming forward to help. I was very pleased to join with the member for Toowoomba North when we handed over the first Nissan vehicle. Nissan is providing 200 motor vehicles which will be used for up to six months by clubs and community groups such as the Cardwell RSL club, which will be using it to transfer cancer patients to and from Cairns Base Hospital. Some will be provided to the Red Cross for community outreach out of Cairns, and eight vehicles will go to Choice Australia Management to assist in the farm clean-up project.

The Reconstruction Authority now has over 120 flood or cyclone affected clubs that have registered with Join Forces and there is a growing number of corporate entities wanting to join forces with them. I commend the program to members. I would encourage those members with affected groups in their electorate to ensure they know about this program and get on the website.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (9.49 am): Finally, as I have outlined today, Operation Queenslander is well underway. Right across the state we see a great sense of purpose as communities roll up their sleeves and get down to work. But the rebuilding of our roads, schools and homes is only part of the reconstruction effort. We also must rebuild lives and shattered communities right across this state.

As we know, the Easter holidays are looming and for many people this is a significant time of reflection and hope. But it is also the first time that many Queenslanders will have a chance to pause and reflect on the experience of this last summer. Research from natural disasters around the world shows that the period of 10 to 12 weeks after the disaster occurs can be the time when the emotional damage of the events really starts to hit home. Holidays and times of celebration are also difficult moments, as people often feel they cannot celebrate as they struggle with their own internal trauma. What that means is that this year Easter may well be a very difficult time for many Queenslanders who experienced the disaster. This year Easter comes just three months after much of the disaster happened and of course Easter is a traditional time of family celebration.

Many have suffered terrible grief and trauma from what has occurred. Queenslanders all over the state have seen their lives dislocated, as they are staying with family and friends, living with in-laws or living in a caravan while they wait for their homes to be repaired. I think we all understand that that is simply not easy. While the physical destruction of the natural disasters was immediate and obvious, other impacts such as emotional distress and depression are not so obvious.

We all have a role to play in looking out for our family members, our friends, our neighbours and our work colleagues who have been affected. Some people may need the ear of someone so they can tell their story. Others might just want a bit of extra company or practical support. Some may need to be reminded that it is important to think about and take good care of themselves. These are all things we can do to support one another.

This week the government will launch a mental health ad campaign in the metro and regional press and also on radio. We want to remind people that it is normal if they feel stressed, letting them know where they can get help and asking family and friends to keep an eye on their loved ones. We will be directing them to available services like the 13HEALTH 24-hour telephone hotline. This support line now also provides a service specifically for people affected by the floods or cyclones and can link people with acute mental health services. General practitioners can also provide help, referrals and information, and Lifeline offers 24-hour telephone counselling.

The reconstruction of Queensland will take time, and it is about much more than fixing roads and rebuilding structures. It is about rebuilding lives, reconnecting people and rebuilding communities. It is also about supporting each other through these difficult times and looking forward to the better times ahead. So, if you know someone who has been affected, Easter is a time to be reaching out and lending a hand.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Attorney-General, Minister for Local Government and Special Minister of State) (9.52 am): One year ago, through the Queensland Growth Management Summit, the government began a landmark discussion with local governments, environmental groups, industry and the general public on how to better manage growth. Since the summit, a significant number of actions and major milestones have been delivered. We have established Growth Management Queensland as the lead agency to deliver summit outcomes and to coordinate growth management in Queensland. GMQ has been instrumental in managing and achieving our growth management agenda.

Immediately following the summit the Regional First Home Owner Grant was established to provide an $11,000 grant for first home owners building new homes in regional areas. Since the summit, we have released the draft Strategic Cropping Land Framework, the State Planning Policy for Healthy Waters, the draft Biodiversity Strategy, the Queensland Integrated Waterways Monitoring Framework, and Valuing the Things We Waste--Queensland’s Waste Avoidance and Efficiency Strategy.

In August 2010, we also released the draft Connecting SEQ, setting ambitious 20-year targets to transform South-East Queensland’s transport network through increasing public and active transport and reducing private vehicle trips. We have released the Queensland Migration Plan, which is setting skills and business migration priorities for Queensland. We released a Transit Oriented Development Guide to promote delivery of best practice compact communities, and called for expressions of interest to develop a transit oriented precinct at Coorparoo junction. The process closed on 18 March 2011 with seven expressions of interest received.

A number of major milestones have also been achieved, including the release of the final Infrastructure Charges Task Force report and the State Planning Instruments Program. We have also declared Ripley Valley, Greater Flagstone, Yarrabilba and Caloundra South as urban development areas, which collectively will provide 143,000 new dwellings. In an Australian first, I visited the Ripley Valley site with Ipswich mayor Paul Pisasale and local MPs last week to release draft blueprints for Ripley Valley, Greater Flagstone and Yarrabilba. These new communities will address the issue of housing availability and affordability.

Delivery of our growth management agenda has been impacted by the recent natural disasters, and future outcomes will be shaped by the government’s recovery response. However, our progress to date in delivering on growth management has been swift and will continue to be a key focus for this government.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade) (9.55 am): It is clear that the economic toll from natural disasters both here and abroad continues to mount. The issues facing our state from the floods and cyclone have yet to subside. Our friends in New Zealand and Japan are still very much in recovery mode from devastating earthquakes.

The economic and fiscal challenge is getting tougher in the short term. Ongoing wet weather has been a further challenge for our state. The Commonwealth Treasury has indicated that losses in production will likely exceed original forecasts, especially in coal production. The risk of larger volume loss than first anticipated is emerging. The impact will be tempered in part by higher prices now being achieved in a supply constrained market. This points to the probability that the already weakened midyear forecasts could be further revised downwards. The situation remains under analysis as the parameters of the next state budget are being decided.

Recent commentary has also centred on the sustained higher Australian dollar, which continues to challenge our export competitiveness and weigh on our tourism industry in particular. Again, this weighs upon the nearer term economic outlook. This uncertainty and prevailing downside weaknesses provide a strong case for the Reserve Bank Board today to avoid further hikes at their meeting. They should, as they have signalled, look through the shorter term inflationary pressures. For Queensland, for Queensland businesses and Queensland families in particular, today is not the day for contemplating an interest rate movement.

These challenges underscore the priority for strong, stable leadership--a sustained economic reform agenda and a clear line of sight to a modern economic future. Our government has been pursuing an agenda to drive jobs growth, maintain a massive building program and support industries of the future. We have embarked upon the most substantial reordering of the state’s balance sheet in our history.

All of this was reflected in last Friday’s affirmation of our credit rating by Standard & Poor’s, which also confirmed our stable outlook. The report noted what it described as our ‘excellent financial management’ and a ‘very strong and diversified’ economy that would overcome the nearer term challenges from the natural disasters, with anticipated stronger growth also supported by reconstruction and rebuilding activity.

The report recognised the budgetary challenges that remain, compounded by the recent natural disasters, and sustained growth. It acknowledged our reform program--our plan to deliver renewed strength to our finances. This government remains determined to deliver on our economic reform agenda. While the economic and financial challenges are real, so is our determination to build a stronger Queensland economy, just as we said we would.

Hansard-Body.A: (Greenslopes--ALP) (Minister for Education and Industrial Relations) (9.57 am): The Bligh government is committed to providing Queensland school students with a first-class education. This includes ensuring that schools are places of learning where students feel safe, comfortable and cared for. In the wake of an incident at Southport State High School last week, I want to reassure Queenslanders that our schools are safe.

XML.Hansard-Body: Almost three-quarters of a million students attend state and non-state schools in Queensland every single day, and incidents involving weapons are very rare. And when incidents do occur, the department responds swiftly. For instance, in 2009-10, 108 students were expelled from state schools for physical misconduct involving an object. Queensland also has one of the most open and transparent reporting systems for student misconduct of any state or non-state school system in Australia. Details of exclusions and short and long suspensions are listed in the Department of Education and Training’s annual report each year as well as being posted on the department’s website.

Other initiatives and legislative changes implemented by the Bligh government to further protect students include establishing the Queensland Schools Alliance Against Violence to deal with violence and bullying in all schooling sectors; extending powers for principals to exclude students for unacceptable behaviour without needing departmental approval; and announcing a series of ‘Raising the Bar’ forums to give principals, teachers and P&Cs the opportunity to suggest ways to improve standards in schools.

I want to send a very clear message to students and parents that knives have no place in schools, and that we have a zero tolerance approach to violence in schools. As a parent of two young boys in primary school, I was very disturbed to hear about the serious incident last week. As education minister, I took immediate action. I instructed Education Queensland to conduct an urgent review into all policies and legislation relating to the possession of weapons in schools. The review covers exclusion powers, searching student property, responsible behaviour plans and the communication of policies to students and teachers.

While last week’s incident was an isolated one, the government has a responsibility to minimise the chances of it recurring. There is no reason for a student to take a knife to school. The Bligh government makes no apologies for taking a hardline stance against knife possession in schools and we will not shy away from tough decisions to further protect Queensland students.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Health) (10.00 am): The Bligh government is delivering more health services sooner to the people of the Sunshine Coast. Yesterday’s announcement confirms two brand-new hospitals that will give public and private patients access to nearly 1,000 new beds on this site. Work on the new 200-bed private hospital starts later this year and our agreement with Ramsay Health Care means up to 110 extra beds for public patients from 2013. The new $2 billion Sunshine Coast University Hospital, to be delivered as a public-private partnership, will open in 2016 with 450 beds, growing to 738 beds by 2021. It will be the biggest hospital building project in the country when construction gets underway in early 2013.

XML.Hansard-Body: It will give Sunshine Coast residents access to a new cancer care centre and a range of complex surgical services including neurosurgery, cardiothoracic surgery, maxillofacial surgery and a trauma service. That means around 10,000 patients will no longer have to travel to Brisbane for these services each year. Not only will the Sunshine Coast University Hospital deliver new beds and services, it will also create thousands of jobs in this important region. More than 2,000 workers will be on site during construction and the hospital will employ 3,500 doctors, nurses and support staff.

We are going to market with a PPP because we believe it will be the most cost-effective, best and quickest way to deliver this project. The PPP bidders will determine how quickly a hospital of this size can be built. The Bligh government always said that this hospital would be built as a PPP if it could be shown that this would deliver taxpayers value for money. Our business case shows it does. We look forward to receiving bids that not only deliver a saving to taxpayers but also deliver more beds and services sooner to this growing region.

We are already putting more services on the ground ahead of the hospitals opening. New services starting this year at Nambour Hospital include a cardiac catheterisation laboratory, a vascular surgery procedural suite, a dedicated endoscopy procedural suite, a radiation oncology service for public patients and an outpatient neurosurgery service. These come on top of a new 96-bed ward block at Nambour Hospital and an expanded emergency department at Caloundra Hospital.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.03 am): Our government is determined to rebuild Queensland both physically and emotionally following our summer of sorrow. I am pleased to report that so far through the community recovery grants program of the Department of Communities $18.8 million has been paid to people in hardship grants and $10.9 million has been distributed to replace household contents and repair damage to homes. One of the greatest needs has been for housing and we have adopted a whatever-it-takes, case-by-case, community-by-community approach to find people stable housing solutions.

We have provided the following help to disaster affected households. To assist people into private rentals we have provided more than 1,500 bond loans, more than 350 rental grants and 775 RentConnect interviews and property inspections. This is where people have been assisted to find private accommodation. Many of the people I have met have been elderly people, for instance, who have owned their own homes, never needed a reference, never needed to go to a real estate agent and have found it extremely difficult. Our RentConnect program has certainly been a great tool in this time of need.

Some 65 households have been helped by the Home Assist Secure. We have received 530 applications for social housing because of the natural disasters. We have temporarily placed 195 of these people into social housing, with another 149 in the process of moving in. We have also provided 118 temporary dwellings across the state in Grantham, Emerald, Gatton, Theodore, Condamine, Cardwell, Tully, Tully Heads and Mission Beach.

I have seen the temporary housing we have put in place in Tully, Mission Beach and Grantham. They are high-quality homes. Many of them have balconies and verandas and outdoor living areas as well. Some 61 people have been housed in the Tully Caravan Park--some of these in temporary homes, some in factory built homes and some in ensuited vans. I thank the member for Hinchinbrook because he certainly supported our need to have people stay locally to keep the lifeblood of these communities going.

We have also held housing assistance forums in flood affected areas to help people find out exactly what information and support they need. Some people have indicated they have needed a break so we have given them holidays that have generously been donated as prizes. I am pleased to inform the House that the first winner of one of the holidays was a plumber from Goodna. He has been able to take a few days break with his family before he continues the work of rebuilding.

While the victims of the floods and the cyclones no doubt need a holiday they also need their government and representatives to stay on the job. The Bligh government is on the job. We are committed to rebuilding our state as quickly as possible and we are here for the long haul.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Transport and Multicultural Affairs) (10.05 am): Today I have good news for public transport commuters in South-East Queensland. New and improved train timetables are coming to South-East Queensland’s two busiest train lines from Monday, 6 June. These improvements will add more than--wait for this--150,000 weekly train seats, more reliability and more frequency to the Caboolture, Ipswich, Rosewood and north coast lines on the TransLink network.

With patronage on Queensland Rail services growing by about five per cent in the six months to 30 December, the time is ripe to undertake the first major recast of the timetable on our two busiest train lines in more than a decade. It is also one of the biggest enhancements ever to public transport in South-East Queensland, delivering many benefits including more capacity with 150,000 additional weekly seats; a simpler timetable based on two stopping patterns allowing trains on each line to run through Brisbane’s CBD stations every three minutes at the busiest times; more reliability with delays on one line now contained, reducing impacts across the network; and a turn-up-and-go train network with off-peak, weekend and public holiday services now running at least every 15 minutes between Darra and the CBD, and four trains an hour between Northgate the CBD.
This is an exciting and historic change made possible by the recently completed infrastructure project such as the upgrade--
Mr Crandon interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Coomera, you have been stretching the tolerance of the chair. The honourable the minister has the call.

Ms PALASZCZUK: This is an exciting and historic change made possible by the recently completed infrastructure projects such as the upgrade between Corinda and Darra, the expansion to the new Richlands stations and the 46 rolling stock sets we have added to the network over the past three years.

The original version of this timetable underwent extensive consultation at community sessions, online and over the phone, during November and December. I am pleased to say that we have been able to make a number of major changes to accommodate that feedback, particularly for commuters wanting to arrive in the city at certain times and better connections for school students. I want to thank all the customers, community groups and present members who provided input into this process.

The new timetable will be available on the TransLink website later today and will be introduced from the first service on Monday, 6 June. Between now and June, TransLink will be working with all bus operators to change their timetables to continue to ensure we have a fully integrated bus and train network. This is the Bligh government in action. This is the Bligh government delivering for commuters in South-East Queensland.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order!

Hansard-Body.A: (Nudgee--ALP) (Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services) (10.08 am): The Bligh government is committed to doing all it can to reduce Queensland’s road toll. That is why 12 months ago the government introduced covert speed cameras to increase the chance and uncertainty of detection and thus motivate motorists to change their driving habits. The government approved that up to 30 per cent of mobile speed camera enforcement can be undertaken covertly using a variety of vehicles and with no advance warning or departure signs at the camera site. Queensland Police Service data shows that our strategy is working. Between April 2010 and January 2011 covert speed camera vehicles were deployed on around 2,000 occasions across the state for a total of around 6,700 hours of operation. During this time around 4 million vehicles were monitored by covert speed cameras, with close to 87,000 detected speeding.

XML.Hansard-Body: Although there are still far too many motorists exceeding the speed limit, I am pleased to advise the House that there has been a steady decline in the number of vehicles detected speeding by covert speed cameras. In April 2010 there were 24.45 detections per 1,000 vehicles; by January 2011 this had decreased to 16.07 detections per 1,000 vehicles, a reduction of around 33 per cent. The current rate of detection for marked mobile speed cameras is around 6.8 vehicles per 1,000. The government believes that the deployment of covert and marked speed camera vehicles will continue to motivate drivers to slow down and make our roads safer.

On another road safety issue, last year four lives were lost as a result of drivers disobeying traffic lights, with a total of 48 lives lost since 2005. The loss of these lives was preventable. Across Queensland there are around 140 red-light camera sites utilising wet film cameras which are now approaching the end of their useful life. That is why the Queensland Police Service has recently purchased 40 new digital red-light cameras for use at sites across South-East Queensland. The cost of these cameras was $1.9 million which was derived from fines collected through the red-light and speed camera program. The message to motorists is clear: the Queensland Police Service will continue to use a mixture of on-road enforcement and technology to continue driving down the road toll.

Hansard-Body.A: (Whitsunday--ALP) (Minister for Tourism, Manufacturing and Small Business) (10.11 am): I am pleased to report back to the House after attending this year’s Australian Tourism Exchange this week that Queensland is most certainly shining on the international stage. Queensland was by far the best represented state at the event, with more than 140 Queensland tourism operators in Sydney this week to sell our unbeatable packages, our unbeatable destinations and our unbeatable hospitality to the world. The Australian Tourism Exchange, or ATE as it is known in the industry, is the largest travel trade show in the Southern Hemisphere and, from my discussions with the operators in attendance, also one of the most profitable networking opportunities they have available to them. ATE puts the smallest Queensland operators in direct contact with the most influential tourism buyers in the world.

XML.Hansard-Body: Knowing how critically important this enormous event is to our tourism operators, we sponsored every Queensland participant at this year’s ATE to get down to Sydney. This crucial financial assistance helped to put Queensland companies in touch with nearly 700 key international buyers from over 40 countries, enabling our operators to promote packages and negotiate deals there and then. Our sponsorship was provided through the joint Queensland and federal government post flood and cyclone tourism recovery package. This is money very well spent, providing all Queensland tourism operators impacted by the state’s severe weather events with the financial assistance and opportunity to bring more businesses to Queensland.

Queensland was certainly shining at ATE. Operators from across the state were showcasing the very best of their products, meeting with overseas contacts and negotiating deals right before my eyes. ATE is the perfect opportunity for Queensland industry to tell the world’s leading travel buyers that Queensland is well and truly open and ready to welcome visitors. Mr Speaker, I can promise you that our operators were putting on a spectacular performance, promoting everything from our five-star accommodation, unique attractions, unrivalled tours and spectacular cruises to, of course, the best food and wine experiences going. With more than 222,000 Queenslanders owing their living to tourism, the industry is a key economic driver for the state. It is vital that we stand by this industry as part of Queensland’s economic recovery. By sponsoring companies to attend ATE this year, we are standing shoulder to shoulder with our industry to ensure we win this fight.

Hansard-Body.A: (Stretton--ALP) (Minister for Energy and Water Utilities) (10.14 am): The approval of the $91 million SunCoast Power Project will mean almost 325,000 Sunshine Coast residents and visitors will benefit from the major new subtransmission powerline project. This is the largest electricity project ever undertaken by Energex on the Sunshine Coast. Given that the Sunshine Coast is one of the country’s fastest growing areas not just in terms of population but also in peak time energy use, this project, along with others on the Energex drawing board, is needed to underpin previous growth and forecast population energy increases across the city. The population on the Sunshine Coast has risen by around 40 per cent in the past 10 years yet network peak electricity demand in the same period has gone up by close to 80 per cent--almost double the population growth, one of the highest rises in the country. Much of this peak energy rise is due to a rapid uptake of air conditioning, swimming pool penetration and new technologies such as energy-intensive televisions, computers and games.

XML.Hansard-Body: This project has been on the drawing board since it was announced in December 2006. Since then an enormous amount of community consultation has been undertaken to develop an alignment with the least overall environmental, social and financial impact to the community. A number of state and local government agencies and community representatives, including the member for Maroochydore, residents groups and environmental representatives, were included in a community reference group which was formed early in the planning stages to provide feedback. This feedback, along with submissions from the broader community, was incorporated into the draft and final environmental impact statements. Environmental and health concerns raised during the stakeholder consultation period have been assessed by government and independent bodies prior to approval. This includes the commitment to any required species management plan. A construction environmental management plan will also identify and address other local wildlife management requirements identified in the EIS.

Energex has a strong commitment to ensuring the safety and wellbeing of the community. These standards ensure that Energex must not propose developments which do not meet a range of environmental, safety and technical standards regarding electromagnetic fields. The SunCoast project meets those guidelines. Negotiations are well advanced with landowners in the local area to secure vegetation offsets and koala habitat plantings. The SunCoast project is a key component of a network of upgrades designed to meet the electricity needs of an additional 170,000 people expected to be living in the Sunshine Coast region in the next 20 years as well as the forecast continued peak demand increases from existing homes and businesses.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Environment and Resource Management) (10.17 am): The devastating natural disasters that tore through Queensland over the past summer have presented an unwanted reminder of how destructive extreme weather events can be. The harsh reality is that floods and cyclones are clear examples of the kind of extreme weather events that scientists predict we will see more of because of climate change. As we consider the homes that were destroyed, the lives that were left in ruins and the communities we are now working to rebuild, there has never been a greater imperative for all of us to act on climate change and to have a clear understanding about what the impacts will be if we do not. In fact, with 85 per cent of Queenslanders living on our coastline, we would be more affected by climate change than any other state in Australia.

XML.Hansard-Body: Given the devastation of the natural disasters our state has endured and our vulnerability to the impacts of climate change, it is truly a coup that this week Cairns is hosting the internationally renowned climate change conference, GREENHOUSE 2011: The Science of Climate Change. The conference has brought together over 450 national and international delegates, with presentations from world-leading scientists and climate change experts including Tom Knutson from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration in the United States of America, who is an expert on the impacts of climate change on tropical cyclones; Dr Gillian Cambers from the Pacific Climate Change Science Program, who is an expert in coastal zone management and small island sustainability; and Australia’s own experts such as the CSIRO chief executive Dr Megan Clark, Bureau of Meteorology director Dr Greg Ayers and distinguished economist and climate change adviser Professor Ross Garnaut. This is a great opportunity for the scientists and representatives from industry and all levels of government to hear about the latest in climate change science from leading researchers from Australia and around the world.

This afternoon I will be presenting to the conference our latest climate science report, the Queensland coastal processes and climate change report. The report is the first of its kind in Queensland and discusses how coastal processes have shaped the coast and how climate change will affect them in the future. It divides the coast into five regions and outlines the vulnerability of each to climate change impacts, such as erosion and inundation from sea level rise.

Queensland’s diverse coastline is one of our greatest environmental icons, but it is also one of our most vulnerable assets. That is why we need to understand these threats and what we can do to mitigate them.
Mr Messenger interjected.
Ms JONES: I take that interjection. The member does not believe in climate change?
Mr Messenger interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Burnett will cease interjecting.

Ms JONES: With a clearer understanding of Queensland’s coast, we can plan for how to adapt to the impacts of climate change and minimise the impacts on our communities. This report provides planners, policy and decision makers with the latest climate change science to support their decision making. It takes leadership in government to tackle these issues head-on, but it is essential for our state’s future.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport) (10.20 am): The Bligh government is focused on rebuilding. We are rebuilding Queensland and we are also continuing to deliver services to help rebuild families. Since the last election, the Minister for Community Services and I have unveiled the $55 million Helping Out Families initiative. Our early intervention and prevention program is providing the right support at the right time to prevent families from entering the child protection system. Families are accessing services on the Gold Coast, Logan and Beenleigh.

XML.Hansard-Body: I am pleased to inform the House that Helping Out Families has received 817 referrals. That is 817 families who have access to the help they need so that they can provide a safe and loving home. It makes good practical sense to address problems early to ensure that we achieve the best possible outcome for children and families. It is about building positive relationships to help families stay together.

This government is also helping to rebuild families through our Indigenous family support services. We have invested $9.4 million this financial year across Queensland. These services provide culturally appropriate support programs to those in need. This includes help with parenting skills, in-home support, which looks at how to manage a household and a budget, and also helping parents address their child protection concerns. By improving parenting skills, we can help provide a safe and nurturing environment for children.

Indigenous family support services also have a strong focus on early intervention. Since services began from mid-2010, 530 families have received support. On top of this, since the last election we have provided $165,000 for staff at these services to receive training so that they can help teach their clients positive parenting skills. This is for the delivery of the highly regarded Triple P--Positive Parenting Program. Today I can announce that I have approved funding to allow 20 more staff members to benefit from this unique program. The Queensland Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Child Protection Peak is fully behind this initiative. This government remains committed to providing the right services at the right time to ensure that Queensland’s most vulnerable children and young people get a flying start in life. This is another example of the Bligh government delivering for Queensland.

Hon. CA WALLACE (Thuringowa--ALP) (Minister for Main Roads, Fisheries and Marine Infrastructure) (10.22 am): The Bruce Highway has been cut far too many times this wet season. That is why I wish to inform the House that the Main Roads investment funding unit has produced a first estimate of the funding needed to stop flooding on the Bruce Highway. It is a sobering report, because it says that around $5.3 billion is needed to accomplish the task along the 1,600 kilometres between Brisbane and Cairns.

Main Roads looked at the Bruce Highway, which is a federally funded road, identifying major trouble spots and the likely cost to fix these sections. Costs for flood immunity works along the specific sections were Brisbane to Gympie, $1.3 billion; Gympie to Mackay, $1.3 billion; and Mackay to Cairns, $2.8 billion, which includes around $800 million to help solve flooding in the Ingham area. The study sets a standard of no more than 48 hours closure in the event of a one-in-50-year flood from Mackay to Cairns and not more than 12 hours closure from Gympie to Mackay in the event of a one-in-50-year flood. The $5.3 billion cost is only for improving flood immunity, not for upgrading the road to widen it or to make other improvements, although immunity improvements and upgrades might occur at the same time.

I am sure members from both sides of this House agree that there needs to be much more progress to flood proof the Bruce Highway, and I am certainly one of them. People in Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra would not put up with their National Highway being cut. Why should we in Queensland? A generational commitment from both sides of federal politics is needed to stop flooding on the Bruce Highway. What we experienced this wet season is a symptom of neglect of our National Highway in Queensland by both sides of federal politics for the past 40 years. But we should give credit where credit is due, because the Gillard government has quadrupled road funding for the Bruce Highway in its first term. A total of $5.3 billion is obviously a massive request. That is why we need both sides in Canberra to commit to fixing this problem once and for all.

I will be taking some action. I will be discussing this new report with my federal counterparts as soon as possible. I will also be working on a plan to get more funding to reduce those flooding closures on the Bruce Highway, but this plan will need a commitment from both sides of politics at the federal level.

Hansard-Body.A: (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.25 am): The Committee of the Legislative Assembly--the CLA--was established by resolution of the House on 10 March 2011 to consider issues arising from the report of the Committee System Review Committee, the debate of the report in the Legislative Assembly on the noting of the committee report and the government’s response to the committee report. On behalf of the CLA, I wish to advise the House of the progress of the committee.

XML.Hansard-Body: Since its establishment, the CLA has met on three occasions. During that time, the non-government membership of the CLA has changed in accordance with changes in the opposition. Nonetheless, the CLA has made considerable progress in respect of major issues, all in a bipartisan manner. In terms of the establishment of the new parliamentary committee system, the most pressing item for consideration by the CLA was the number and jurisdiction of the new committees. The committee has agreed upon the new committee system, which must be finally approved by this House as follows: the establishment by standing orders of seven portfolio committees. They are (1), Finance and Administration Committee; (2), Legal Affairs and Police Committee; (3), Industry, Education, Training and Industrial Relations Committee; (4), Environment, Agriculture, Resources and Energy Committee; (5), Community Affairs Committee; (6), Health and Disabilities Committee; and (7), Transport, Local Government and Infrastructure Committee. I table for the benefit of all members a table showing the proposed seven portfolio committees and their portfolio and oversight responsibilities.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Table of proposed new portfolio committee structure [ 4206 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: The committee also agreed upon the continuation of the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee. In addition, the Members’ Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee will continue to hear complaints about the ethics of members or breaches of parliamentary privileges as a renamed Ethics Committee. It is proposed that the ethics committee will also operate as an oversight committee for the statutory officers of the House: the Auditor-General, the Integrity Commissioner, the Ombudsman, the Electoral Commissioner and the Information Commissioner.

The CLA has also proposed that estimates for the statutory officers it oversights be conducted by the Ethics and Oversight Committee. The Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee and the Ethics and Oversight Committee will have the same membership, performing dual roles.

It is apparent that some of the portfolio committees are likely to have a higher legislative workload than other portfolio committees. Similarly, other committees will have responsibility for monitoring portfolios with enormous expenditures and service delivery. Others will monitor portfolios that involve many detailed and interesting policy issues. It is virtually impossible to evenly allocate the responsibilities of government across a portfolio committee system, but the CLA believes that the establishment of the seven proposed portfolio committees achieves a good mix and balance. However, the CLA welcomes feedback on its proposal.

In terms of time line, it is expected that the new portfolio committees will be established in the next sitting week of 10 May to 12 May. It is expected that the committees will not meet during the regional sitting in Mackay from 24 May to 26 May, but that the timetable of the House will be changed to enable the new portfolio committees to meet on each Wednesday morning from budget week of 14 June to 17 June 2011.

The CLA has agreed that the initial focus of the new portfolio committees must be the new estimates process from budget week to the estimates process in July. Therefore, it is anticipated that the new legislative process will commence after the budget is returned in August and that bills already introduced and on the Notice Paper prior to the August sitting week will not be referred to the new portfolio committees. The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee will, however, continue in existence to examine legislation introduced until the June sitting week, with the SLC ceasing to exist from 1 July.

The CLA is conscious that in the period between May and August extensive education is required for members, staff, the public sector and the public generally about the new estimates and legislative process. The CLA is already considering the details of this educative process. The CLA has also turned its attention to the accommodation and resource needs for the new committee system. Later today legislation, which will facilitate the establishment of the new committee system, will be introduced into the House. I trust that the matters that I have just reported on from the CLA will inform the debate on that legislation.

(10.30 am): I table the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 4

XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind)
(10.30 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1) The report No. 105 of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee (IEPPC) of June 2010 recommended that this House find Mr Nuttall committed contempt of this place on 36 different occasions.
2) The report also recommended that Mr Nuttall be fined two thousand dollars for each of the 36 contempt charges.
3) Mr Nuttall under Standing Orders has the obligation and right to appear before this place and be heard in his defence as a result of the adverse findings.
4) Mr Nuttall’s appearance was delayed because of a potential prejudice to Mr Shand’s trial.
5) Mr Shand’s trial is now concluded with a guilty verdict.
6) Mr Nuttall is ready, willing, able and desires to be heard at the earliest opportunity before the bar of this parliament.

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 7) The Clerk of the Parliament and the Davis independent legal report advises that Mr Nuttall’s appearance in this place will not prejudice any legal appeal by Mr Shand.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Premier to comply with Standing Orders and put to the House the question that Mr Nuttall appear before the bar of this parliament on Tuesday, 10 May 2011 in order to be heard in relation to the IEPPC’s report 105--36 contempt findings.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: I welcome to the public gallery today students, teachers and parents from the Woodridge State High School in the electorate of Woodridge, the Robina State School in the electorate of Mermaid Beach and the Mount Warren Park State School in the electorate of Albert. Question time will end today at 11.32.

Mr SEENEY
(10.32 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to the 119 per cent increase in electricity prices since this Labor government came to power in 1998, which is more than twice the 47 per cent increase in the cost price index for the same period. I also refer to the 174 per cent increase in water costs since this Labor government came to power in 1998, which is four times the increase in the cost price index for the period. I ask: can the Premier explain to Queensland families why they must continue to endure these massive increases in their cost of living due to the policies of this failed Labor government?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. Like every member of this House, I share concerns about growing cost-of-living pressures on families. What I know is that many families face many bills. We know, for example, that one of the most expensive bills that most families face is their mortgage bill. We also know that families have to pay their rates if they are owner-occupiers. I am concerned about the increasing rates bills that have been charged by South-East Queensland mayors. I am particularly concerned about the growing rates bills--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The House will come to order.

Ms BLIGH: I am particularly concerned to see what has happened in the Brisbane City Council area, despite promises by the former mayor that rates would not rise above the rate of inflation. That was the promise: rates increases would not go above the rate of inflation or he would resign. What was the rate of inflation over the period? It was 21 per cent. What was the average increase in Brisbane rates? It was 42 per cent. That is double. But of course it was not only owner-occupiers that were hit: community groups, such as the Richlands Soccer Club, saw rate rises of 54 per cent. And, of course, unit owners in Brisbane have seen some of the largest rate rises in the history of the city, some going from $98 a quarter to a staggering $700 a quarter.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Both sides of the House, the Premier has the call.
Ms Grace interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Brisbane Central will cease interjecting.

Ms BLIGH: I sincerely hope that the new mayor of Brisbane will, in fact, curb rate increases and give families that have been suffering under these increasing rate rises some relief. I hope we see a very different attitude from the new mayor of Brisbane than we saw from the one who has just walked away from the city.

Mr SEENEY: My second question without notice is also to the Premier. I refer to the huge increases in costs of living suffered by Queensland families resulting from the Labor government’s imposition of a fuel tax, its imposition of increased motor vehicle registration fees and the increase in public transport fees, and I ask: does the Premier now accept that the imposition of these additional government imposed cost-of-living charges has impacted harshly on Queensland families and was a bad mistake from a failed Labor government?
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my right will cease interjecting.
Mr Wallace interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Minister for Main Roads.

Ms BLIGH: As I indicated in my answer to the last question, on this side of politics we are deeply concerned about the cost of living for working families. That is why in Queensland we work very hard to make sure that people pay less for their electricity than they do in Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. I want to have order.

There are 40 per cent increases in Western Australia. But what do we on this side of politics do to make sure that those who are most vulnerable, those who have the lowest incomes, those who need protection are protected from these pressures? We have an extensive system of rebates to look after people who need that help. In the south-east corner, where we have the challenge of paying off the water grid, we have a water rebate. We also have an electricity rebate and, above and beyond that electricity rebate, we cross-subsidise regional Queensland so that they can be guaranteed the same electricity price as those in the south-east.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting. As I understand the question, it was about cost of living and the Premier is answering that question. The Premier has the call.

Ms BLIGH: Under the administration of our government, Queenslanders continue to pay less tax than their counterparts anywhere else in Australia. We pay $417 less per year than the average tax rate of the rest of the states of Australia. Keeping taxes and charges low by comparison to the rest of the country is something that drives our financial strategy and it is something that we will continue to ensure is part of our financial strategy: looking after those people who are vulnerable, like pensioners, through rebates.

I note with disappointment that there is no water rebate from the Brisbane City Council. Other councils can do it, but the largest council cannot. It is good enough for the Gold Coast City Council and good enough for the Moreton Bay Regional Council but not good enough for the largest council in the state. We will continue to look after people through rebates. We will continue to look after regional Queensland through cross-subsidisation of energy. Ms GRACE: My question without notice is to the Premier. Can the Premier update the House about the financial assistance that has been provided to councils to rebuild their communities that were affected by floods and cyclones over the summer?

Ms BLIGH: We have now seen almost $400 million worth of natural disaster relief funding go out the door and into the coffers of councils so that they can get on with the job of rebuilding their communities. Many people in the House will know that for many years, under all sides of politics, the arrangements under natural disaster relief provisions that have prevailed are that councils do the work, incur the costs and then submit invoices that go through both state and federal checking processes. That means that councils, and often quite small councils that do not have a big rate base, are left with the holding costs or carry that debt on their books. Through the new system established under the Reconstruction Authority, we have brought those payments forward and paid them in advance. That gives the councils absolute confidence to contract the work and get on with the business of rebuilding their communities.

We all know that some of our smallest councils were the worst affected. The Cassowary Coast and the Lockyer Valley bore the brunt of the worst of the disasters. Their councils are among our lowest rate based councils with very small populations. The Cassowary Coast Regional Council has had $19 million delivered to it, the Hinchinbrook Shire Council has received $17 million and the list goes on. The councils are absolutely focused on the task before them. They are working hard to make sure that they can look their constituents and citizens in the eyes and say, ‘When you were down and when you were in trouble, I stood by you. When you needed me and the leadership of this council, we stood up to be counted.’

For the life of me, I cannot imagine Rob Chandler walking away from the people of Alpha and Jericho. Can anyone imagine someone of the calibre of Donna Stewart leaving her post? Would Brad Carter turn his back on Rockhampton or would Peter Maguire turn his back on the people of Emerald? Would Bill Shannon leave the people of the Cassowary Coast? Would Steve Jones? No, he will go the distance. Can anyone imagine Ray Brown walking away from the people of Condamine? The Mayor of Ipswich, Paul Pisasale, would sooner fly to the moon than leave the people of Ipswich. I pay tribute to each and every one of the mayors for going the distance, for standing with their people, for sticking with their task, for meeting their civic duty. They are people of substance, people of character and people who have values.

Ms PALASZCZUK: I would like to thank the honourable member for her question. It is a very environmentally sensitive part of an area that I represent. In fact, the member for Mount Ommaney also has a very keen interest in the area. She works very actively with the local green groups in the area.

Pooh Corner is a very important parcel of land. It is environmentally sensitive. Over the years, a very strong campaign has been run to protect this significant parcel of land for future generations. Therefore, I was surprised to see on the front page of today’s local paper an article in which the local councillor for Jamboree misleads the public by saying that there were plans to build a railway depot on the site. Today, I confirm for the shadow minister for transport that, due to the environmental significance of this parcel of land, it was completely ruled out by Queensland Rail. I am advised that it has been completely ruled out.

Clearly, this is what the opposition is doing. All you do is whip up community and public concern when it is not needed. Not one person raised that issue with me or the member for Mount Ommaney. All you are doing is whipping up hysteria.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Direct your comments through the chair.
Ms PALASZCZUK: That land is protected and that land will continue to be protected. No railway depot will be built on that land.
Mr WENDT: My question is to the Premier. Can the Premier update the House on the progress of the local disaster heroes program?

Ms BLIGH: Members will have heard me talk about this program and call on them to nominate people whom they know have in some way helped their community or a neighbouring community get back on its feet. Last Friday nominations closed for the local disaster heroes program. The program has been embraced with open arms by communities right across the state. I am pleased to advise the House that around 3,000 hero nominations have already been processed and daily many more are arriving by post from across Queensland. I thank members from both sides of this House who have worked to make sure that people who played a role have been nominated. I congratulate them for playing that role in their communities.

Every single one of the nominations represents one of the thousands of stories of the people who kept the Queensland spirit alive during our darkest hours. We have seen nominations for local businesses, clean-up volunteers, people who baked cakes and even some media personalities have been nominated. This year during Queensland Week we will all have a chance to say thanks. Queensland Week will be extended slightly to run from 4 to 13 June. Nine events will be held--in Grantham, Townsville, Rockhampton, Emerald, Bundaberg, Ipswich, Innisfail, Toowoomba and Brisbane. Obviously, many more communities will hold events, but those nine locations will host the major events. We will be inviting every nominee to come to one of those events, but I know that some communities will host their own events around the nominations. People who have attended one of the big events may find that a local event will be held to say ‘thank you’ or ‘congratulations’. I encourage that. If that is what mayors want to do, we encourage them to do so. Some of my members have told me that they want to hold thank you and congratulatory functions after people have received their recognition.

At the events, people will be provided with a specially cast medal that commemorates the contribution that they made. The hero awards are for community members, but at the events we will also see uniformed officers such as police, ambulance and emergency service workers recognised and presented with a service medal in relation to both the floods and the Cyclone Yasi event, as appropriate.

I want to praise every one of those people who have been nominated. These are people whom the rest of their community saw stand up. When someone needed to be counted, when a hand needed to be lent, these are the people who did it. I encourage everyone to get behind this program and to recognise the great efforts that these people have made.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Treasurer. I refer the Treasurer to the recent release of the Commonwealth estimates of the effects of Labor’s proposed carbon tax imposing an extra $860 on Australian families. Given that the Queensland Labor government supports this tax, when will the Treasurer release Queensland Treasury modelling on the effect on Queensland families?

Mr FRASER: I thank the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and I suppose shadow Treasurer at this point for his question. The reality, of course, is that what we saw released into the public arena last year was not modelling of any proposed tax because there has not been any detail of the nature of that tax decided upon by either the federal government or the House of Representatives, let alone the Senate. So the notion that there is something to be modelled is not, in fact, the case.

The point is this: what we are talking about here as a nation is confronting the real effects of human induced climate change. This is the side of parliament that accepts the reality of climate change. The reality is that this is the side of politics that accepts the need to confront climate change and to deal with it. What are we dealing with here? We are dealing with a massive market failure--the externalising of carbon out of the economy. The weight of scientific evidence and the weight of policy advice is to price carbon into the economy. This is the side of politics that ultimately will deal with climate change.

The question for the other side is: where do they stand now? Where does Campbell Newman stand now? He was out this morning talking about his green heart. Does he have a green brain? Does he accept human induced climate change? Or is he going to be beholden to the faceless men of the LNP--to Bruce McIver, who is a climate change denier--or to the Leader of the Opposition, who is one of the best climate change deniers? Has he now had to bankrupt himself, as the former Leader of the Opposition had to do, and deny his past policy position?

The real question here today is: where does Campbell Newman stand now? We have all heard him go out there and talk about climate change. We have all heard him say that he accepted the reality. But where is he now? He is dancing to the tune of the banjos who deny climate change--the old boys from the National Party who came in and traduced the Liberal Party in this place. They are calling the shots. They are picking the leader. They are picking the shadow cabinet. They are saying it is 1,250 bucks a throw to get into the shadow cabinet. How many members opposite have paid their 1,250 bucks to find out whether they get to be in the shadow ministry? Who has paid their dues to be in the shadow ministry? Not one of them, because this mob in here is not being run by anyone in this chamber. They are dancing to the tune of those outside--those who deny climate change, those who refuse to deal with its consequences.

This is the side of politics that says unambiguously to the people of this state, to the future generations of this state, that we unambiguously will confront the challenge of climate change and deal with it. The real question is: where does Campbell Newman stand on this issue today?
Mrs SMITH: Mr Speaker, may I first acknowledge in the public gallery the principal and school leaders from Caningeraba State School in the electorate of Burleigh.
