Mrs SMITH: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for State Development and Trade. Can the Treasurer update the House on any recent independent examinations of Queensland’s finances?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Burleigh for her question and for her interest in ensuring that the Queensland economy and the state’s finances are positioned for the future for future generations in Queensland.

As I said this morning, we saw Standard & Poor’s issue their latest credit rating on Friday. They pointed to a ‘robust, strong and diversified’--their words--Queensland economy. They also pointed to this government’s ‘excellent financial management’--their words again. I want to quote from the report. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland’s financial management is excellent in our view. In response to the floods and expected reduction in self-generated revenues, the Queensland Government is undertaking further savings measures as part of its midyear review and is currently conducting a review of spending priorities as part of the 2012 budget process.
XML.Hansard-Body: There it is from the ratings agency. They point to the challenges that continue in terms of our budget performance. They point to the challenges that come from growth and exacerbated by the current natural disasters. But there it is in full, telling it like it is.

There is, however, a set of public finances that the ratings agency cannot comment on anymore--about which they cannot tell it like it is and on which they cannot pass independent judgement. Who might those be? When Standard & Poor’s reviewed the Brisbane City Council’s finances in 2007--I note it is a AA plus credit rating, not a AAA credit rating under Campbell Newman--what did they say? They put Brisbane City Council on negative watch. What was Campbell Newman’s response to being put on negative watch? Did he put in the hard yards? Did he put in place a policy? No. He sacked the ratings agency. Imagine if in 2009 my response was to sack the ratings agency! Why did he do that? Because he does not like answering questions. He does not like answering questions about why rates have risen 42 per cent despite his pledge to keep them in line with inflation. He cannot answer why the toll on the Clem7 tunnel today is $3.95 when he said it would be $2. He cannot answer why he sunk $770 million of ratepayers’ money into a financially collapsed tunnel--the Clem7 is now in receivership--because he does not like answering questions.

One thing he can do is pull the Leader of the Opposition into line. Old ‘Yap Yap’ got the old dog into line last week. He put the dog collar on him and brought him to heel. He got the short leash on the Leader of the Opposition. When he stood up, Campbell Newman proved that he could get right up on tippy-toes and bring the Leader of the Opposition into line, because he wanted to have a go at being deputy but then he found out that the deputy deputy wants to be the deputy and the deputy deputy deputy down the other end wants to be the deputy. And now they have John Brent in the game because he wants to be the deputy from outside the parliament. What we know is that there is a complete absence of leadership on that side of the parliament. The Leader of the Opposition has been brought to heel.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Both sides of the House will come to order.
Mr Fraser interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Treasurer.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: And the Leader of the Opposition now will cease interjecting.

Mr BLEIJIE: My question is to the Deputy Premier and Attorney-General. Does the Attorney-General support the gagging of senior public servants from revealing the total of unpaid SPER fines, which are reported to now total more than $630 million? Has the Attorney-General now rescinded the gag order set by his predecessor?
Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question, which, unfortunately, is based upon a false premise.
Mr Wilson: Is he a lawyer?

Mr LUCAS: I take the interjection of my ministerial colleague. Yes, he does purport to be a legal practitioner. SPER is about making sure we collect fines from people. I say this about the former Attorney-General and his record in relation to SPER. I say this about his record--
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Stop the clock. As I understand it, the Deputy Premier and Attorney-General was asked a question. He is answering that question. I cannot hear any abuse of any member of the opposition that would occasion interjection. Therefore, I call the honourable the Attorney-General. The Attorney-General has the call.

Mr LUCAS:
The former Attorney-General’s record in relation to SPER is a record that speaks for itself--a 15 per cent increase on the previous year in the collection of fines. That is what he did. What the taxpayers of Queensland want to know is what the former Attorney-General achieved in his time in terms of collecting those fines, and he achieved a 15 per cent increase. Why is that? It is because of the tough measures that were introduced under his watch.

People can play semantics about what is reported on websites and the like. If it makes people happy for us to report other information there, we have done that. But what matters is what is collected. Of course SPER, being the agency that it is--it collects fines, for example, for the Brisbane City Council--is not always able to determine how it might collect a debt if, for example, it is not provided with information from the body the debt is owed to. Also, half the SPER current debt of $293.7 million has been deferred as a result of the floods and cyclone. So it is misleading to compare year-on-year figures for the last two months. Fines have been suspended and we would expect that number to go up.

We saw some funny arguments from the shadow minister in relation to the thinking that the money should go to teachers, nurses and police--and it should. That is why the former Attorney-General achieved a 15 per cent increase in collecting fines. But there have been silly comments by the Police Union secretary that we should throw people in jail at the cost of 100,000 bucks a year. That would actually take money away from consolidated revenue. We on this side of the House will make sure that we have policies in place to collect fines where appropriate to make sure that those people who commit the offences pay their fines. But we will not throw good money after bad and put people in jail for fine defaulting in ordinary cases simply because it costs more money to do that than to actually recover the money, and it would take money away from consolidated revenue.
Mr LAWLOR: My question is to the Minister for Transport. Could the minister please outline to the House the latest measures in planning for Cross River Rail?

I am more than happy to address that issue a little later.

Cross River Rail, worth an estimated $8 billion, is the proposed new 18-kilometre north-south rail line in Brisbane’s inner city. It includes a new surface station at Yeerongpilly, a new 9.8 kilometre tunnel connecting to new underground train stations at Boggo Road, Woolloongabba, Albert Street and Roma Street and a new surface station at the Exhibition.

This great city, and indeed the Gold Coast, needs Cross River Rail. The government knows it, the opposition knows it and transport experts know it. However, we are not quite sure what the position now is from the opposition. An LNP press release of 24 October posted on the LNP’s website screams ‘Cross River Rail remains an LNP priority’. That is what you said. That was your policy position.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Address your comments through the chair, Minister.

Ms PALASZCZUK: ‘The opposition supports Cross River Rail,’ it said. It appears that the former lord mayor of Brisbane missed the memo completely because last month he curiously grabbed a platform of his own and suddenly called for Cross River Rail to be completely scrapped.

What does the shadow minister for transport think about that? The events that have followed now give us some motivation. This is a remarkable turnaround. This shows the clear divide in LNP policy in relation to this matter. Less than a year ago the former lord mayor said to the Brisbane Times --
Opposition members interjected.
Ms PALASZCZUK: You don’t want to hear it, do you. You don’t want to hear it. You don’t want to hear it because it shows how you are completely and utterly divided.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Stop the clock. I will wait for the interjections to stop. Minister, address your comments through the chair. Those on my left will cease interjecting.
Ms PALASZCZUK: The former lord mayor said a year ago--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: If we do not get the inner city rail project done, it affects the ability to run rail services right across the region.
XML.Hansard-Body: A second river rail crossing must be the next big step in our public transport system. Either we lock in a second river rail crossing or we lock in a future of overcrowded trains and congested roads. But what does Cross River Rail mean? It means easing congestion for commuters coming in from the outer regions of Brisbane. This benefits the people living in Logan, living in Caboolture, living in Ipswich, living down the Gold Coast. You need to work out your policy position on Cross River Rail. You need to work out your policy on Cross River Rail because clearly you formerly supported it and now you clearly do not.
Mr Nicholls interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Clayfield!
Mr Lucas interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: And the Deputy Premier!
Dr FLEGG: My question without notice is to the Minister for Education and Industrial Relations. It is now over 12 months since the government released--

Mr DICK: I thank the temporary shadow minister for education for his question. That is one prediction I will make today when Campbell Newman gets his way and clears out anyone who stands in his way, stands in the way of his ego, stands in the way of him monstering the opposition from outside the chamber--the democratic chamber of the parliament of Queensland. He has been caught out with a blatant lie--a blatant untruth--and the question that now must be asked is this: given the history and given the proof here of his long-term support for reform, why does he think he can get away with this untruth? When the history of the 2011 floods are written, history will record this candidate--this former lord mayor--deserting his post. He is a former Defence Force officer and he knows exactly what that means. He is a coward. He went missing in action and he deserted his post. The people of South-East Queensland and the people in the rest of the state will know and understand--
Ms BATES: My question without notice is to the Minister for Health. I refer to a leaked email from district oral health director for the Gold Coast which says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Some of the facts quoted such as financials were inaccurate, however the basis of the points raised are accurate and we all have to agree an unacceptable waste of public resources.

This is timely for us as we all know that our own fleet is not fully utilised. We are aware that prior to Christmas school staff were asked to ensure that they pre-planned to ensure that they had patients to come back to, some did, some did not. We are all aware that activity at some facilities has since been good, some almost nil.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: I table the email.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Email, undated, from the Director of Oral Health, Gold Coast Health Service District, regarding the school dental health service [ 4212 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Come to your question.
Ms BATES: I ask the minister to explain why his government is wasting money on an oral health scheme which is not achieving and is sitting idle wasting taxpayers’ money?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. I have never seen a more public admission of shame in my entire life--the shame that is borne by the opposition in this House and every other Liberal National Party member who in the federal Senate blocked $52 million of federal government funding for public dental health. The opposition does not want to recognise that Queensland has the best public Dental Health Program in Australia. That is what it does not want to recognise. Two million Queenslanders have treatments from this public Dental Health Program every year. There are more Queenslanders eligible for public dental health in Queensland than any other state. We fund public dental health in Queensland at the same level as New South Wales despite the fact that New South Wales has double the population.

There is nothing more deceitful than this opposition when it comes to public dental health. Not only did the Liberal National Party in the Senate consciously block and criminally neglect the Queenslanders of this state by stopping $52 million coming into Queensland; every opposition member in this House and those preceding them were deathly silent for 10 years as John Howard ripped $50 million out of the public Dental Health Program coming to Queensland--not just for one year but year after year after year. Ten years!
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The House will come to order. The minister has the call.

Mr WILSON: There will never be a greater confession from this Liberal opposition and National Party opposition. People in the bush are missing out because the National Party did not have the spine to stand up to its Liberal Party colleagues in the Senate. Some 187,000 Queenslanders have missed out on treatments because of your failure and your neglect to stand up for them.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Minister, direct your comments through the chair.

Mr WILSON: The record speaks for itself. If those on the other side had any guts, they ought to tell the public the truth that their failure and neglect in stopping that money means that 187,000 Queenslanders have missed out on public dental health which they are absolutely entitled to.

Ms FARMER: My question without notice is to the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport. Can the minister advise how the Bligh government has supported sport and recreation facilities across Queensland to help people lead healthy and active lifestyles? How does this compare with investment by local councils?

Mr REEVES: I thank the honourable member for the question. She is a great supporter of local sport, particularly in the Bulimba electorate. The Bligh government is committed to rebuilding and delivering services for Queenslanders. This government is continuing to support local sport and recreation facilities to help Queenslanders lead healthy and active lives. In 2010 the Bligh government delivered two rounds of sport and recreation infrastructure funding to help clubs upgrade their facilities. To date I have approved more than $20.6 million for 144 community infrastructure projects right across Queensland, and we worked with many councils across Queensland in delivering this funding. There have been 121 applications from councils seeking partnerships with the Bligh government to deliver better sport and recreation facilities. How many applications were there from the Brisbane City Council under ‘can’t-do’ Campbell’s watch? How many do members think? Zero! Nil! Zilch!
Ms Bligh: He was having lunch with his plotters!

Mr REEVES: He was obviously doing lunch with his plotters instead of putting in applications for sports and recreation. It seems Campbell is a can’t-do kind of guy when it comes to funding local sports and recreation projects. He does not understand that they are the lifeblood of our communities and suburbs. The man who thinks he will be a man for all Queenslanders would prefer to fund poorly used bike programs in the inner city than invest in many local sports and recreation facilities in the suburbs and towns. There was not one application--not one application! Instead, ‘can’t-do’ Campbell has cut and run, leaving Brisbane sports and recreation clubs in limbo at a time when people need leadership. In comparison, Ipswich council has made eight applications; Cairns Regional Council, four; and Redland City Council, two. ‘Can’t-do’ Campbell could not even be bothered lodging one. Despite the lack of interest in this program by ‘can’t-do’ Campbell, I am pleased to inform the House that the Bligh government approved $3.7 million of funds for clubs within the Brisbane City Council area to support clubs in the member for Ashgrove’s electorate such as Bowls Queensland, Enoggera squash club and The Gap junior Australian football club.
Ms Jones: Hear, hear!

Mr REEVES: I know the member for Ashgrove recognises the value of sport. Not only was ‘can’t-do’ Campbell not interested in sport; he could not even put any funding in the Active Inclusion Program--none! We received 37 applications from councils including South Burnett, Redlands, Tablelands.
An opposition member interjected.

Mr REEVES: They do not like it. People should be judged on their actions. ‘Can’t-do’ Campbell is all talk while the Bligh government listens, acts and gets results for the people of Queensland, particularly in sport and recreation. Those opposite and their can’t-do leader want to barrack from the sidelines but cannot even put in an application for sports funding while the Bligh government invests more funding in sport and recreation than any other state in the country. Unlike those opposite, we are focusing on rebuilding Queensland, including local sports clubs.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: My question without notice is to the Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women. Minister, I spoke to a small business owner yesterday who had to fill several vacancies in his business with people needing to relocate as there were no local applicants. These new residents will find affordable housing difficult to get. Minister, what is this government doing to build additional social housing in the Gladstone electorate?

Ms STRUTHERS: I thank the member for the question. I have met with her on several occasions and I know of her concern regarding affordable housing and social housing in her electorate. Unlike many members of the LNP, she has not opposed the nation-building spend on social housing. She has been a strong advocate for social housing, and I thank her for that. Unlike members of the LNP, who many times are in their local papers opposing social housing--including the former leader, the member for Surfers Paradise--the member for Gladstone has stuck up for social housing tenants, and I thank her publicly for that.

I understand the pressures on cities like Gladstone--growing cities, cities that are part of the mining boom in this great state of ours. I know that the Deputy Premier, who now has responsibility for those planning issues, is working with the member’s local community and working with mining companies to meet their commitments in relation to housing and that the Urban Land Development Authority is undertaking significant work in Gladstone.

There are a number of fronts on which we need to deal with this housing issue. One of them that is in my area of responsibility is social housing for people of Gladstone. As part of our package of support to people around the state, one of the new products we have is the National Rental Affordability Scheme. Under NRAS, we are funding, with the federal government, subsidies to private developers to build housing and to bring that housing to market at 80 per cent of the market rent. I have discussed the opportunities we have and will have into the future to bring that product into the Gladstone region.

We are working hard right around the state to make sure that people have an affordable place to live. Gladstone and some of our other cities around the state are certainly under significant pressure. I urge members opposite to give us the backing we need, to give us support. Throughout the past 12 or 18 months a lot of my energy has gone into working with local media where these people have opposed our housing developments--absolutely appalling opposition to public housing. Again, let me remind members of some of the comments from members opposite that we have had to deal with--feeding the paper with nonsense--such as from the member for Surfers Paradise 18 months or two years ago: ‘Not these people, not in this street’. That is the sort of attitude many of those members opposite have. That is the sort of attitude they have to public housing.
Our commitment is very strong. Members, how many new dwellings are we rolling out around the state?
A government member: Four thousand.

Ms STRUTHERS: More than 4,000. We have a big bucket of state money that we are working with. We have a partnership with the federal government to roll out social housing. We are absolutely determined in our efforts to give people the housing and the support they need. In this time of need, when people are facing their darkest days, we are helping people affected by floods and cyclones as well.
Ms O’NEILL: My question is to the Minister for Main Roads. Can the minister inform the House about federal funding for the Bruce Highway?

Mr WALLACE: That is a great question about the Bruce Highway. There is $2.6 billion from the current Labor government. I ask members to compare that to $840 million from the previous Howard government in its last five years. Labor stands for roads.

But what about this Campbell Newman character? He boasts that he will be able to build major roads such as the Toowoomba bypass and upgrade the Bruce Highway if he were Premier of the state. However, in today’s Townsville Bulletin he admits that the last time he travelled the Bruce Highway was 25 years ago when he was in an Army convoy. Twenty-five years ago! What does the pretend Leader of the Opposition think about that? What do those National Party members think about someone who has not driven along the Bruce Highway for 25 years? I reckon that is a shame. This side stands for better funding for the Bruce Highway and we will continue to fight for it.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Question time is over.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (11.33 am): This morning in the parliament we saw the Premier and a succession of ministers line up to attack Campbell Newman, the leader of the LNP’s election team. The people of Queensland have to ask why. It is because they are running scared. They know the track record of Campbell Newman. Government members can compare that track record with their own track record and they are shamed by the comparison. They are shamed by the comparison of the track records of Campbell Newman and Anna Bligh. They are shamed by the comparison of the track records of the Brisbane City Council and the Queensland state government.

XML.Hansard-Body: They know that Campbell Newman has stood up for the people of Brisbane. They know that Campbell Newman has delivered for the people of Brisbane and that, like all local governments across Queensland, the Brisbane City Council has been thwarted by a state Labor government that has failed to deliver. Like all local government leaders across the state, Campbell Newman has had enough of this failed Labor government. Campbell Newman is standing up for Queensland, because it is time to get rid of Bligh, Lucas and Fraser.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! It would be better for the dignity of the House if those members were referred to by their correct titles.

Mr SEENEY:
It is time to get rid of the Premier, the Treasurer and the Special Minister of State. Right across the state, Queenslanders are saying that they have had enough. They have had enough of a Labor government that hides the truth to dodge bad headlines. They have had enough of a Labor government that puts politics first. They have had enough of a Labor government that works only for itself, not for the people it represents--a Labor government that has not been able to plan for the future, that has not been able to cut the waste and that has not been able to stop spending Queenslanders’ money.

Campbell Newman put up his hand to become Lord Mayor because he believed that Labor had failed Queenslanders. Despite 11 years in power, the Labor led council failed to deliver decent roads, it failed to deliver the necessary infrastructure and it failed to support the people of Brisbane. Now, Campbell Newman is putting up his hand for all of Queensland.

Campbell Newman has lived in communities across the state. He has worked in Moura, he has worked in Toowoomba, he has worked in Duaringa and he has worked in Biloela. He knows Queenslanders, he has worked with Queenslanders and he wants to help Queenslanders, just as he has helped the people of Brisbane. Campbell Newman has spent half his life in Queensland. He has worked in the coal industry, the grain industry, the electricity industry and the telecommunications industry. He understands what makes our economy tick and he understands what it is going to take to rebuild our state.

That is why the Treasurer, the Premier and the Special Minister of State are running so scared this morning. That is why the Treasurer is somewhat pale when he sits and interjects in the parliament this morning. He knows the track record of the man who will lead the LNP in the next election. When Campbell Newman put up his hand to become the Lord Mayor of Brisbane, he was the unpaid, unelected Leader of the Opposition for the Brisbane City Council. That campaign lasted for two years and Campbell Newman worked every day unpaid to get elected so that he could turn Brisbane around. That is exactly what Campbell Newman will do now for all of Queensland. He will listen to the people of Queensland and he will deliver for the people of Queensland.

As Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Campbell Newman delivered the Clem7 tunnel. He convinced the government to take on Airport Link and the Legacy Way project. He delivered the Go Between Bridge and the Eleanor Schonell Bridge. He built cycleways and created and protected parks and green spaces. A wonderful statistic that I like is that Campbell Newman put 715 new buses on Brisbane’s roads in just seven years--715 new buses! He was the leader of a team that treasures the environment. They planted 1.38 million trees, saving 1,100 hectares of bushland from development. His can-do team adopted carbon offsets for council vehicles, Brisbane’s CityCats and the city’s bus fleet. Under his leadership, Brisbane City Council buys 100 per cent of green energy. One hundred per cent of the electricity requirements of the Brisbane City Council is green energy. That is doing something. Every traffic light, every streetlight, every council building is powered by green electricity, making Campbell Newman’s council the largest purchaser of green energy on the national grid.

This is what Campbell Newman does and this is why the Labor government is frightened of his move to state politics. This is the difference between Campbell’s can-do delivery and the Bligh government’s can’t-do rhetoric. It is the difference between what Campbell Newman can do and what Labor has continually failed to do.

Under Campbell Newman’s leadership, the LNP worked hard for the people of Brisbane. Under Campbell Newman’s leadership, the LNP team here in the state parliament will work tirelessly for the whole of Queensland. Twenty years ago Queensland did not have any debt. Twenty years ago--a time that the current Treasurer would struggle to even remember--Queensland had zero debt. Now we are heading for $80 billion worth of debt and it is getting worse.

The failed Treasurer in this failed Labor government, Andrew Fraser MP, readily admits that over the next four years we will see an accumulated deficit of $10 billion. The failed Treasurer in this failed Labor government, one Andrew Fraser MP, lost the state’s treasured AAA credit rating. That will be his legacy. That is what the people of Queensland will remember him for. He could not balance the books. Every year this government, the Bligh-Lucas-Fraser team, keeps spending more than it earns and Queenslanders are paying the price. They will pay the price for generations to come. They will pay the price of this failure. Can any Queenslander honestly say that life is better under this Labor government?

It is getting worse. As the failed Treasurer in this failed Labor government continues to deny the reality, the reality for Queenslanders is getting worse. It is getting worse with the Gillard government’s carbon tax which is going to have an extra $860 removed from Queenslanders’ family budgets. The Lord Mayor of Brisbane, Campbell Newman, stood up to the federal government when Labor tried to get out of supporting flood and cyclone effected local governments. Campbell Newman stood up to Canberra and demanded that it help councils that had damaged sewerage systems, road and public transport infrastructure. What did the Premier do? What did the Treasurer do? What did the Special Minister of State do? They did nothing. They simply did nothing. The comparison between what they achieved in that hour of need is stark when their performance is set against the performance of Campbell Newman in his role as Lord Mayor of Brisbane City. The Premier was ready to abandon the councils and the ratepayers of Queensland because of her politics. The Premier put politics before the people of Queensland.

Queensland used to be the envy of the nation. People wanted to come to Queensland. Now interstate migration has ground to a halt as Queensland has slid to the bottom of the ladder. Under Bligh, Lucas and Fraser Queensland is no longer the low tax state. Under this failed Labor government Queensland has lost its AAA credit rating. They have destroyed the state’s reputation. They have robbed family budgets and it will only get worse. A Campbell Newman team will ensure Queenslanders power Queensland again not politics, a Campbell Newman team will make sure that our state is a can-do Queensland again. A Campbell Newman LNP team will work for Queenslanders not ourselves. We will save Queenslanders money, deliver more and cut waste. We will be open and accountable and we will plan for the future, not live for the moment. A Campbell Newman led LNP will inject a new energy into Queensland and create new opportunities for our state. We will present a clear, stark choice between Can-do Campbell and ‘never-has-done’ Anna.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr WATT (Everton--ALP)
(11.43 am): From all the laughter on the other side they obviously know that I have great news for the electorate of Everton.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! The member for Everton has the call.

Mr WATT: In the two years since I was elected as the member for Everton, I have worked hard with my colleagues, the members for Ashgrove and Ferny Grove, to fight traffic congestion in our area. Everyone understands that one of the downsides of South-East Queensland’s huge population growth is the increasing traffic on our roads. The Bligh government is doing a lot to tackle growth and congestion in the south-east corner. We are providing incentives to move to the regions rather than the south-east, we are encouraging development in our inner city areas to stop urban sprawl and we are investing massively in new public transport to give people other travel options.

Despite these initiatives, congestion is still a fact of life in my area, which is why tackling it has been one of my biggest priorities since I was elected. Last year I surveyed locals about traffic. People told me that more than anything they wanted the bottleneck at the Samford Road-Wardell Street intersection at Enoggera fixed. This is the point where traffic heading to and from the suburbs in my electorate starts backing up. Congestion at this intersection is unacceptable and it is getting worse. Only this morning, I spent 15 minutes waiting to get through this intersection myself while on my way to parliament. Some time ago, the members for Ashgrove, Ferny Grove and I agreed that fixing the intersection was our shared No. 1 priority. We got the Minister for Main Roads, Craig Wallace, out to inspect the intersection for himself, most recently on 15 March, and I appreciate the efforts that the minister has made in this regard. We have had countless meetings with ministers and public servants. I have made seven speeches in parliament on the subject of traffic congestion and I organised a deputation of concerned local residents to meet with the Premier and the Minister for Main Roads about this intersection at December’s Albany Creek Community Cabinet.

The good news is that following all of this hard work the government has agreed to fix this intersection once and for all. The upgrade will happen in two stages. Stage 1 will extend the outbound left-turn lane on Wardell Street approaching Samford Road. Last year Minister Wallace committed to extending the turning lane and the project has now been scheduled to start mid-2011. I again thank the minister, his staff and his department for looking favourably at this project. Stage 1 will lengthen the turning lane from 30 metres to 115 metres and will be finished this year. This will let through 100 more cars in each change of lights and will improve traffic flow in the afternoon peak hour.
After completing stage 1 the government has committed to fund stage 2 over the next four years.
Ms Davis: Where’s the money coming from?

Mr WATT: This involves a massive widening of the intersection and increasing the number and length of turning lanes on both sides of Samford Road and the other side of Wardell Street. I take the interjection from the member for Aspley who, despite being the spokesperson for transport issues, does not seem to think that this is a priority for our area. This massive upgrade will fundamentally transform the north-west suburbs and the daily commute for many people in our area. It will reduce queuing times for commuters coming from Everton’s suburbs, particularly in the morning and on weekends.

The only thing that is not resolved is an exact start date for stage 2. It is great to have an ironclad guarantee that the work will happen, but we now want work on stage 2 to start as soon as possible. That is why, together with the members for Ashgrove and Ferny Grove, I have established an e-petition to persuade the government to start work now. It can be accessed through my website and I encourage all who want this intersection fixed now to join that e-petition. Already 76 people have signed the e-petition and I am expecting many more to follow in the days and weeks ahead.We understand that the government has to find millions of dollars to repair roads in flood and cyclone affected parts of Queensland, but we also want to make sure our area gets its fair share. With a bit more help from my constituents and my fellow north-west MPs, we will get this horrendous intersection fixed once and for all.

This latest announcement comes on top of a range of other roadworks that the Bligh government has undertaken or is undertaking to tackle traffic congestion in Everton. These include upgrading the intersection of Pickering Street and Samford Road; upgrading the intersection of Taylors Road, Prospect Road and Samford Road; extending the turning lane from Albany Creek Road onto Keong Road; improving the traffic lights at the intersection of South Pine Road and Flamingo Drive at Albany Creek; installing a turning arrow at the intersection of Faheys Road East and Old Northern Road to assist families dropping kids off at All Saints Primary School; and undertaking planning work to improve the intersection of Stafford Road and South Pine Road.

It is easy in this game to come out with glib slogans like ‘can-do’. What matters more is getting runs on the board delivering big improvements for your constituents and it does not get much bigger in my area than fixing the Samford Road-Wardell Street intersection once and for all. As a father, I understand that every minute spent in traffic is a minute not spent with your family. This intersection will make a huge difference to the lives of Everton families.

Hansard-Body.A: (Kallangur--ALP) (11.48 am): In the recent disastrous flooding that hit Queensland, my electorate of Kallangur was not immune from serious damage. Not only was there devastation to property below the North Pine Dam, but also the AJ Wyllie Bridge, which connects Petrie, Lawnton and Strathpine, was severely damaged and had to be closed for testing. In January, northbound lanes of the bridge, the low bridge, were closed as a result of this structural damage, which includes cracks and significant erosion to the foundations. The Department of Transport and Main Roads has undertaken comprehensive investigations of the bridge to determine the extent of the damage. Investigations included load testing, surveys of the water area with particular reference to tidal currents, crack mapping, geotechnical testing and hydraulic assessments. These have revealed cracking on sections of the structure, along with severe scouring where water has pushed away the earth at the base of some bridge piers. Most testing was not visible to the public and has led to some frustration because of the severe congestion caused by the closure of two lanes. This bridge sees a very large volume of traffic. The southbound bridge remains open to one lane of traffic in each direction.

XML.Hansard-Body: After a thorough investigation, taking into account the high volume of use and the financial and environmental issues, the department decided that a new bridge is the very best option. The new bridge will align with the existing higher southbound bridge and will make both bridges less prone to scouring and better able to handle flood flows. To have a bridge that will be less prone to flood damage and closure is the best outcome for the community. Building a new bridge to replace the 77-year-old structure will also save money on costly maintenance each year. The long-suffering users of the AJ Wyllie Bridge will certainly benefit from this new bridge but still will endure delays while the new bridge is constructed.

The first part of the project will be to demolish the existing bridge. That will happen as quickly as possible and be a mark of significant progress. As soon as the design and tender process is completed, the construction of the new bridge will begin. I know that the hardworking minister and the department of main roads will ensure that this project happens as quickly as possible because they fully understand the impact on us all. I thank the local community and businesses for their patience during the closure of the northbound bridge. The safety of all motorists and users of the bridge is our No. 1 priority and we are working hard to restore this important route for northbound travellers as soon as possible. Pedestrians and cyclists will be accommodated by a crossing further upstream and the team are investigating just where and how that will be managed. I know it will be hard, but I ask the community for its continued patience during the planning and building process for the new bridge.

During the testing and inspection stage, one of the biggest difficulties has been getting information out to the community. The minister and Main Roads staff have assured me that regular information bulletins will be issued regarding progress and the construction phases. Members of the public can also subscribe for SMS updates about the AJ Wyllie Bridge by visiting www.northpinebridgesms.com.au and following the prompts. I know that my office and that of the member for Pine Rivers, Carolyn Male, will ensure that information is distributed via our newsletters and networks. I thank Carolyn Male for her strong advocacy, and I thank the minister and staff for their attention to this critical matter for my electorate and the Pine Rivers community.

Hansard-Body.A: (Moggill--LNP) (11.52 am): It is now well over a year since the government released the Flying Start green paper on education. Whilst that is a discussion paper, it all but announced a 2014 move of year 7 into high school. The logic put forward by the government was that this was a part cohort due to the introduction of the prep year and that there was a need to move year 7 to come into line with other major states in preparation for the introduction of the national curriculum. Whilst those opposite like to tout their advertising agent’s slogan that the LNP is without policies, I remind the House that, just as I did with the Masters report, I gave a detailed response on how the LNP viewed the issues raised in Flying Start.

XML.Hansard-Body: Although the move of year 7 was one of the central issues raised in that discussion paper, once again the government was found hopelessly unable to plan ahead or even think through the critical implications of the move. It does not surprise Queenslanders that this government cannot plan education because it has been unable to plan in almost every other area of life in this state. Moving year 7 would impact on tens of thousands of Queensland families, thousands of Queensland teachers and the education of our young students. The government’s dithering policy paralysis has failed Queensland schools. Government and non-government schools were ramping up for the move that this government foreshadowed, but now they have no idea what is happening. In the absence of any leadership from this government, some have even decided to go it alone.

As the LNP has been urging the government to realise, Flying Start was a fatally flawed document. What has the government done since those warnings? It started off by indicating a 2014 move of grade 7 but never mentioned middle schooling or recurrent expenditure. It indicated an increase of over 50,000 students in Queensland high schools yet proposed only $350 million for capital works. That money, which is not new money, would be barely enough to fund non-government schools. It ignored completely the impact the move would have in remote and rural areas. This left Queensland high schools with the threat of serious overcrowding and an inadequate secondary teaching workforce.

Anyone who heard the minister’s response to my question this morning and who had any confidence that this minister could grapple with the issues in education planning would have had those allusions exploded. In a three-minute answer, when he had the opportunity to tell Queensland schools what his government was doing, he did not even mention his plans in relation to year 7. In a puerile and personal attack on the opposition, never once did he mention what his government is going to do, even though hundreds of schools and thousands of parents are waiting to hear the answer.

The LNP has urged the government to get real about the proposal on year 7. We immediately issued a response to the government’s Flying Start paper. I issued a further paper, detailing our belief that middle schooling was an important part of dealing with the move of year 7. There is an urgent need for this government to clarify the amount of money that will be needed for capital works. Our estimate is that it will be in excess of $1 billion if we want to avoid serious overcrowding. There is an urgent need for the government to address the workforce issues of providing an extra 2,000 specialised high school teachers. There is an urgent need for the government to detail how it will assist people in rural and remote Queensland.

The LNP has made it clear that, in government, we will allow this move to be driven by schools. There is an urgent need for the government to engage ACARA, to ensure that curriculum will not disadvantage Queensland students who might still be in year 7 in a primary school. At best, we think that a five-year move from 2015 is possible.

Hansard-Body.A: (Capalaba--ALP) (11.57 am): As I have said before in the House, my electorate is nestled close to some of the most spectacular environmental assets in South-East Queensland. We are close to Moreton Bay and we have the benefits of parks, green space and wildlife. We are also close to some magnificent resources and assets, such as North Stradbroke Island. People in the Redlands want to look after their surroundings and we take great pride in our natural environment. In the Redlands, business leaders are reflecting that sentiment.

XML.Hansard-Body: Many of our peak business organisations, such as the Redlands Institute and the Redlands Chamber of Commerce, have a keen interest in the role that businesses can play in becoming more sustainable. However, it is not just businesses in the Redlands that want to find ways to be more environmentally friendly. This desire is echoed by businesses right across the state. That is why the state government has invested millions of dollars in the ecoBiz program. The ecoBiz program is designed to help businesses make environmental and financial savings by implementing ecoefficient practices. It assists businesses to measure their current resource use, to identify the areas that can be improved and to help them to plan and implement ecoefficient and sustainable businesses practices.

Of the 600 businesses participating in the ecoBiz program, 84 have now completed the program and together they have saved more than 53,000 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions and 710 million litres of water. I am pleased to see that the state government recently congratulated six businesses that took part in the ecoBiz program. They were awarded for adopting innovative ways to save water, energy and overall costs at the recent Sunshine Coast Business Expo. One of those businesses was the Sunshine Coast TAFE, which has worked closely with the government to improve energy, water and waste efficiency. This has seen the Sunshine Coast TAFE reduce greenhouse gas emissions by almost 800 tonnes and running costs by over $180,000.

As a partner to the program for many years, the Good Guys Capalaba, which is in my electorate and is run by James Brockhurst, has made great savings. By encouraging the sale of ecoefficient appliances they have reduced their customers’ energy consumption by 36 per cent and reduced greenhouse gas emissions through the sale of ecoefficient washing machines and air conditioners.

Since 2005 James has been at the forefront of communicating sustainable product options to his customers while exercising responsible business operation efficiencies. James’s philosophy is very simple: businesses have a responsibility to provide a positive impact on their community, and the environment is a critical part of this. I concur with his business philosophy. This is a great example of a local business running an environmentally friendly and sustainable business.

The ecoBiz program not only saves the environment but also saves businesses’ bottom lines. Last year ecoBiz partners across the state reduced their running costs by more than $5 million. On average, each partner has reduced its annual resource costs by 14 per cent, saving over $80,000 annually. They have achieved this by reducing energy consumption by an average of 20 per cent, water consumption by 31 per cent and waste generation by a whopping 45 per cent. Many businesses that have been part of the ecoBiz program are moving on to take leadership roles and work with the government’s ClimateSmart Business Clusters program, which aims to promote and drive ecoefficiency improvements in energy, water and material and waste management.

I would also like to mention briefly the success of the Redlands energy conservation community. I am pleased to see that, due to the overwhelming success of the energy conservation community announced by the Premier last year, the service is now expanding across the Redlands to include all suburbs such as Alexandra Hills, the bay islands, Birkdale, Capalaba, North Stradbroke Island, Ormiston, Thornside and Wellington Point. Under the program, Energex installs small energy management devices onto air-conditioning units and pool filtration systems in participating homes which will cycle power between 4 pm and 8 pm on peak demand days. In my view, this is an excellent initiative. Ultimately, all these programs make good sense. More importantly, they are good for our community, for the environment and for our future generations.

Hansard-Body.A: (Caloundra--LNP) (12.02 pm): Over the past weeks we have seen the true position of budgets in Queensland Health revealed. We are now aware that the Metro South health service district faces a budget deficit of $90 million; the Royal Brisbane Hospital faces a deficit of some $60 million; the PA Hospital faces a deficit of some $34 million; and, as I understand, the Wide Bay health service district faces a budget blow-out of around 12 per cent. A memo signed by the chair of surgery at Princess Alexandra Hospital states--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: As part of a coordinated district wide challenge the division of surgery at the PAH has been instructed to reduce activity where possible by 10% during the last quarter of the current fiscal year.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He then goes on to state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To do this without compromise to the safety and quality of inpatients and the continued treatment of emergency cases, a number of unpalatable initiatives will be implemented. These will include a rotating roster of closure of some of our operating lists and beds in your wards with matched nursing staff reduction. These strategies will impact negatively on elective surgery waiting times, an outcome which I find “very disappointing” ...
XML.Hansard-Body: There we have it: the chair of surgery at the Princess Alexandra Hospital is saying that surgery will be cut so that this government can get its budget back to a balanced state. This means that as time goes by there will be fewer operations, fewer elective surgery procedures and more people waiting.
It goes on and gets worse. In a memo dated 15 March 2011 the district chief executive officer of Metro South made this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Queensland Health as a whole and Metro South within it have been amassing structural debt for quite sometime. The time has certainly come to address this by realignment and reform from top to bottom.
XML.Hansard-Body: I could not agree more. Reform is required within Queensland Health, and it has to start with the removal of this government, which has been so incompetent and so negligent as to deliver a health system that is crippled at its core and simply is not able to deliver effective, timely and efficient service to people across this state.

I also quote from a memo dated 21 March 2011 and signed by the acting executive director of Oral Health Services in the Metro South health service district, dealing with the issue of dental treatments. The email is in direct response to Dr Theile’s earlier memorandum. In relation to the impact upon dental services, it states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... if measures need to be taken which increase the wait for services it may not be within our power to prevent.
XML.Hansard-Body: This means that there will be longer waiting times for dental surgery and dental treatment--at least in Metro South. I have no doubt that this will translate right across the state so that the 108,000 people waiting for dental treatment will simply now have to wait longer. In the past six or seven years this government has spent something like $40 billion on the health system. And after all that, we are now seeing massive budget blow-outs and, more importantly, delays in elective surgery and patients receiving treatment on time.

Perhaps the most damning indictment of the public health system actually comes from Justice Ros Atkinson, in comments reportedly made recently in relation to an appeal against a sentence on the grounds that the defendant’s health had not been taken into account. The defendant had pleaded that his health should have been considered and a reduced sentence determined. As reported in the media, Justice Atkinson said that in her experience prisoners with medical conditions were often better in jail because of the treatment they received. The report then quotes the justice as saying--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In one case I knew of a man who would have died but for being in prison.
XML.Hansard-Body: Perhaps we will have a better idea when we receive the answer to a question on notice that I asked the minister on 8 March 2011 seeking details of how many doctors and nurses are employed within Queensland correctional facilities.

When we reach the point at which the prison system provides people with a better public health service, some serious questions have to be asked not just of this minister but also of the former health minister, the current Deputy Premier, and also the member for Stretton. These men have overseen a public health system debacle that resulted in the payroll system collapsing. Some $210 million has been spent to rectify a system which originally cost $69 million. After 12 years of Labor, we have a system with a massive budget blow-out and a system that does not deliver across the state on any informed basis.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (12.07 pm): Last week I had the pleasure of touring the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital facility at the Metro North health service district with CEO Keith McNeil. The Metro North health service district includes the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital, Prince Charles Hospital, Redcliffe Hospital, Caboolture Hospital, Kilcoy Hospital, subacute and residential care services, primary and community health services, mental health services and oral health services.

XML.Hansard-Body: The area I first visited was the emergency department, where I witnessed a number of patients going through various phases of the care process. There was a lot of activity and staff were fully absorbed in assessing patients according to the appropriate level of care needed and effectively providing medical attention to a large number of people, ranging from someone with unexplained aches and pains to someone requiring urgent surgery.

I was absolutely engrossed watching how the emergency team process flowed so smoothly, even to the extent that some patients requiring surgery were taken to the operating theatre within seven minutes of undergoing their initial assessment. The emergency staff continue to refine and improve their processes in relation to best patient care and efficiency of operation to cut waiting times and so that ambulance paramedics can get back on the road and on with the job as quickly as possible.

From there we scrubbed up and toured the operating theatres, which were all being utilised. I saw the highly skilled surgeons and staff undertaking a major prostate operation and then intensive pancreatic cancer surgery with the utmost care and attention to the patient, albeit I was at a safe distance. I heard some very sad and somewhat tragic stories in the ICU about various anonymous patients being treated who were involved in serious traffic accidents and someone who had serious burns to 80 per cent of their body brought about by injuries incurred while enjoying a favourite hobby with family members. The RBWH has an exceptional record in the successful treatment of serious burn injuries compared with many other leading countries.
Ms Grace: They are world’s best practice.

Mrs ATTWOOD: I agree with the member for Brisbane Central. I met with a number of staff to discuss their roles and how they work together to ensure that everyone who needs treatment is able to receive it to the best of their abilities. They cannot and will not turn anyone away when they need help. Nor can they predict the number of people needing help every day. Flexibility in their processes and operations is absolutely paramount in this busy hospital.

But the part of my visit that touched me the most was the walk through the neonatal unit. Tiny premature babies no bigger than my hand in some cases were being gently and lovingly cared for by skilled professional staff. It is just incredible and quite a miracle that during their three-month stay in most cases they grow to a normal size, overcoming the serious difficulties from birth to become part of a very happy and grateful family.

This visit to the RBWH really opened my eyes to how well our health system works and its many great miracles and achievements. This is due, in the most part, to the dedication and commitment of the hospital’s highly trained medical profession, nursing and allied health professionals, and state-of-the-art facilities and equipment provided by the Queensland government. I witnessed the special areas where training and patient consultation by specialists was provided to regional hospitals via video-telelink.

As the Parliamentary Secretary for Health, I am most disturbed by the fact that an estimated 80 per cent of people seeking help from our public hospital system are doing so because of illness or injury due to lifestyle issues. This is why the federal and state governments’ health reforms in relation to GP clinics and Medicare locals providing primary care for people in the community are an appropriate way to provide services in the future.

The district provides a full range of health services including rural and regional tertiary teaching hospitals and state-wide superspecialty services. Residential facilities managed by the districts include the Eventide Nursing Home at Brighton, Ashworth House, Jacana ABI Centre at Bracken Ridge, Cooinda House and the Halwyn Centre. Apart from the places in the RBWH I visited, the Metro North district provides a wide variety of primary healthcare services including oral health, mental health, child health, school health, aged care and rehabilitation, palliative care, chronic disease management, general primary medical care, and alcohol, tobacco and other drug services.
Outreach clinical services are provided in non-Queensland Health facilities such as high schools and primary schools--

Hansard-Body.A: (Maroochydore--LNP) (12.12 pm): Commuters are frustrated as they are caught in traffic jams several kilometres long and small businesses are hurting from loss of customers as regular road users avoid the AJ Wyllie Bridge over the North Pine River. I heard the Premier claiming this morning how quickly the government is responding to fix infrastructure damaged in the floods. Well, not in this area. The Premier did not mention any time frame to fix this problem bridge between Petrie and Lawnton.

XML.Hansard-Body: The government has taken this area for granted and grown complacent about the impact of the loss of these northbound lanes and has been slow to respond. It is three months since this critical link over the North Pine River was damaged in the floods, halving the capacity of this very busy road with only the southbound lanes able to be utilised for two lanes of traffic. The impact has been made worse due to the fact that the other local alternative route is via Youngs Crossing, and it is flood prone. When water is released from North Pine Dam, this road is closed. This community really has suffered a double whammy.

In addition, motorists from Dayboro do not even get the courtesy of a ‘road closed’ sign near that town to warn them that further down the road Youngs Crossing is closed. That is another issue, but it is worth mentioning as it is an example of how the state government and its agencies need to step up to the plate and help the community. As well as delivering a new bridge, in the meantime there is a need to help with better traffic management. This should also include the community of Dayboro and district to give them fair warning of road closures closer to home so they can take an alternative route.
The minister only announced the decision to replace the AJ Wyllie Bridge recently after LNP candidates Trevor Ruthenberg and Seath Holswich, together with the community, publicly lobbied for action--

Mr WALLACE: Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I find those comments offensive. They are untrue. We had divers have a look at that bridge. She is questioning the integrity of those divers, and I ask that those comments be withdrawn.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Does the minister find the comments personally offensive?
Mr WALLACE: I do, Madam Deputy Speaker. I find those comments personally offensive.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: I ask the member to withdraw.

Ms SIMPSON:
Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. That is not in accordance with the standing orders. It is not a personal reflection.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I have asked the member to withdraw.

Ms SIMPSON:
Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I draw your attention to the standing orders. That is not a personal reflection in regard to the minister. I ask for a ruling in this regard.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER: I ask the member to withdraw her comments.
Ms SIMPSON: Madam Deputy Speaker, I withdraw whatever the minister finds offensive.
Ms Male: No, unconditionally.

Ms SIMPSON: Well that is the only provision within the standing orders. The minister only announced the decision to replace the AJ Wyllie Bridge after public uproar about the fact that it had been so slow to respond. Our candidates, Trevor Ruthenberg and Seath Holswich, together with the community, publicly lobbied for action. However, I share their concern that more needs to be done by the government to help this community. We want to see more from the government--some compassion and support for this community and its local businesses, help with traffic management and the fast-tracking of the bridge’s replacement. The delay in announcing a replacement has no doubt slowed down this process.

A new bridge is good news, but we want to see more done to bring the construction of a new bridge forward and to address these critical issues that I have mentioned. Three months have passed since the northbound lanes were closed. This has a huge ongoing impact on this community. The traffic chaos continues for the people in this area. We will stand up, along with this community, and advocate for more to be done, because these people are hurting.

The response from the government has been slow. But the impact on the people has been fast, with businesses and locals feeling the impact on their pay packets and their pockets. I want to draw the attention of the government again to the fact that people do not have many local alternatives. Youngs Crossing Road floods frequently, leaving this bridge as the only link to these communities, except for a very large diversion.

Action on the AJ Whyllie Bridge has been long overdue even before the floods. There has been concern about the fact that this old bridge has not seen the attention of government particularly in regard to timely maintenance. What we have seen as a result is a community that has been left stranded. They have been left in a situation of intolerable hardship and, for many of those businesses, there is a question mark over whether they will survive.

This area is one of the fastest growing regions in Australia and the residents are tired of the inadequate transport infrastructure. They are tired of the fact that this government has been so slow to respond. We need to see a faster response in addressing these valid concerns, and more needs to be done than what has been announced to date.

Hansard-Body.A: (Morayfield--ALP) (12.18 pm): This Queensland Labor government continues to invest in our teaching professionals and in educational opportunities for our young people and continues to support initiatives which provide our kids with a flying start to their education. Last month I was very pleased to welcome the Minister for Education to the Morayfield state electorate for a Queensland-wide announcement at the Morayfield East State School. This announcement related to the establishment of four new teacher education centres of excellence, including one at the Morayfield East State School. These teacher education centres of excellence are about further enhancing the great work that our teachers are doing every day in our schools.

XML.Hansard-Body: Most people will remember from their schooling days that one teacher who changed their lives, that one teacher who connected with them, that one teacher who inspired them to reach their full potential. I was lucky--I had Mr Voss in physics, Mr Taylor in modern history and Ms Wilkins in English encouraging me to seize the educational opportunities before me. These centres of excellence are about developing more Mr Vosses, more Mr Taylors and more Ms Wilkinses. These centres of excellence are about supporting our teacher graduates to become outstanding teacher professionals who have the potential to change our young people’s lives. What a worthy vision that is. By investing in our teaching professionals we invest in our young people and, in turn, we invest in the future of our communities.

The Morayfield East State School will be the base for the Morayfield cluster schools centre of excellence. This means that not only will Morayfield East State School benefit from this significant investment in teacher training and excellence but Morayfield State School, Minimbah State School, Morayfield State High School and Jinibara State School will also benefit.

Each teacher education centre of excellence will focus on a specific area of teacher training excellence. For instance, the centre at Kelvin Grove State College will focus on early childhood education and the middle phase of learning. The one at Morayfield East State School will focus on improved student performance in low socioeconomic areas. The Mount Stuart cluster schools centre of excellence will focus on Indigenous students and community engagement. The centre at Aspley State Special School will focus on special school education. The one at Benowa state and state high schools will focus on science and mathematics education.

As noted by Professor Geoff Masters in his review of the education system in Queensland, we know that there is a strong connection between excellent teacher training, effective teaching and student outcomes. These centres will help us attract and train the best teachers for our schools and will help us continue to offer a world-class quality education to all of Queensland’s young people. These centres will partner clusters of Queensland state schools with Queensland universities to ensure high-performing pre-service teachers are classroom ready and are trained in specific targeted priority education disciplines.

I am very proud that this Queensland Labor government is significantly investing in teacher excellence and educational opportunities for our young people. But some people may still ask: why do governments invest in education? Well, the answer is very easy. This Queensland Labor government invests in programs like the Teacher Education Centres of Excellence program because this government believes in people. This government believes in the potential of young people. This government believes that education is everything; that education is the silver bullet that breaks the cycle of disadvantage and marginalisation. By investing in education, we invest in the potential of our young people. By investing in our young people, we invest in the future of our communities. That is why governments should invest in education. That is why this Queensland Labor government is investing in teacher education centres of excellence.

I would like to take this opportunity to formally congratulate Dr Brian Gray, the principal of Morayfield East State School; Ms Janelle Amos, the principal of Morayfield State High School; Ms Vicky Gahan, the principal of Morayfield State School; Mr Mark Farwell, the principal of Minimbah State School; Mr Brad Fox, the acting principal of Jinibara State School; and teachers Ms Jodie Riek and Ms Sandra Doyle-Robinson for their efforts in respect of the Morayfield schools cluster centre of excellence. They are certainly helping our kids to have a flying start to their education.

Hansard-Body.A: (Nanango--Ind) (12.23 pm): I rise to bring to the attention of the House the concerns of people in the Nanango electorate with regard to health services in general but particularly the renal dialysis service in Kingaroy. As members would be aware, over the last few years the people of the South Burnett have fought hard to endeavour to have a renal dialysis service established in the Kingaroy Hospital. Members can imagine how pleased we were when in 2008 then health minister Stephen Robertson announced that we would get such a facility in the area.

XML.Hansard-Body: As members would be aware, our main concern at the time was that so many renal dialysis patients had to travel to Toowoomba and further afield to get their treatment. Some of those patients had to travel well in excess of three hours to get treatment. Some live an hour from Kingaroy and had to make the trip to Toowoomba. They would leave very early in the mornings and it was fairly late in the evening when they got back home--seven, eight or nine o’clock in some cases. It was a very arduous and long trip.

We were pleased to get this renal unit at Kingaroy. The minister said at the time that there would be $603,000 in recurrent funding each year to ensure the renal unit delivers a sustainable service. Everyone was happy. It is quite distressing to find out that at this point in time the unit is not operating to its full potential. It is only operating three days a week. It is my understanding that it only treats six patients per day.

It is distressing to hear that approximately five renal patients are still having to travel to Toowoomba for their treatment. Given the recent floods and the damage that has been done to the roads in the area that trip is now a lot more difficult than it was before. I would not think there would be a person who would think that all patients in the area should not be treated at the unit at the Kingaroy Hospital. Why is the unit not operating at least five days a week? Is that because there is not sufficient funding? If that is the case, we would ask that funding be supplied. Is it because there are insufficient trained staff able to operate that machinery? If that is the case, we would ask that extra emphasis be placed on obtaining staff to operate the service. It is a great unit and we are more than pleased to have it, but we would like to ensure that anybody in the South Burnett region who requires renal dialysis is able to access their treatment at this hospital.

It has recently been brought to my attention that the Cherbourg renal unit is no longer operating. I will be asking the minister to check this out for me. It is an essential service in that town. It should not be sitting idle. The reasons for that I am not sure about. The matter needs to be investigated. There is no point having this kind of service inoperable. It is not a cheap service. The equipment is quite expensive and it needs to be utilised to its full extent.

I would ask the minister to ensure that the South Burnett renal dialysis service operates fully at least five days a week and that it services all patients in the area. I would ask the minister to clarify exactly why the Cherbourg renal unit is not operating at all. I have sought information from the health service in the South Burnett. I am looking forward to positive outcomes for both these units so that they can service the patients that need this service.

Hansard-Body.A: (Broadwater--ALP) (12.28 pm): As I talk with people in my electorate about how busy the Gold Coast is and how much our city has grown there are two projects that Gold Coast residents are keen to hear more about and to see completed. The Gold Coast University Hospital project and the Gold Coast Rapid Transit project are two projects that will transform the Gold Coast. Both are key election commitments of the state Labor government. Construction works and early works that can be seen underway now demonstrate this government’s commitment to investing in the Gold Coast as well as delivering key infrastructure projects that create jobs and stimulate our economy.

XML.Hansard-Body: Recently I attended a briefing on the progress of the rapid transit project that included a bus tour of the early works. A number of key stakeholders also attended, including business industry representatives, Griffith University staff and local councillors. The bus tour and briefing took us to where stage 1 of the light rail system begins its journey--the most northerly point of Parklands Drive. It is here at the rapid transit’s Gold Coast University Hospital station shell construction that the size of these two major projects can be seen and the future of the health and knowledge precinct can be visualised. This precinct will become one of the largest transit oriented developments on the Gold Coast and provide a major public transport interchange linking the highly populated northern Gold Coast to the key activity centres of Southport, Surfers Paradise and Broadbeach.

There are two light rail stations planned for this precinct--the Gold Coast University Hospital station and the Griffith University station. Construction of the Griffith University station is currently underway and near completion. This work has been called the station shell as it includes the roof, floor and walls that will support the future station structure. I was pleased to learn that 80 per cent of contractors working on this site are locally based and the project has spent almost $18 million in the local community sourcing labour and materials. This work is being done now so as to be completed in conjunction with the opening of the Gold Coast University Hospital, therefore creating no impact or disruption to the operators of the new hospital and its patients and visitors.

The Gold Coast University Hospital will offer all services currently offered at the existing hospital site plus new and expanded services that will greatly reduce the number of Gold Coast patients required to travel to Brisbane for treatment. New services that will be offered include cancer radiotherapy, neonatal intensive care, trauma response and a full suite of public cardiology and cardiac services for the people of the Gold Coast. The emergency department will be significantly expanded. There will be additional delivery suites, birth centre rooms and a special-care nursery. There will be extended mental health services and the number of operating theatres will increase from nine to 16, with the capacity for more. Support services such as intensive care, pharmacy, radiology and pathology will also be expanded. The hospital will be ideally located with the private hospital and specialist suites on-site and adjacent to Griffith University. Not only will the precinct provide future generations of doctors, nurses and allied health staff with the opportunity to learn their speciality in a hands-on, state-of-the-art facility; it will also attract graduates and experienced staff to work, teach and undertake research on the Gold Coast.

It is a fact that this Bligh government’s funded $1.76 billion Gold Coast University Hospital will grow to become a nationally and internationally recognised centre for innovative medical research and health care. As this government is delivering on our promises, the opposition is being led by a candidate who is not a member of parliament and by an interim leader in the House. It is being led by an interim leader who is flip-flopping on announcements and scrapping policy that it had--and given the length of time that it has been here, it has not developed much! These projects that I have spoken about are yet another example of the Bligh government working for Queensland, planning and investing for our future. The Bligh government is getting on with the job.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! The time for matters of public interest has expired.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 22 March (see p. 644), on motion of Mr Fraser--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (Deputy Leader of the Opposition) (12.33 pm): This bill is titled the Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and is a peculiar mix of unrelated provisions--a bit of this, a bit of that with a little bit of the other--and very little consistency or rationale between the grouping of all of these pieces of legislation in one bill. There are some provisions that are concerned with housekeeping and updating the legislation, a couple of repeals of outdated legislation or legislation that has passed its use-by date and a number of other amendments that will have impacts on a diverse range of areas from family trusts through to water supply and--would you believe it?--iconic places. There are some 16 acts amended in this bill and a further 11 acts are being repealed. A quick look at the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert that was released at 10.30 this morning will give anyone who is interested in this legislation an indication of all of the changes that are being made. I should also point out that the opposition was afforded a briefing on the bill this morning at 8.15. In fact, some aspects of that briefing are still being conducted as we speak, particularly in relation to some of the areas regarding water use, some of the areas regarding national parks in Cape York in your part of the world, Mr Deputy Speaker O’Brien, and some other areas. Therefore, we in the opposition are still resolving a number of issues and seeking answers to a number of questions from this morning. My intention is to deal predominantly with the revenue areas, although I will touch on a couple of other areas as well, and indicate that other speakers on this side of the House will be addressing certain issues.

As the bill deals with revenue, I thought it would be interesting to actually reflect on the state of the state’s revenue. It is truly the case that this is the biggest taxing, biggest spending government in this state’s history, and in terms of being the biggest taxing government in this state’s history it seems to be proud of it. Revenue is going up to almost $42 billion this year, revised up in the midyear fiscal and economic review. But revenue going up is not alone. It is not Robinson Crusoe, because not only is revenue increasing but expenses are also increasing, up by over a billion dollars to $43.3 billion, resulting in, under the hands of this long-term Labor government, a deficit of $1.5 billion--another operating loss from the government that lost the AAA credit rating, a government that imposed a fuel tax on motorists throughout Queensland, a government that increased registration charges between 17 per cent and 23 per cent, a government that increased tolls on toll roads by 33 per cent before attempting to sell off the toll roads and a sale that it said it would not undertake.
Government members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! I would now ask the honourable member to return to the provisions of the bill before the House.
Mr NICHOLLS: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I guess when one talks about--
Government members interjected.
Mr Horan interjected.
