Mr NICHOLLS: I hear the cattle mewing up the back there, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: It is hard to give you the protection of the chair if it is your own members interjecting on you as well. Order! The House will come to order!
Mr NICHOLLS: They continue to speak with the sounds of cattle as they contentedly chew their cuds up in the back there and worry about what is being said down the front here.
Mr Lawlor interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: The sheep are up there and they are looking to be shorn, and I hear the member for Southport. It was an interesting question he asked this morning. I thought, ‘What a pity! If you were only still in cabinet, you would have known the answer to that.’ But that was not to be the case, was it? What a pity!
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! For the second time I will ask the honourable member to return to the provisions of the bill currently before the House.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr NICHOLLS: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As we were saying--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: And I do not need advice from the member for Callide.
Mr Seeney: But he is allowed to respond.
Mr NICHOLLS: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Talking about--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order, member for Callide! I do not need your advice. Please do not offer it.

Mr NICHOLLS: Because we are debating the Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, I thought it would be appropriate to talk about the revenue. We are dealing with the Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, so let us talk about the revenue, which is going up, as I said, to $42 billion this year--boosting up year after year as the biggest taxing government this state has ever seen continues its rapacious reach into the pockets of the taxpayers of Queensland, whether it be through land tax, another issue that is being dealt with in this bill, or transfer duty, another issue that is being dealt with in this bill. Revenue is being continually seized by this government as it tries vainly to balance the books.

How much is that revenue going to be this year? This year, payroll tax will be almost $3 billion. Transfer duty is down a little bit this year because of the restrained business conditions brought about by the government’s ineptitude and its mismanagement of the economy. Transfer duty is down by $300 million--down to $1.9 billion. But land tax is still going very nicely--‘Thank you very much,’ says Mr Fraser--at $1.052 billion. Motor vehicle registration duty is increasing to $1.3 billion this year. So when we are looking at a revenue bill that deals with those aspects of revenue, I think it is important that we put it in the context of this large-taxing, large-spending government--this government that lost the AAA credit rating before the global financial crisis and before the cyclones, storms and floods that hit our state. This is a revenue grab of the like not seen in Queensland’s history, a revenue grab by a government that cannot control its expenditure--unlike a government that will be led by Campbell Newman that will save money and deliver more by getting action on the basics and cutting waste.

The bill repeals 11 acts. It repeals some redundant legislation and legislation that has not been effectively used for some considerable time now. The Debits Tax Repeal Act 2005 is repealed, it having achieved its purpose. It is one of the acts that was put in place following the introduction of the new tax system--the GST--that has delivered so much for the states and delivered so much for Australia. It was effectively a review and a revision of the tax system brought in by the Liberal-National coalition at the federal level--and opposed every step of the way, of course, by the Labor Party at that stage. That act is no longer required as all outstanding debits tax matters are being wound up and there are no more matters to be dealt with under that particular piece of legislation.

Similarly, the Tobacco Products (Licensing) Act is also repealed. That act provided for the collection of licence fees from tobacco wholesalers. I mentioned before about revenue being gathered as a result of the repeal of the fuel subsidy by this government after the last election. Of course, that subsidy was brought about because of legislation like the Tobacco Products (Licensing) Act. The case of Ha v State of New South Wales found that the recovery of those types of licence fees was, in fact, unconstitutional. As a result, governments had to change their position. So tobacco licensing fees could not be collected from wholesalers in a similar way that petroleum licence fees could not be collected. So under the National-Liberal coalition at the time a scheme was put in place, with the concurrence of the federal coalition at that stage, to make sure that motorists were remitted to them through the petrol pump eight and a bit cents per litre so that they were not going to have a tax on them. Of course, that situation has now changed under this government, which is now imposing a new fuel tax. But this is the type of legislation that led to that particular change occurring.

A number of bank acts are repealed: the Advance Bank Integration Act, the Bank Integration (Bank of Queensland) Act and a number of others, including the Bank of South Australia Act, the Bank of New Zealand Act and the Challenge Bank Act. Special legislation was required to bring all of those acts together when those banks were merged during the 1990s when bank consolidation was occurring. Those acts have achieved their purpose and are now no longer required. They all had 20-year sunset clauses in them. We are repealing them sooner than the 20 years that was required.

The Iconic Queensland Places Act 2008 is being rolled into the Sustainable Planning Act following a 2010 review. We all remember the lengthy debates that were held in this place when forced council amalgamations occurred against the will of many of those councils involved and really in direct contradiction of promises that were given about the Size, Shape and Sustainability process that had been implemented previously. It was a breach of trust and a breach of faith with the people of Queensland by the then Beattie government. A number of places were identified as being iconic. Noosa was one of those. The amalgamation was going to particularly affect the view of the people of Noosa in terms of their particular little piece of paradise that they occupy for which they are responsible, which is quite different from the rest of the Sunshine Coast and is regarded by many people, both north and south of the divide of the old Noosa shire council, as being an iconic part of the Sunshine Coast. This legislation was a sop that was provided to try to, I guess, buy off those local concerned residents. Of course, as we know, it has failed and it is now being shown to be the complete waste of time, energy and effort that it always was. Not surprisingly, the 2010 review said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the iconic place development assessment panels were found to not be the most effective mechanism for the protection of iconic values.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is not surprising, because in the debate of the original bill in 2008 we on this side of the House warned about that. In that debate we said that we would continue to maintain the right to scrutinise how these panels operate. We said that the solution was just a watered-down version of the respective councils, which the amalgamations destroyed in the first place. They were weak and ineffectual, which is not surprising from a government that was so badly out of touch with its constituents that it took the stance of ignoring the wishes of communities that were just trying to protect their way of life.

The original assessment panel that was outlined in that legislation was nothing more than a Clayton’s council--the council you have when you cannot vote for your own. That is what the panels suggested by the iconic places legislation were--a reduced council, not elected by the people and for the people, but appointed by the minister and subject to all the vagaries of a political appointment process. The legislation was not designed to help local communities. It was only meant to provide a political solution. Again, this legislation is a clear example of a long-term Labor government that is more concerned about protecting its political reputation than it is about governing for Queenslanders. So we will be supporting the removal of the iconic places legislation. It should never have been put in place in the first place. It was a bad piece of legislation put forward by an out-of-touch government.

The New Tax System Price Exploitation Code (Queensland) Act is being repealed. It was a transitional provision that was put in place as part of the move to the goods and services tax. That role was taken over by the ACCC and has not been in place and necessary since 2002. So that legislation is no longer necessary.

I turn now to the amendments to the Duties Act, which deal with a number of legislative changes to bring various parts of the duties legislation regime into line with that of other states to clean up any anomalies that have been found to be in the legislation either through court cases or investigation by the Commissioner of State Revenue and through other areas. So there are some changes in relation to the vesting of a principal place of residence. So rather than just a straight transfer of property, where a court orders property to vest in one party, that process would normally be subject to transfer duty. This legislation provides an exemption from transfer duty on land pursuant to that vesting order. That is an issue that was not foreseen in the original legislation but there have been sufficient examples of that occurring to warrant the change to make sure that no extra duty is payable in circumstances where there is a vesting, for example in a Family Court order being made.

There is a provision for special disability trusts. I think that is an issue that is much more relevant to people these days as we look at a national disability insurance scheme and the ongoing problem of an ageing population, particularly in relation to ageing parents with disabled children and how provision is made to look after them in the future. There is now a provision for special disability trusts and there are certain tax concessions so that property transferred into a special disability trust will be exempt from duty, which I must say is a very good thing. The worry and concern that many people have about how they are going to deal with people who have a disability of some sort is enormous and, as I am sure many members will know, has to be seen to be believed. So being able to reduce some of the burden so that special disability trusts can be put in place so that property, particularly a house, can be vested in them to provide for people with disabilities in the future, I think, is a very worthwhile amendment and a change to the duties legislation.

The transaction that creates the trust for the acquisition of an eligible home that will be the principal place of residence for a person with a disability will be exempted from that duty. It defines an eligible home as a place that will be used or is used as the principal place of residence for the beneficiary of the trust. And there is no restriction on the co-occupation of the property by other people, so family who are necessary to help look after the person with a disability can live there and not lose the benefit of the exemption to it.

The other provision in relation to duties is in relation to the transfer of modified vehicles for people with a disability. Transfer duty is paid on the value of the vehicle. When vehicles are modified to provide that they are able to be driven by people with disabilities it increases the value and the transfer duty would normally be payable on that increased value. Under an administrative arrangement that has been in place for some time now, that extra duty has not been paid. This brings the law into line with those administrative arrangements and just charges the duty on the value of the vehicle prior to modifications so that people are paying the same duty as those of us who do not require a special modification.

There are some changes to duty on Indigenous land use transfers. When an ILUA--an Indigenous land use agreement--is made and it transfers land back to Indigenous people there will be some exemptions from duty if it is used for residential or community purposes. That is put in place with some conditions about satisfying the Commissioner of State Revenue about some of those changes.

There are provisions that deal with the transport legislation to provide for some nominal condition for vehicles that only use the roads for a limited purpose. If a person has a farm vehicle that only needs to go on the road to move from one paddock to another or an industrial vehicle that only needs to move from one work site to another, there is a provision in the legislation for a $25 nominal duty to be paid. We would certainly support that. That change is brought about by the expiry of the Transport Operations (Road Use Management--Vehicle Registration) Regulation and its replacement in 2010.

There are some changes in relation to the provisions of cancelled transfers and cancelled contracts. What happens quite often, particularly with off-the-plan sales, is that a unit is bought by someone who holds it during the course of construction and then that person enters into a subsequent contract to sell it, taking a profit in the middle--flicking, if you like, the interest on. Those people often can make a profit and one of the ways to deal with some of the things that occur, particularly the instance of duty, is that contracts are cancelled and replaced with new contracts. This provision provides that where that sort of thing occurs between related persons there is a dutiable instrument that can be appropriately charged when those transfers are cancelled. That ensures that the revenue is protected on the way through. We do not mind people making a profit provided they pay the appropriate duty that everyone else is obliged to pay.

There are some provisions in relation to change of trustee duties which bring the surrender of an interest under a trust into the provisions of the duties regime in the same way that the acquisitions of interest are. That is just bringing it in for consistency and again is a revenue partition matter. There are some other changes in relation to partitions of property and also some changes in relation to punitive measures for self-assessors. These days most stamp or transfer duty is assessed by lawyers or accountants in their offices. They do most of it in their office without having to go through the inestimable pleasure of traipsing down to the stamps office which used to be the case. One would have to take a cheque and pay it down there. One can do it in the office now and transfer it through. There are some minor mistakes and errors that sometimes occur. It is not necessary to prosecute people in those instances but simply to hit them up with a fine to remind them of their obligations and to make sure that they do go about doing their assessments in the right fashion and in the right manner. That just widens the power of the commission to act administratively rather than go through the court system.

There are some changes to family trust concessions to remove the commissioner’s discretion and to set out in black and white those instances when a concession is allowed and those instances when a concession is not allowed. It removes it from the discretion of the commissioner. There is an longstanding principle, if I remember my old tax law days, that it would be better to have all the rules in relation to exemptions and commissioners’ discretions removed and have it clearly set out in black and white so that people can understand exactly what it is and order their affairs appropriately. I think this is a step down that path to make sure that the rules are clear and clearly understood.

There are still some outstanding issues in relation to some aspects of trusts, particularly testamentary trusts--transfers of interest in trusts under wills where there are some unintended consequences that in a certain light could look like a death duty on a transfer. I know that some of these matters have been referred to the Treasurer’s office. I think those matters still need to be resolved satisfactorily. I understand that there is still some work being done by the commissioner’s office in relation to resolving those issues. There are not many of them, but I think the intention is there not to tax transfers of interest in trusts under testamentary dispositions. I think that still needs to be dealt with.

There are some changes to the First Home Owner Grant Act to extend the provisions for clawback in case someone does not fulfil the conditions for the first home owner grant and extend those for consistency with the existing provisions of the revenue legislation for recovery of concessions that have been allowed. So if someone does not fulfil their conditions the commissioner has up to five years to recover the appropriate amount of duty.

There have been some changes to the Land Tax Act which are beneficial to taxpayers in relation to timing, particularly when there have been reassessments. There has been a change to the Queensland Competition Authority Act--that old friend of the Treasurer’s and mine that we often talk about in dulcet tones. I think administrative orders are being put in place to allow more than just the Treasurer or the Premier to give directions to the QCA. I see the Treasurer nodding willingly as he parcels that one off to the Minister for Finance--to allow the Minister for Finance to give some instruction and direction to the Queensland Competition Authority--and I am sure that the Premier will be equally excited at the ability to move that off to someone else to allow those administrative arrangements.

There are substantial changes to the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act. I am sure that the member for Callide will be having something to say about those arrangements. It is no secret that the LNP opposition thinks the arrangements put in place for South-East Queensland water restructuring were a complete dog’s breakfast. We said at the time that there were going to be increases in costs. We said that it was going to cost water consumers more. In fact, the head of the Queensland Water Commission said that prices would be going up by 147 per cent. They have been going up and they continue to go up, and this government seems to remain powerless to resolve it.

The government has announced some changes to the structure of the bulk water supply authorities. That is what this piece of legislation is. It is about establishing a capacity to introduce a regulation to transfer assets from the various bulk water suppliers. So WaterSecure, which is the subject of this particular action or activity, will be merged and its assets will transfer to South East Queensland Water--Seqwater--for operation. That was announced by the government in late 2010.

What is interesting is that during the briefing we received this morning the amount of savings was unable to be identified. One question that I would ask the Treasurer is: what are the savings expected to be as a result of the merger of these two entities? It is not so much about what impact that would have on the price down at the consumer end but more about what the actual saving would be because, presumably, it is getting rid of rented premises or occupation costs, fixed overheads, the board of directors and a number of other people. So what are the actual savings that will materialise as a result of moving WaterSecure into Seqwater?

Then, what are the additional obligations that are being picked up by Seqwater? WaterSecure operates the Tugun desalination plant. So what happens to the rights and responsibilities and the liabilities and warranties particularly in relation to the Tugun desalination plant and the obligations if there are things that need to be fixed as a result? Where do those obligations fall and who is responsible for them?

The other interesting thing is in relation to the protection of employees of WaterSecure. Those under certified agreements will be given protection from redundancies for three years; those under common law agreements will not. It is certainly easy to see the government’s ideology in that respect--that is, there is no interest in looking after all employees, only employees under certified agreements no doubt negotiated with their mates in the union. Those who choose to exercise their own decision-making process and enter common law contracts will be the ones for the chop under a rationalisation.

The bill will facilitate the merger of WaterSecure with Seqwater by 1 July 2011. We would like to see the costs of that as well as the savings. Future changes will also include Wyaralong Dam, the Northern Pipeline Interconnector stage 2 along with the western corridor assets.
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.

Hansard-Body.A: Before lunch I was speaking about the expenditure of this government and how dreadful it was in terms of the $42 billion in revenue it is receiving while expenses are increasing to $43.3 billion. I highlighted how much has been raised through increased taxes and charges. I spoke about the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act. I indicated that the water restructuring program eventually put in place by this government was a farce that led to increases in water charges for South-East Queensland consumers and I spoke of the obvious dissatisfaction and unhappiness that is displayed by everyone who gets a water bill these days. I spoke about how the proposal to amend the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act to provide for the amalgamation of WaterSecure and Seqwater was an acknowledgement by the government that it had got it so spectacularly wrong when it put it in place three years ago.

XML.Hansard-Body: The bill will incorporate transitional provisions for the proposed merger of Seqwater and WaterSecure, including a statutory exemption from transfer duties. Thank goodness for that. At least the poor old consumer will not have to pay again for the mistakes of this long-term Labor government. I covered the certified agreement for employees and the difference in the way that certified agreement employees will be treated as opposed to those employed under common law contracts.

The legislation will also allow for the dissolution of WaterSecure upon the completion of the transfer of its assets, liabilities and employees to Seqwater. Interestingly, it will remove the existing restriction on the number of directors who may be appointed to that board, which is currently limited to five. One has to wonder what justification there would be for appointing extra directors to manage the assets. Certainly it has been said that, because there will be more complex assets to be managed, there will be a need for more expertise in relation to the assets that are being transferred. Currently Seqwater deals with dams, and the merger with WaterSecure will mean that it will also deal with processed water plants, particularly the Tugun desalination plant. One would hope that the board will not double in size because of that. I presume the board will be absorbed into the running of Seqwater and that the controls over the cost of that area will be dealt with.

The bill deals with the urban water arrangements for areas outside South-East Queensland. Currently, those urban water arrangements are being reviewed by the Department of Environment and Resource Management. Some of the obligations on councils outside the South-East Queensland corner will be lifted in relation to their water management plans, whether it is a leakage management plan to control leakage or an outside water use plan for parks and gardens. Circumstances have changed. Obviously we are not in the position that we were in three years ago when Queensland was facing a water supply crisis because of the inability of this long-term Labor government to actually manage water supplies effectively, which meant that all of those water restrictions had to be put in place.
Government members interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: The truth hurts them. They squeal when they get pricked by having the truth revealed to them. The reality is that if this long-term Labor government had better managed the water supply and built and planned for the future, instead of living for the moment as it always does, if it had worked for Queenslanders instead of working for itself, we would not have had nearly the number of water problems that South-East Queensland suffered from 2005 to 2007. However, now that the rains have fallen, the dams are full and the water security situation is so different, the government is removing some of the more draconian regulations that it was forced to put in place because of its earlier failures. I am sure that the member for Callide will have something to say about some of those issues.

Other changes proposed by the legislation relate to a simplification of the payroll tax regime. This year, payroll tax will collect almost $3 billion. It is one of the major sources of income for the state. There are some requirements to bring it into harmony with provisions occurring in the rest of Australia. We are happy to see those provisions made, to clarify and simplify some of the exemptions. The bill also deals with some fringe benefit issues and how they are to be treated for the purposes of calculating payroll tax. It brings Queensland into line with the rest of Australia. The bill also deals with some of the grouping provisions and some of the more complex arrangements that occur over time and that impact on thresholds for the payment of payroll tax.

The bill amends the Aboriginal Land Act to deal with areas of national parks on the Cape York Peninsula. Other members on this side will address those issues, including the transfer of land and the provision of arrangements to allow for Aboriginal management to take place in some of those national parks. In the briefing this morning I asked some questions about how that would occur--whether there had been arrangements or agreements entered into with local Indigenous groups and whether funding had been provided to enable appropriate management plans to be put in place and to enable them to carry out activities that will be required under those agreements. Just after the lunch break I received advice from the ministerial officers that appropriate arrangements would be put in place and that agreements had been put in place. As I said, other members on this side will address that particular issue.

The bill seeks to make some changes to the Water Act in terms of the regulatory requirements for statutory authorities to obtain licences to take water from watercourses as part of the reconstruction and rebuilding process. Other members will comment on those issues and the activities that are underway.

The bill proposes changes to the legislation for the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association to deal with its status as a charitable institution and to provide it with certain benefits. One of the problems is that currently the legislation allows for it to be wound up by resolution of the members and to distribute what is left over to the members, which is contrary to the normal arrangements for incorporated associations. Normally, incorporated associations have to provide that, on a winding-up, their assets are transferred to an organisation with similar objects and purposes. The bill deals with that issue, however long may the RNA continue in operation.

The bill makes some changes to the Local Government and City of Brisbane acts. One of those changes will bring together the local government superannuation scheme and the scheme administered by the City of Brisbane for its employees, City Super. Although I do not have confirmation of this, I understand that the employees covered by both superannuation schemes have voted to approve the merger of the two schemes and that there are no objections from the members to the merger of those two entities. That follows some changes and recommendations made in the federal review of superannuation. Members will remember that last year that report was released and it dealt with that.

The bill proposes changes to boundaries. Other members on this side will deal with those issues, as well as definitions for appropriate conduct for councillors. That change corrects a drafting error from the original legislation, where ‘inappropriate conduct’ was defined in one section but was not covered in another section.

Hansard-Body.A: (Callide--LNP) (Leader of the Opposition) (2.38 pm): I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to the Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. As the shadow Treasurer and member for Clayfield has indicated, this bill encompasses a wide range of issues across the broad range of acts that it seeks to amend. I intend to restrict my comments to a couple of those areas, chief amongst which is the amendments that the bill makes to the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act 2007. As the member for Clayfield indicated, the fact that this proposed amendment is in this bill today is a recognition of the great failure of this government with regard to water reform in South-East Queensland.

XML.Hansard-Body: I have said in this parliament many times before that one of the great legacies of this Labor government will be the water supply system that it has inflicted upon people in South-East Queensland, a water supply system that will result in people living in South-East Queensland being saddled with the financial burden for generations to come that is a direct result of the failure, the mismanagement and the short-sightedness of this Labor government that for 12 years now has sat on the government benches. One of its great legacies will be the water bills that every Queenslander will receive for generations to come. There is very little that can be done to correct that. This particular bill seeks to make what is a supportable change--a change that we will support--but it is a very small change. It is a very small manipulation, a very small recognition, that the whole system that the government put in place has become a financial burden for the people of South-East Queensland.
It is interesting to see what is in the explanatory notes that accompany the bill. One of the paragraphs states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In September 2007, the Queensland Government approved a range of institutional reforms to be implemented across the South East Queensland (SEQ) urban water sector. These reforms addressed a number of critical shortfalls in the urban water supply arrangements, and coincided with the establishment of the SEQ Water Grid.
XML.Hansard-Body: I think that the term ‘the water grid’ is a term that will live in infamy and will become one of the notable legacies of this Labor government. The water grid was a political construct. It was a concept that was built in the mind of the former Premier, Premier Beattie, and in the mind of the ministers responsible at the time. It was a concept that was built to address a political problem. It was a concept that was built to defend the government against the quite justified attacks that it was experiencing from water users in South-East Queensland about the way it had failed to meet its responsibility to provide the required water infrastructure to ensure a reliable and economic source of water for domestic and industrial use in South-East Queensland.

We had a water crisis in 2006 and 2007 and these reforms were put in place in September 2007. Just three years later, we are here again in this parliament changing those institutional reforms, seeking to wind back some of the reforms that were put in place. As I said, those reforms were all about politics. They were all about creating the perception in the public’s mind that somehow or other this mythical creature called ‘a water grid’ was going to solve the problems that had become so apparent because of the years of government mismanagement. Of course it did not.

What it did was load the water supply system with a capital cost that will mean that water bills in South-East Queensland will be horrendously high for generations to come. That capital cost is built into the water supply infrastructure that is there now. It is very difficult to put an accurate figure on it. The most accurate figure is the one that I heard one of the mayors from South-East Queensland using a couple of days ago when he said that there are $4 billion worth of assets that water users of South-East Queensland are paying interest and redemption on that are contributing nothing to the water supply in South-East Queensland. There is $4 billion worth of assets that the water users are paying for that are contributing nothing. That figure clearly illustrates the extent to which the whole management of the water supply system in South-East Queensland will become one of the more infamous legacies of this government when it is dispatched to political history, as it so richly deserves.

The bill before the House seeks to combine two of the entities that were set up as part of that reform process. It was a reform process that had flow charts and diagrams. It looked something like a snakes and ladders game, trying to determine who was responsible for what. It was typical Labor bureaucracy: set up a complicated bureaucracy, give a whole lot of people jobs, put in place a convoluted and complex process and produce very little. That is what Labor governments do. That is what Labor governments have done for the last hundred years: set up those sorts of complicated bureaucracies to cover its own failures and subsequently ensure that the people who depend on those services end up paying more for the services.

That is what this bill seeks to correct. It seeks to play around the edges, if you like, of that problem that was created. It seeks to allow for the proposed merger of the Queensland Manufactured Water Authority, or WaterSecure--one of those entities that was set up--and the Queensland Bulk Water Supply Authority, or Seqwater, which the government announced in late 2010. It is something that is certainly a small step in the right direction, but it does not make a significant impact on that huge capital cost structure that I spoke about earlier and that water users in South-East Queensland will come to recognise as one of the main contributors to those horrendous water bills that they will receive for many years to come.

One of the great indicators, if you like, of how that cost structure contributes to those water bills--and it is only one of half a dozen examples that I could pick--was the executive salaries that were paid to the boards and the CEOs of these water entities that this bill seeks now to amalgamate. There was quite understandable public outrage when this matter received a deal of public attention earlier last year because some of the salaries that were involved were extraordinary, to say the least. We could take a few minutes to go through some of them as an example of just how this whole bloated bureaucracy that was put in place by the Labor government to solve its political problem has become a financial impost on water consumers in South-East Queensland.

The Queensland Water Commission, that great entity that many of us in this place have described over the years as a political shield for the Beattie Labor government--and that is what it was at the time--was an initiative to distance the government from its responsibilities. The Queensland Water Commission had five executives that were paid a total of $1.12 million in 2010, with one executive receiving over $300,000 in remuneration. It pays contractors and consultants another $5.6 million. All of that cost comes from the water bills that the people in suburban Brisbane and South-East Queensland pay.

The SEQ Water Grid Manager had a total remuneration for three of its top executives of $929,000. The top executive in that bunch of three was paid $440,000 a year to manage the water grid. The board and committee remuneration for the water grid manager for that year was $246,500 with another $1.58 million paid in consultancies.

They are the sorts of costs that are impacting on the water bills of everybody in South-East Queensland. Seqwater, the organisation that will carry on from the amalgamation that is proposed in this legislation, has examples in a similar vein. The total remuneration for five of its executives was $1.42 million a year with the top executive remuneration being $480,000 per year. The board remuneration for salary, fees and super was $335,000 for the year. These are incredible salaries for what should be the delivery of an essential service.

WaterSecure, the entity that this bill seeks to amalgamate with Seqwater, has a total remuneration for six of its executives of $1.7 million, with the top executive remuneration being $520,000 per annum--$520,000 per annum for an executive of an organisation that this bill seeks to amalgamate with Seqwater. You have to wonder about the government, about the ministers, who allowed that sort of organisation to be set up three years ago. You have to wonder about the administrative skills of people who set up an organisation and pay somebody $520,000 to be its CEO and who three years later understand that it can be wound up--amalgamated with an organisation that already exists. What an absurdity! What a great indication of the administration skills of this Labor government. What a great indication of how this Labor government has failed. What a great indication of what Labor governments always do. They have done it for the last 100 years and, given the chance, they would do it for the next 100 years. That is what Labor governments are about: bloated bureaucracies, overpaid jobs for Labor mates and increased water bills for the people of South-East Queensland.

I have said it before in this place and I say it again: when the Premier gets around to finally calling an election, the people of South-East Queensland should take their water bills to the ballot box. They should take their water bills with them on polling day. They will never have a better how-to-vote card than the water bills they get in the mail, because the water bills that South-East Queenslanders get in the mail will be forever-telling evidence of the administrative skills and the capacity, or lack thereof, of the members who sit on the government benches and who deserve to be removed simply for this issue if for no other--no other than a half a dozen other examples that I could give.

While we will support the amendment contained in the bill, the people of Queensland generally should always remember that it is but a small step towards rectifying the problem that the Labor government created. It is an admission--clear and simple, loud and plain--that the water grid and the water reform process that was put in place were flawed and have failed. Nobody knows that more than the people who pay their water bills in South-East Queensland.

I will move on to a couple of other parts of the bill that I believe are pertinent and worthy of some comment--that is, the amendments to the Local Government Act. The member for Clayfield, the shadow Treasurer, spoke about the amendments to the Local Government Act and the extent to which the local government amalgamation has been a failure and has created angst and concern right across Queensland. In the communities that I represent, I do not think there is another issue that has impacted so hard and for so long as the issue of the amalgamation of local governments. It is an issue that this Labor government and a lot of its ministers simply do not understand. They simply do not understand the impact that that amalgamation process had on the small communities I represent.

My electorate has some 22 small communities. In the case of North Burnett Regional Council, six shires were amalgamated into one. In the case of the Banana Shire Council, old shires were cut in half and tacked on one way or the other. In the case of the South Burnett Regional Council, five shires were amalgamated into one. The effect that has had on those communities is difficult to quantify. It has in many cases torn the heart and soul out of small communities. It has torn apart the fabric that made those small communities what they were. It is in many instances, I believe, impossible to reverse. I say that with great regret. While it should never have been done, it is probably impossible to reverse. But there has to be some effort put into trying to make the system work better, trying to make what we have now work for the benefit of those communities, because it is not working for them at the moment.

The Treasurer now holds a position different from the one he held when this amalgamation process was passed through this House. His position in the government now, I would suggest, provides an opportunity for him to correct some of the problems, to right some of the wrongs that have been inflicted upon regional communities by this amalgamation process. It is blindingly obvious that those communities want something done. A whole range of issues need to be addressed.

Firstly, in relation to the boundary issue--which is the direct subject of this legislation--there are a number of places where the need for boundary adjustments is plainly obvious to anyone who wants to look at it. There are a number of obvious examples of the boundaries set at the time of amalgamation being completely and utterly unsuitable. A classic example in my electorate is the way that the old Taroom shire was cut in half. The old Taroom shire, which was a great shire--it was a good example of how a local council can reinforce the fabric of a community--was chopped in half. The town of Taroom was tacked onto the Banana Shire Council and the town of Wandoan was tacked onto the Dalby Regional Council. Those people have never recovered from it, and it is situations like that that need to be addressed. While we cannot go back and repair all of the damage that has been done by this process, we can address issues like that.

There are also, I believe, issues surrounding the empowerment of local councillors to properly represent their communities. I think the act and regulations have gone too far in restricting the ability of local councillors to properly represent their communities. I know that the member for Warrego, the shadow minister, will have more to say about that.

The other issue in this legislation relates to flood recovery. Parts of the Water Act will be amended to allow flood recovery works to proceed in a more timely way. That is certainly something that I would support. But I have to say that the whole issue of getting on with the job of flood recovery in relation to rural and regional roads is pitifully slow. There is frustration building right across regional Queensland with how red tape is choking and strangling local governments who are trying to get on with that flood recovery work, trying to return some of that road infrastructure to a more useable standard. It is difficult for people in large urban areas to understand the importance of road infrastructure to the industries and the people who live in regional areas. But that road infrastructure needs to be brought back to a standard that allows those industries to operate and that allows those people to get back to some sort of normal life. This part of the bill once again is only a very small step towards addressing those issues that are increasingly becoming a frustration for people right across my electorate. While we support the passage of this bill, it is an opportunity to highlight once again the failings of the Beattie-Bligh Labor government in so many areas.

Hansard-Body.A: (Warrego--LNP) (2.58 pm): I commend the member for Callide for the comments that he has made. They reflect the views of many Queenslanders. This legislation we are talking about today amends the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act 2007. When we consider the enormous cost and effort that was put into the water grid by the government, there was no thought put into it. No real cost-benefit analysis was done. Anybody with a bobcat or a wheelbarrow got a Mack truck rate when this job was done. If the job had been done with more due diligence we would have found the cost for the ratepayers of this state and the water users of this state would have been dramatically less. When we look at what is happening in terms of water prices in South-East Queensland we see enormous price rises, outrageous price rises. As the member for Callide said, the voters of this state should take a water bill to the ballot box. That is no better demonstration of what this government has done to the costs of living in this state. It is not just water costs but the rates that councils are now charging people because they have to--

XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Watt: Exactly.

Mr HOBBS: I will go into more detail about that later. I recall being in this House when then Premier Beattie got up and talked about the way the water boards in this state were run. He had a map that had lines running everywhere. He said how complicated it was. It is much more complicated now the way the ALP has put things together. The legislation before us today attempts to break it down again and make things a little simpler. But, at the end of the day, it is still going to cost. It is going to cost more and more because those opposite have lumbered the water users of South-East Queensland with the $9 billion water grid. I do not think the people of this state can have any comfort in this legislation reducing the cost of living. Nearly everything that has been done by this incompetent state government has cost people more. That is the case with electricity charges. When anything is reformed the costs go up.

This bill covers amendments to a lot of areas and I will just quickly touch on a few. It makes amendments to the RNA act--the Royal National Agricultural and Industrial Association of Queensland Act. What a great organisation that is. It has been operating since 1875--that is, 136 years--and has been providing great entertainment for the people of Queensland and the people of Australia. The restructure occurring at the site now will be of benefit and take us into the next century. It is a good site and a handy site and one that we should maintain. The bill makes an amendment so the RNA can maintain its Australian Taxation Office endorsement as an income tax exempt charitable institution. That is an amendment that is certainly welcomed.

I now want to refer to the amendments in the local government area. They are very important. This bill makes some amendments to the Local Government Act, particularly with regard to the Local Government Change Commission which was established under the legislation. The commission must consider whether a boundary change application is in the public interest and is consistent with local government related law. The commission is to conduct an assessment of the application in a way it considers appropriate. This legislation makes it a little simpler for the Local Government Change Commission to look at minor boundary change applications.

There have been many changes made in the past to local government boundaries in this state. I have been a councillor and a chairman in the past. Every council goes through these issues, sometimes with some agony and sometimes with some satisfaction. At the end of the day, some changes need to be made and some never get made because of a stand-off between people or councils or whatever the case may be. There needs to be a mechanism whereby sensible changes can be made. Common sense must prevail when it comes to these decisions.

As the member for Callide mentioned, as a result of forced amalgamations there are glaring examples where some changes need to be made. What happened with the amalgamation of councils was that the internal boundaries were pulled out and the 130-year-old external boundaries stayed the same. Not a lot changed but geographically it did not work in many instances. It was like a jigsaw puzzle that did not quite come together. There are some common-sense changes that need to be made.

The most important point when it comes to these minor matters is that it has to be in the public interest. If it is in the public interest that matters be resolved quickly and without going through a long, drawn-out process then that is sensible in so far as it will save time and money and reduce the bureaucracy. This government is famous for bureaucracy. This is one small step to help that situation.

There are some other issues that the Local Government Change Commission can deal with under the Local Government Act and the City of Brisbane Act. It can change the number of councillors in a council. This should have been done before. Smaller councils in terms of their revenue and population but not in terms of their geographical area have four councillors and a mayor. During the recent floods we saw situations where councillors could not get into their areas because of the flooding. They only have to have one councillor sick or somebody excluded due to the stupid conflict of interest laws that the government put in place and it means that the council simply cannot get a quorum. They have four councillors and a mayor and one or two of them are out--
Mr Reeves: Is that a policy?
Mr HOBBS: Yes, it is, as a matter of fact. Of course it is. We will change the situation to make it sensible and practical and workable rather than what you people put in place.
Mr Reeves interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order, Minister!

Mr HOBBS: There has to be common sense here. Some of those legislative changes need to be made. In fact, I believe your government is working towards that now so I would not be too smart on that side of the House.

At the end of the day, we have to make sure it is sensible. There was a recent recommendation of your own committee that councils with under 30,000 people should have six councillors. Guess what? It was rejected by this government. For what reason? Just because it did not want that happening. In reality, in many instances it is sensible to have that number of people on the council or at least to give the councils the option to have that number of people on the council. If they do not want six and instead want to keep four they can do that. If it is practical and sensible in those regions to have six, we should let them have six. You should have accepted the recommendations of the committee.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Warrego, please direct your comments through the chair.
Mr HOBBS: Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do not see any reason this government could not give councils more councillors.

I want to move on to the provisions in clauses 8, 9 and 10 related to correcting a minor drafting error in relation to notifying a councillor of a hearing of a complaint. The words ‘inappropriate conduct’ were inadvertently omitted from the previous act. That amendment needed to be made. That is an acceptable amendment to the legislation.

One thing I would like to raise is that we need to ensure that no past allegations are challenged under this legislation. I understand from the briefing that I had that this provision is not retrospective. At the end of the day, if past allegations can be resurrected due to this amendment then there needs to be caution exercised. When I refer to the local government changes I am referring to the changes to the City of Brisbane Act as well as the Local Government Act because they are similar.

The other aspect I want to talk about is the changes in relation to iconic places. This was one of those debacles that this government presided over with forced amalgamations. Communities like Noosa and the Douglas shire wanted to preserve the uniqueness of their areas.

The government did not think about this when the forced amalgamations were done, so it grabbed the Iconic Queensland Places Act 2008 out of the air and put it in place. That is one of those things that was better than nothing, but it meant nothing. In fact, after three years the review that took place found it to be not the most effective mechanism for the protection of iconic values. Surprise, surprise! The government added more bureaucracy, but at the end of the day the government should have left those councils alone to do their own thing. They did a great job and are still doing a great job, but this has made it much more difficult because the government has now lumped them all in together.

As the member for Callide said, around this state there are enormous concerns in relation to the forced amalgamation of councils. Up the coast and out west there is enormous dissent in relation to the way that local government is operating. And it is not the fault of the councillors; it is the fault of the legislative processes that have been put in place by this government without any thought, without any cost-benefit analysis and without any statement of the likely impacts on the ratepayer. Of course, the impacts on the ratepayer have been absolutely enormous across this state. Amalgamation cost nearly $200 million. The government reluctantly paid about $60 million but the ratepayers had to pick up the rest of the bill, and they are still suffering from that. I do not think this state has ever seen so many local governments operating deficit budgets, and that is thanks to you, Treasurer. We have lost our AAA credit rating and we now have the biggest debt Queensland has ever had. The councils under you are now probably in the worst debt--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Member for Warrego, please direct your comments through the chair.
Mr HOBBS: The councils in this state are now in the worst debt they have ever been, and it is getting worse.
Ms Croft: Which ones?

Mr HOBBS: Nearly all of them. Get the books out and have a look. If the member does not believe me, she should go and talk to them. They are having a great struggle, and many councils will tell you that. The change to the Iconic Queensland Places Act will still be in there--it is a bit of a sop--but at the end of the day it is important that we preserve the important parts of our state such as Noosa and Port Douglas. Places such as those have created a niche in the market and people from around the world want to be able to go there and see the special qualities of those places.
A government member interjected.
Mr HOBBS: They were able to do that before, and this legislation really has not got them a great deal.
A government member interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Minister, you are being repetitious.

Mr HOBBS: Mr Deputy Speaker, he is always repetitious. No-one takes any notice of him. The people of this state are sick to death of bureaucracy, they are sick to death of the cost-of-living increases and they are sick to death of this ALP government.

Hansard-Body.A: (Townsville--ALP) (3.13 pm): I am pleased to rise to make a contribution to the Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2011. The amendments proposed in this bill include a range of practical and important improvements across a number of portfolios. I will focus my comments on the amendments that will reduce red tape and that will assist our state in its recovery from the floods and cyclone devastation that we have seen in 2011.

XML.Hansard-Body: States and territories have worked to harmonise payroll tax arrangements, to reduce compliance costs and to improve certainty. Queensland’s payroll tax legislation was amended in 2008 to give effect to these arrangements. The Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2011 contains amendments to the Payroll Tax Act 1971 to continue to improve harmonisation across states and territories. These changes will: ensure that payroll tax is not payable on benefits exempt under the Commonwealth Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986; remove the requirement to group a company with another company as related corporations where one of the companies holds its interests in the other company on trust; ensure that, where two or more members of a group together have a controlling interest in a business, all of the members of the group and the persons who carry on the business together constitute a group; and amend the employee share scheme provisions of the Payroll Tax Act 1971 to reflect changes to Commonwealth employee share scheme legislation which had been referred to for payroll tax purposes.

In relation to the employee share scheme arrangements, state revenue commissioners have worked together to develop the principles for taxing shares and options issued by employers to employees. All jurisdictions will make legislative changes to give effect to the agreed approach, with legislation developed by New South Wales being used as the model legislation.

I also support the amendments in the bill to the Local Government Act which will strengthen the responsiveness of the Local Government Change Commission. Designed to improve the functioning and processing of relatively minor and non-controversial or non-contentious change applications, these amendments are consistent with the provisions of the Local Government Act 1993 which provided the commission with some of the similar flexibilities that are proposed in this amendment. I stress that the flexibility in this can only be used in cases of minor change applications where there is unlikely to be any arising public interest and where it would be a waste of the commission’s resources to go down a path of conducting public hearings and seeking submissions for applications that are quite clearly agreed to by the relevant and affected parties.

I turn to the amendments to the Water Act in relation to both reconstruction and urban water reform. The amendments to the Water Act 2000 are also being made in support of the government’s commitment to fast-tracking and streamlining the reconstruction of Queensland. The amendments will allow state agencies or local government authorities to take water for construction or maintenance of state infrastructure without the usual permits. Subsection 20(2)(a) of the Water Act provides for the taking of water in an emergency situation for a public purpose without a water entitlement. This provision was used during the recent flood and cyclone events to provide relief from the requirement to hold a water permit before taking water. As the emergency has now ended, subsection 20(2)(a) of the Water Act can no longer be used for the purposes of taking water during the reconstruction of our great state.

This proposed amendment will provide an authorisation for a constructing authority, including state government departments or local government authorities, to take water for the reconstruction of public assets such as our roads without the usual licence or permit. It is important to note that water can only be taken for the purposes prescribed and in accordance with the prescribed regulation. This will reduce the administrative burden on both the constructing authority and DERM by removing the requirement to make an application and assessment of same. In effect, this could improve current approval processes by numbers of months. This is not only reducing red tape but also reducing the time it will take, and that is critical as we reconstruct the state.

I want to make a couple of comments on the urban water reforms. This bill further amends the Water Act and the Water Supply (Safety and Reliability) Act with the aim of removing some planning and reporting requirements whilst still providing a legislative framework which continues to deliver safe and reliable water and sewerage services. I support that amendment.

Once again, the recurring theme in this ROLA Bill of 2011 is about getting smarter and more efficient practices that will get our state back on her feet and will still maintain the rigour required to maintain safety standards, quality of life, quality of services and our environment. This is all about reducing red tape and administration to support every possible avenue of fast-tracking the reconstruction of Queensland. This is on top of the $385 million of NDRRA advances that were announced a fortnight ago, which, I might add, did include $25 million in advances to the Townsville City Council so it can get on with the job instead of playing politics on issues of importance in our community. I support the amendments in this bill and commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Buderim--LNP) (3.18 pm): I rise to make a short contribution to the Revenue and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. In particular, I want to address the proposed amendments to the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act. It is no surprise that we need this amendment to this act. What a shambles! But are we getting the right amendments? In 2007 Labor decided that it could legislate to steal water assets from the ratepayers of South-East Queensland. It thought it had all of the answers, but all it did was create the most bloated and inefficient bureaucracy that we have ever seen in this state. There are 11 entities in South-East Queensland responsible for the supply, management and regulation of water. At the helm of those 11 entities we have 101 executives. I will speak more about that when I speak to the relevant amendments shortly. The explanatory notes for this bill state--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In late 2010, the Government announced a revised operating strategy for the manufactured water assets to reflect the substantial improvement in water security in SEQ.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is Laborspeak for ‘We got it wrong again’. It started to rain again and all the Gillard-Rudd-Wong-Garnaut disciples opposite had to stop talking about the drought. This bill enables a regulation to transfer assets, liability instruments and employees between certain state owned entities. Apparently, the regulation-making powers will provide a flexible and efficient means of transferring water security assets, liabilities, instruments and employees to Seqwater as part of the merger of the two authorities announced by the government in December 2010. When talking about water security, it is always amusing to read the word ‘efficient’ in any bill introduced by this Labor government. I note that the announcement occurred two weeks after I raised an issue when debating a water bill back in November. So we over here in the LNP are pleased to have provided the minister with guidance on this particular matter.
But I am not sure that the minister got the entire message back in November. The explanatory notes state further--and this is an absolute beauty--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The amendments will also lift the current five-member limit for water entity boards, allowing responsible Ministers to appoint additional directors to the post-merger Seqwater to reflect its added responsibilities and the expertise required.
XML.Hansard-Body: Let me say that again. These amendments give the government the ability to add more directors to those boards. The minister is right off the rails on this one. The idea is to get a few more snouts out of the trough and not allow more snouts into the trough. Yes, the Labor Party jobs-for-the-boys policy is alive and well in this bill. We know that the South East Queensland Water (Restructuring) Act established four new authorities to own and operate bulk water supply, transmission and production infrastructure in the region and to oversee the water grid. WaterSecure was established to own, operate and maintain the Gold Coast desalination plant and the western corridor recycled water scheme. That may have been the intention, but as we know the operation and management of the desalination plant and the western corridor membrane plants have been handed over to a French company called Veolia.
In November I asked the Premier a question on notice about the deal between WaterSecure, one of the companies subject to these amendments in the bill, and Veolia. The answer received back was--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Veolia Water Australia and its partners in the Gold Coast Desalination Alliance have ten years--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: yes, 10 years--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: remaining on their contract to operate and maintain the Tugun desalination plant on behalf of WaterSecure.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The Premier’s answer continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Veolia’s contract for the Western Corridor Recycled Water Scheme is a fifteen year term.
XML.Hansard-Body: Just so we get this absolutely straight, this bill provides the machinery to see this merger of Seqwater and WaterSecure, which I called for back in November of last year, and arising out of this merger this bill will provide for the responsible minister to appoint additional directors to the merged entities to reflect the added responsibilities and expertise required. That is pretty important. But we need to hang on just a moment. The Premier indicated in her answer to my question on notice that the responsibilities for which WaterSecure was created, namely operating and maintaining the desalination plant and the western corridor membrane plants, have been flick-passed to a private company called Veolia for 10 and 15 years respectively. So where are these perceived added responsibilities coming from? Again I ask the question: why the need for the extra directors? In relation to WaterSecure--one of these entities mentioned within this bill--the Premier’s answer to my question on notice continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The financial details of both contracts remain commercial in confidence.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is Laborspeak for ‘We’re paying too much and we don’t want the public to know anything about it’. In relation to WaterSecure the Premier’s answer to my question on notice continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: These competitive contracts provide flexibility to adjust to various operating scenarios across a range of production levels from zero to one hundred percent. These contracts deliver world-leading expertise from an internationally recognised water company and ensure that the plants are available to operate in line with SEQ Water Grid instructions at all times.
XML.Hansard-Body: That all sounds very impressive, but Veolia is on the job for at least the next decade and a half and we are not allowed to know how much that costs. Let us not forget that the desalination plant is in mothballs.
Through the amendments in this bill the following provision will be inserted into the act to apply to a transfer between WaterSecure and Seqwater made as part of the proposed merger--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Specific employment guarantees for WaterSecure employees transferred to Seqwater.
XML.Hansard-Body: Further, the new provision aims to minimise the administrative complexities and costs associated with transactions undertaken by regulation and to ensure a smooth transition of the business and the preservation of the status quo in terms of the application of instruments and employee entitlements. New section 112 of the act provides a three-year prohibition on the retrenchment of any employee covered by a certified agreement that is transferred from WaterSecure to Seqwater. Again, that all sounds wonderful--and I am all for preserving jobs in this state, as we all are on this side of the House--but this bill talks about streamlining and making things more efficient, which one would assume means cutting costs, including labour costs. So my final question is: what will the former employees of the now redundant WaterSecure be doing at Seqwater? I think that question really needs some looking into. We are amalgamating all of these people into this one entity and there sure are a lot them. Considering that this bill legislates that the labour costs will not decrease for at least three years and it further legislates that more directors can be appointed to do half the amount of work, how is this legislation going to in any way result in lower water costs for the consumers of Queensland?

I know that on the Sunshine Coast people’s water bills continue to rise. Every time they come out at roughly 25.88 per cent more. People are not very happy with that. I think they have pretty well had enough of it. I know that the shadow minister spoke earlier and also our leader--
Mr Shine: Which one?

Mr DICKSON: --relating to how-to-vote cards when people go to the next election. The next election is really what the member should be interested in, because I think there are going to be a lot of Queenslanders taking their bills along when they vote. Those bills will make great how-to-vote cards. This needs to happen sooner rather than later. We need to make water delivery authorities much more efficient and much more streamlined. All I can read out of this particular component of the bill is that the government is going to create more bureaucracy. We are going to have a whole lot of people sitting around playing canasta. At the end of the day, I do not think that the ratepayers are going to get any benefit from this bill.

We have to remember who amalgamated the water supplies in this state. It was not the councils, because I was there when it happened and I remember it extremely well. Henry Palaszczuk basically told us on the Sunshine Coast, ‘You’re not getting a water pipeline built to the Sunshine Coast. You’re crazy if you think that will ever happen. We won’t go through any green corridors.’ Guess what happened? They built a water pipeline to the coast. They forgot to put pumps in it so that they can pump water back to the coast. They just take away the water. The benefit that we on the Sunshine Coast have for this water restructure is that we pay more for water every single day of the week. The people are not happy. They are not going to cop it. But this situation is occurring right across South-East Queensland. Enough is enough. The people of Queensland are going to have a good old say at the next election. I look forward to that, because I will be handing out how-to-vote cards and I am sure they will be delivering water bills to the government in spades.

Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP) (3.27 pm): This bill is an omnibus bill that in part reflects the ongoing need for the state to continue to adapt our legislation to secure a continuous revenue stream from state taxes that have continued long after the introduction of GST and which relate to all manner of other things. The bill also amends the First Home Owner Grant Scheme. It also further entrenches Labor’s water as income as part of its so-called reform agenda in water restructuring. It again toys with local government, with an obsession about Labor’s new class enemies: local government and councillors.

This bill is really a complex document. It is so diverse that it is all but impossible to discuss all of it without leaving something out. If that is the case, is it just too difficult to be really of any use as a legislative tool? The taxation changes all seem relatively sensible and deserving of support. The obvious place to start would be the most serious issue confronting everyday Queenslanders today, and that is the serious ratcheting up of water prices from an uncaring government which feels that it now has the right to reform our use of carbon after it has reformed our supply of water.

This bill seeks to extend the powers of the chief executive regarding water rights, guaranteeing the work related rights of employees with relevant water entities, and new regulations regarding the construction of water infrastructure bodies to mirror what the government has in GOC parallels.

The major assumption of this bill is that water infrastructure will be massively improved by grouping all progressively under Seqwater without any further need to come back to parliament. This bill moves WaterSecure, the desal plant and the western corridor bypass into this existing bigger entity, Seqwater. In future, Wyaralong Dam and possibly others will also move. The overriding principle seems to be that this monopoly, wholly government owned entity is no different from a GOC and by default can be put at arm’s length from the scrutiny of parliament. It also then becomes captive to a voracious Labor government, desperate for cash, lurching for any critical life commodity, such as water, where the public can be held to ransom by an overarching single Seqwater monopoly.

The desal plant is only the dog it is now because Labor demanded a plant beyond its original design specifications and penny-pinched on everything from pipes to filters. Arguably, the contractors may remain cost plus on-site forever. Putting it into Seqwater is irrational. It should be gifted to the Gold Coast City Council and refashioned. Gold Coast Water should be able to manage it. No amount of moving entities with minor cancellation of small boards will make any difference to Labor’s failed water security plan. Under Labor, water equals money whereas it should equal public benefit. The terms ‘exploitation’ and ‘abuse of power’ seem appropriate here. Irrespective of Wyaralong Dam, the northern pipeline interconnector, the Tugun desalination plant, known as WaterSecure, and the western corridor being described as drought-proofing, it was all too late, too expensive, too bureaucratic and too much of a monopoly at the end.

The amendments to the Water Act 2000 are more of the same. The aim is to allow for streamlining of approvals for constructing authorities--that is, in flood recovery--to take water for construction and state infrastructure maintenance by exempting them from the need to obtain water licences and permits. These are practical considerations to some of the changes that authorise state agencies and/or local governments to take water for projects including for state infrastructure. It avoids the need to issue and reissue permits for water harvesting and will impose limits when water is short, as has been mentioned today a number of times.

The other water changes are minor and somewhat procedural. Curiously, there is an extension of time granted to water service providers outside South-East Queensland or local governments that had boundaries adjusted at the 2008 local government elections to prepare and submit system leakage plans to the regulator for approval. Leakage remains a big issue everywhere, both in micro form and in macro form. With the removal of the 40 per cent infrastructure subsidy, councils will invariably be delaying leakage repair strategies almost into the never-never because of the potential cost. At a time when water is so precious, it could be that an affordable strategy to repair tiring infrastructure is just too difficult and it is just easy to reduce the pressure in the pipes and repair them on an as-needs or emergency basis. This demand for plans without some budget seems short-sighted when seemingly it has been done in the name of water security.

That part of the bill relating to local government seems to raise a number of issues that are all largely left unexplained. The first is the merging of the LGsuper and City Super schemes. The justification is that Jeremy Cooper’s review broadly stated that the consolidation is in both funds’ interest. The proof of the pudding of course is in the eating. I hope City Super contributors in three to five years time--because that is the standard time they are assessed over--will agree it was the correct decision. I think the verdict will remain out until then.

The second change that seems to send all the wrong messages is that relating to the amendment to alter provisions regarding disciplinary action under the City of Brisbane Act. Whilst the change is relatively minor to correct a drafting error to allow the Brisbane City Council Councillor Conduct Review Panel administrative power to hear a complaint of what is deemed to be inappropriate conduct, this bill continues the enduring obsession of this present Labor government with criticism of councils and their councillors.

Councils represent the community interest of all of our local Queensland communities. This ridiculous approach of blaming councils for problems that by and large are due to the actions of an out-of-control, reckless Labor state administration is largely appalling. Today in the House we have heard outrageous statements about rate rises exceeding the cost of living by very marginal amounts, according to Premier Bligh. This from a government that has ruthlessly taken over council water assets, sold off electricity retailers and ratcheted up everything that goes with it, including Seqwater bulk water prices that I have discussed earlier that are outrageous! Councils have had their infrastructure grants severed and have had massive costs shifted back onto them from the state so that those ratepayers have had to carry those costs.

Councils and councillors are local champions of their communities and they are natural partners of government. They are not recognised under the federal Constitution and, as such, they deserve the support of all state governments which they serve. They do not deserve these ongoing, disgraceful, in-parliament offensive criticisms. I do not deny that, as my wife is a councillor for Surfers Paradise, I may have somewhat of a conflict, but I believe this deeply: local councillors find the current hostility directed at them as an electoral campaigning strategy by the state Labor Party totally unprofessional and desperate. I call on Labor to recant and apologise, especially to our Lord Mayor, Ron Clarke, who is routinely criticised in this House by all number of speakers, including ministers here today. Mayor Clarke is a great Australian who has championed our broader Gold Coast rights for water control and security. He has brought our nation great distinction over a long, long history in many spheres. He is the patron of the 2018 Commonwealth Games and he deserves the accolades that are bestowed upon him.

In relation to local government changes in this bill, clauses 7, 8 and 58 of this bill amend the City of Brisbane Act and the Local Government Act to allow the minister to direct a local government change commission regarding its assessment of a proposed change. This change commission is created under this act. Critically, clause 58 amends section 19 to remove minimum requirements regarding assessment and direct that change commission to act in a particular way and require that change commission to comply with the minister’s direction. I refer members to section 19. I put it to members that this should be referred to as potential amendments to gerrymander by Labor since it nobbles the capacity of the so-called independent body, the change commissioner.

The comments of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee in paragraph 49 of the Legislation Alert that was issued today should be noted. The change is wrong and merely reflects much of the nonsense that occurred in the last electoral redistribution in Queensland.
