XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It should be remembered that under the existing law, a large number of ‘penthouse’ owners have an almost unfettered ability similar to that contained in section 380 to force a re-writing of levies in their favour.

It is the Property Council’s view that new section 380 and its associated provisions provides the greater good for the greater number of unit owners as opposed to the existing legislation which provided windfall benefits for a small number of wealthy penthouse owners.
XML.Hansard-Body: Not all penthouse owners are wealthy. Some bought under favourable developer conditions. Not all have cash on hand. Some are on tight budgets and need to live frugally. It is unfair and improper of the Property Council to make discriminatory judgements such as these. It is comments like these that could be accused of typecasting and creating a social divide. Mrs Boland from Mermaid Waters argued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Penthouse owners weren’t the only ones to benefit from changed entitlements, a considerable number of other unit owners did also. Not all penthouses are mansions and have very wealthy owners as we are led to believe.
XML.Hansard-Body: Liat Walker and Ros Janes, directors of Success Law Pty Ltd, said with regard to the following: ‘Any application before a specialist adjudicator or QCAT that has not been decided or has not been given effect by the time of the commencement of the amendment bill will cease to have the effect at commencement’--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We consider the objectives of the amendment Bill have not been met. Indeed, there will be less certainty for those bodies corporate who have been the subject of an order adjusting the contribution schedule lot entitlements, as they could be subject to a reversal of the order.
XML.Hansard-Body: Christina L Schoenbaechler from Palm Beach was grossly unimpressed with former minister Lawlor’s proposed amendments to the BCCM Act, suggesting it should be recycled as toilet paper. She said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The legislation achieves an unfair, confusing and communistic piece of legislation that could not be further from its objectives. I have lived many years in Europe and seen this type of legislation depriving human rights.
XML.Hansard-Body: Recent water price hikes have hit hard, especially singles living in complexes where units are not connected to a separate meter.
Mr Lucas interjected.

Mrs STUCKEY: The minister may like to listen to this. A suggestion was put forward that if the government really wanted to make unit living a more level playing field, the authorities should install separate water meters to every unit at no or very little cost to owners. The reason given was that it is not fair or reasonable for a single person in a unit to be made to contribute to water usage by units with three or more inhabitants.

Another resident reported that some unit blocks with separate meters are accepting a bulk bill from Allconnex and then billing each unit on their consumption. The UOAQ are of the view that bulk water supply should be discounted due to reduced meter-reading and billing costs.

The committee of a high-rise building in Main Beach on the Gold Coast comprising 124 units are most distressed as they changed their lot contribution schedule by consensus and had it ratified by the court. The history of this facility, I am told, is that the developer presold the penthouse and all subpenthouses--37 of them--to Japanese investors before the lot contribution schedule had been determined. The developer then loaded all the top units’ contribution schedules so that he could reduce the lower floor contribution schedules to make them easier to sell on the local market.

This action was considered so blatantly wrong that the lot owners, by consensus, agreed to a more equitable schedule. It is now their view that they will be reverted to the unjust contribution schedule with no opportunity to have the matter reviewed. If this behaviour was going on at this one block then there is every chance it has occurred at others.

A number of people have told me that in the early days of high-rise development developers offered some buyers very good deals to assist in quicker sales but others did not fare so well, as I have indicated with the above-mentioned case. The committee of this building want to know if this legislation is unconstitutional in that it deprives building owners of their democratic right to vote on the future of their building. ‘How can this legislation satisfy the primary and secondary objectives of the BCCM Act?’ they ask. Mrs Boland says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The passing of this bill would be a travesty of justice, unthinkable in a democracy ... By reverting to the original unfair entitlements will not make the issue go away--it will continue to simmer and cause disharmony in various Body Corporates.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Martin Clark, who owns a large unit in the Q1 building on the Gold Coast, said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I have always voted Labor and was disappointed to hear you suggest that unit owners such as myself should be subsidising Body Corp levies for the smaller units ... The majority of wear and tear in the building is caused by the major traffic through these rental units.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Why is there no provision for units that are rented out to holiday makers to pay higher Body Corp levies? These are the units that have the biggest impact on common property or maintenance. During the Schoolies festival for example, Q1 has about 100 units rented out to schoolies. At the end of the festival, we had approximately $100,000 of damage caused by schoolies. However the unit owners who reaped massive rents (approx $4,000 per week) contribute nil extra.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is a quote from Mr Clark. Wallace and Robyn Kienzle, in supporting the bill, described the developer’s system for allocating lot entitlements as--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... very well thought out and took into account the size of the unit, the floor level and the stack--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: that is, whether it was north-east, east or south-east facing--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: all of which affected its value.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Kienzles were submitted to an unfair situation in which a number of body corporate committee members banded together to seek an adjustment which they believe had a detrimental result for a number of owners in the scheme.
Mr Lucas: There is nothing erudite in reading out letter after letter after letter. Your colleague the shadow Attorney-General doesn’t make that sort of contribution.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Deputy Premier!

Mrs STUCKEY: It is a real pity that the minister is interrupting me while I am actually telling him about someone who is supporting his legislation. Atlantis West on the Gold Coast went through an adjustment which saw the contributions of the penthouse and subpenthouse owners reduced substantially. A number of residents from Atlantis West expressed their support for these amendments. Reg Warr of Robina said, ‘If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it!’ He underwent personal costs of thousands of dollars to go through an adjustment to have a fair and equitable entitlement system put in place. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is grossly unfair and makes a nonsense of an existing order and a total waste of those monies expended to reach that decision. That there is no room for appeal against such a reversal of procedure adds to the blatant unfairness of the proposal.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Graeme Muller from Labrador in opposing the legislation said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Why should one section of the community have to unfairly subsidise another, there is no justice in this. We cannot agree that some lot owners have an obligation to provide affordable housing (for others). That is the responsibility of Governments. It is a disgraceful piece of legislation that is contemplated.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The UOAQ wrote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Bill as presented fails to provide any improvement over the consultation draft. The Minister has not considered--or if considered, rejected--stakeholder concerns. The Minister has failed to make any appropriate changes to present more democratic and objective achievement of the stated objectives of the legislation. Moreover, the Explanatory Notes admit that the Bill fails to achieve compliance with the Legislative Standards Act 1992. The Unit Owners Association Queensland philosophically rejects ‘resolutions without dissent’ as a device to circumvent democratic voting rights and disenfranchise owners.
If anything is achieved, it is to add to the confusion and expense surrounding contribution schedule adjustment.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It goes on to mention that the explanatory notes admit that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Existing schemes will not be able to adjust their contribution schedules except by resolution without dissent, or reversion to the pre-1997 developer imposed schedules. Resolutions without dissent are an impossibility; therefore, all existing schemes will be reverted, on the opinion of one owner, to the unfair and unjust developer imposed contribution schedule. Effectively reverting Bodies Corporate 14 years to where they were before the 2003 contribution schedule legislation, and creating two classes of buildings, pre and post the Bill.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The current principle for setting and adjusting contribution schedule lot entitlements is--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: as is quoted in this bill--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘that they should be equal except to the extent it is not just and equitable in the circumstances for them not to be equal’.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This, according to the UOAQ, is one clear and easily understood principle.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Summervilles from Runaway Bay wrote to me and explained that they and other owners put in a combined request for their lots to become just and equitable. They engaged solicitors, as did the body corporate. Both parties negotiated the lot entitlements to adjust an equitable number for everyone. It was submitted to QCAT. A judgement was passed on 6 April 2010 and body corporate fees were adjusted on 1 July. Now they are very concerned that the minister is taking away their equality and their rights to appeal. These folk paid a significant amount of money to go through the processes brought in by this same Labor government that is now trying to toss out its own legislation, harming innocent unit owners along the way.

Les Armstrong, President of the Association of Residents of Queensland Retirement Villages--the largest advocacy organisation in Queensland that represents 7,500 members across the state’s 326 villages--has expressed his concern at not being consulted by the government on this legislation despite 135 of Queensland’s retirement villages established as community title schemes under the BCCM Act. A submission from ARQRV stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In preparing the bill, the Government does not appear to have considered the unique nature of retirement village schemes as compared to ordinary community titles schemes.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In particular, Mr Armstrong raised issues regarding unit sale prices and exit fees. He states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In light of these matters, the ARQRV opposes the Bill to the extent that it could cause an increase in ongoing costs for residents in villages who had entered the village (and committed to exit fees) in the belief that the equality principle would continue to be applied to their contribution schedule lot entitlements.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: So any argument from the government that this is to support people on lower incomes is absolutely lame according to Mr Armstrong’s submission.
XML.Hansard-Body: Notably, unlike many other bills that come before the parliament, the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 does not list in the explanatory notes what organisations, government departments or key bodies were consulted on the drafting of this legislation. This omission is perplexing and would suggest a degree of secrecy on the part of the government. According to reports in the newspaper, the former minister stated they had received about 150 submissions to the draft consultation bill, largely from affected individual lot owners. But those figures were in contrast to those provided by Mr Catlin during our briefing, who said there were 216 submissions in total. Unfortunately it would appear the government did not ask for a waiver from those who sent in submissions, using the excuse of cabinet confidentiality, so honourable members are prevented from knowing details of submitters. In order to provide genuine transparency in this debate, I ask if the minister will give honourable members an explanation as to why this is so and provide a catalogue of these groups to the House. After all, they are included sometimes in other bills.
On 6 December 2010 a Gold Coast resident received a letter from the then minister stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: There were 216 submissions received and departmental officers from the Office of Regulatory Policy within the Department of Employment, Economic Development and Innovation reviewed all submissions and provided an analysis of submissions to government for consideration. Submissions were received from owners in community titles schemes, advocacy groups, law firms and professional organisations as well as Government agencies.
XML.Hansard-Body: I can understand why private individuals desire privacy over their submissions, but I fail to see why all of the other groups mentioned are not disclosed and made available as important material to assist with this debate. The opposition requests that the minister table for the House a list of the groups and the government agencies he mentions in the correspondence he sent to this resident and I ask that the minister give a breakdown of percentages for each group and for these individuals. Without this information the members of this parliament are denied knowledge of the degree of support or the degree of dissension in these submissions. It struck me that 216 submissions was a relatively small response when one considers the size of the pool of affected people, estimated to be over 364,000 lots. A sceptic might accuse the former minister of pushing his own barrow on this one, determined to proceed regardless of responses. Then there is the fact that this review has been going for so long and only now appearing in the parliament for debate. I wonder how many people with lot entitlements living under these schemes realise what the government is planning here. How many submissions from residents were for this legislation and how many were against? Surely we have a right to know.

Another point of concern was raised by a respected firm that deals with issues relating to this act. It told me that the 2008 discussion paper resulted in such negative reactions to this bill that the former minister at that time shelved the results, hoping the more recent one would provide more support for the bill. Sue Ekert, a long-serving committee member of UOAQ, commented--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The submissions procedure was a complete debacle in my view. Minister Lawlor is looking after the complaining people in his electorate.
XML.Hansard-Body: Another submission from Mrs Sue Potts from the Sunshine Coast said she actually met with the former minister to address the inefficiencies of this bill in relation to layered schemes and said of the former minister--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... he listened but did not help. He appeared to already be set on his particular course of action--to overturn the current legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body:
In the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Legislation Alert No. 1 of
2011 a number of sections of this bill were highlighted as potentially affecting the rights and liberties of individuals. In particular, the committee found new section 46A, which defines the relativity principle for setting contribution schedule lot entitlements, may be inconsistent with the principles of natural justice as it may allow a decision to be made based on an irrelevant consideration, that being that contribution lot entitlements could be solely based on the market value of lots, placing a larger portion of body corporate costs on owners of lots with higher market values irrespective of the size of their lots or any other relevant considerations. This is an exceptionally important point, which was also raised by the Queensland Law Society as a considerable flaw in the way in which this legislation has been drafted.

The Legislation Alert of this parliament echoed numerous concerns from the Law Society, highlighting sections of the bill that adversely affect the rights and liberties of individuals, unclear and vague drafting that will leave concepts open to broad interpretation by the courts and strong concerns about the retrospective application of this bill. I say again: these serious issues were raised by the parliament’s own committee.

Also worth noting is the number of offences that this bill creates, the majority of which relate to penalising bodies corporate for failing to adhere to time frames and procedures for updating the CMS. Like many other honourable members in this House, I am not in favour of the practice of retrospective legislation. This bill before us would enable retrospectivity to apply many years back. In March 2008 in this House I said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Retrospective legislation is contrary to fundamental legislative principles.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Ryan: They whack those poor pensioners that own units in your electorate. Whack them hard.

Mrs STUCKEY: My position has not changed but, very clearly, those interjecting do not really care about fundamental legislative principles. Aspects of this proposed legislation will have retrospective impact on some community title schemes, with the ability to revert contribution schedule lot entitlements to their original settings prior to any and all adjustment orders. Reverting contribution schedule lot entitlement adjustments may be seen as a breach of fundamental legislative principles as orders from a specialist adjudicator, tribunal and court will be overturned even though they were made in accordance with the law at that time.
The Australian College of Community Association Lawyers said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A retrospective reversion and/or to permit unilateral action on the part of a single owner is inconsistent with good policy and legislative practice and creates discriminatory outcomes rather than a balanced and equitable basis for the rights of all stakeholders involved in community title schemes.
XML.Hansard-Body: On the subject of retrospectivity, I ask honourable members to cast their minds back to the debate on the 2003 bill. This debate attracted a stack of Labor speakers--some 26 of them--who spoke in glowing terms about the provisions in the bill. They raised numerous unaddressed issues relating to management rights, an area omitted from this bill before us despite the government having almost eight years to review the legislation. Here is what some of them had to say about this legislation that they now want to reverse. The honourable member for Stretton--the minister at the time--said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The guiding principle for both setting and adjusting the contributions schedule is that it involves the equitable sharing of the costs of operating and maintaining the common property. These costs should be borne in proportion to the benefit, not in proportion to the unit’s value. It is not a contribution linked to an ability to pay, but as a payment for services.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The minister went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: However, if there are reasons why an equal contribution schedule would not be fair or equitable, it can be changed through application to the courts or to a specialist adjudicator.
But when we are talking about those parts of a property where the benefits are shared more or less equally, we cannot apply the same formula.
XML.Hansard-Body: Now Labor is introducing this as part of one of the formulas developers may use when setting contribution schedules--included in relativity principles established under this bill. The Queensland Law Society and other respected bodies have grave concerns about the inclusion of market value of the lots as an attributing factor to be considered when allocating lot entitlements. The minister went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: At the end of the day, this bill is about two things: It is about our economy and it is about our people. That is why the central tenet of this bill is to make things simpler and fairer for all Queenslanders... the bill before the House today, has meant that the legislation before members is the best tool for fixing the little cracks in Queensland’s community titles industry.
XML.Hansard-Body: The honourable member for Callide is not one who is known to often praise Labor policies. He must have been feeling in a generous mood, because he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I think the minister can be commended for the fact that the legislation that comes before the House today is the result of a compromise in terms of what was, at the start of this process, a divergent range of opinions. That compromise has been able to satisfy unit owners as well as residential managers and the rest of the stakeholders. As far as I am aware, no group within that stakeholder community opposes this legislation.
XML.Hansard-Body: The honourable member for Mackay--now a minister--spoke in glowing terms about this bill. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This bill is a model of how government, business and the wider community can work together to develop workable, practical and beneficial legislation that delivers positive outcomes for all Queenslanders.
The involvement of industry stakeholders in developing this bill has been exemplary and instrumental to its success.
XML.Hansard-Body: Sadly, this involvement was not continued in the consultation process leading to this bill. You could not silence the member for Mackay. He was so full of praise. He went on to say--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This bill does not favour one group over another. This bill delivers a fair outcome for every Queenslander it affects.
XML.Hansard-Body: I wonder what the honourable member has to say about this bill, as it undoes the fair and balanced stakeholder approved model of 2003. By its very nature, this bill establishes a two-tiered system of bodies corporate, differing for schemes established prior to the commencement of the bill and those established after the commencement of the bill. The explanatory notes to the bill state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This proposal does present a possible breach of fundamental legislative principles in that lot owners in schemes established prior to the commencement of the Bill will have a different set of rights to lot owners in schemes established after the commencement of the Bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: The government’s response to this matter is--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The distinction between the community titles schemes established pre- and post-commencement of the Bill is considered necessary.
XML.Hansard-Body: By whom? How was this deduction made that it was necessary? This statement does not offer any explanation, either measured or otherwise. Those schemes developed after this bill will be governed by an entirely new set of principles and arrangements. Legal opinions state that buyers may be discouraged from purchasing lots in older buildings where bodies corporate have entrenched arrangements that are deemed unfair. The minister needs to satisfy the argument. Where are the statistics and figures to say that that will not be the case?

The former minister could not provide a list of those who supplied submissions and has now managed to avoid all responsibility for providing a breakdown of the findings. Additionally, there are no accurate figures of people who are tied up in the middle of applications for adjustments. As I said earlier, in 2003 not one member of parliament opposed the bill. Let us see what the Labor members will do now. Will they go back on their word? Will they say that they told untruths in 2003? No, they lack the intestinal fortitude to do that, especially as their own minister could not bring himself to acknowledge the 2003 legislation in his second reading speech.

It is important to look at what was said in the debate on that bill, as it is the provisions therein that the minister and the Bligh government now want to repeal. The minister may think that Labor’s own legislation in 2003 was wrong, even though he cannot admit it. But what he has presented before us today is abominable and the LNP cannot support it. I shall be moving a number of amendments and I foreshadow that now.
Debate, on motion of Mrs Stuckey, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Parliament of Queensland (Reform and Modernisation) Amendment Bill

Hansard-Body.A: (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (7.57 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Auditor-General Act 2009, Criminal Organisation Act 2009, Electoral Act 1992, Information Privacy Act 2009, Integrity Act 2009, Legislative Standards Act 1992, Ombudsman Act 2001, Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 and Right to Information Act 2009 for particular purposes. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper : Parliament of Queensland (Reform and Modernisation) Amendment Bill [ 4214 ].
Tabled paper: Parliament of Queensland (Reform and Modernisation) Amendment Bill, explanatory notes [ 4215 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for Reconstruction) (7.57 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: I am pleased to introduce the Parliament of Queensland (Reform and Modernisation) Amendment Bill 2011. This bill seeks to reform the Queensland parliamentary committee system to strengthen and support the role of the Legislative Assembly in scrutinising legislation and executive government. This bill enacts the first stage of the government’s response to the work undertaken by the Committee System Review Committee in 2010 in their landmark and bipartisan review of our committee system and parliamentary processes.

In 2009, the government released the discussion paper Integrity and accountability in Queensland . It was clear from the feedback that Queenslanders wanted greater oversight of the government and examination of legislation by the parliament.

Queensland is unique among Australian states in that our legislation only has to pass one house of parliament to become law. In response, the parliament established a committee to report on how the parliamentary oversight of legislation could be enhanced and how the existing parliamentary committee system could be strengthened to enhance accountability. The Committee System Review Committee, chaired by the member for Sunnybank with the member for Southern Downs as deputy chair, included representatives from both major parties and the Independents. Its members understood parliament and parliamentary procedures in detail. They were very well experienced members of the House. The committee spent most of 2010 considering options and public submissions on ways to improve parliamentary oversight and accountability.

Its report of December 2010 made 55 recommendations. When the government was considering the recommendations, it had the key points from the terms of reference at the forefront of its deliberations: accountability, oversight and effective examination of legislation. Parliament debated the review committee’s report over two days in March 2011 and, as a result, the parliament established a Committee of the Legislative Assembly to provide a roadmap to implement the government’s response to the report. This bill takes account of the views of many of the members who contributed to the debate, together with the wishes of the Committee of the Legislative Assembly, including the members of the opposition and the view of the cabinet. It will improve the way the parliament operates and will better adapt our committee system to the community’s expectations in the 21st century.

Specifically, the bill makes a number of changes. First, it will establish portfolio committees made up of an equal number of members from each side of the parliament. These committees will cover all ministerial portfolios and government departments. Their main activities will include, for their respective portfolios: conducting the budget estimates inquiries; examining legislation, both government and private members’ bills; and examining public accounts and public works matters associated with the portfolio. Portfolio committees will have the ability to call public servants as witnesses and ask questions of them directly in accordance with the provisions of the standing orders. Alternatively, public servants may be invited to assist committees to understand the legislation which government brings before the parliament. Members of the public will be able to make submissions on legislation and raise concerns they have regarding legislation directly with the committee.

The portfolio committees will be provided with more time during sitting weeks to discuss matters and more time in parliament to have their reports debated. The new committee system will reinforce the current high level scrutiny of the rights of individuals and the principles of natural justice. Accordingly, the bill retains the functions of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee to examine legislation for consistency with the Legislative Standards Act 1992. These powers are being provided to portfolio committees to enable them to examine both the legislative obligations and the policy intent of the legislation simultaneously.

The Public Accounts and Public Works Committee will no longer exist, but all of its functions are being given to the portfolio committees. That is, the portfolio committees will be able to review reports by the Auditor-General and examine major capital works within their portfolio areas, amongst other things. The portfolio committees will also serve as the estimates committees to examine in detail the budgets of the departments within their portfolio and ask questions of ministers and senior public servants at their public hearing. These comprehensive powers and responsibilities will ensure that the budget, accounts, capital works and legislation for portfolio areas will be examined in the one forum in a coordinated and comprehensive manner.

The number, title and portfolio areas to be allocated to these portfolio committees will be established by the parliament in standing orders. These matters are to be the subject of further consideration by the Committee of the Legislative Assembly with a view to having draft standing orders before the parliament for consideration in May 2011. The bill also seeks to establish a separate ethics committee to consider any matters referred to it with respect to complaints about the ethical conduct of particular members or alleged breaches of privilege by members of parliament or other persons.

While the Committee of the Legislative Assembly was established by resolution of the parliament on 10 March 2011, this bill will establish that committee as a statutory committee. The Committee of the Legislative Assembly will assume the responsibilities of the Standing Orders Committee and the bill provides that the Speaker will be a member of the committee when it is dealing with matters relating to the standing orders. The bill also makes provision for a member of the committee to nominate an alternate.

The bill provides that the areas of responsibility of the Committee of the Legislative Assembly will be: the ethical conduct of members, including arrangements for the Register of Members’ Interests--however, the ethics committee will deal with any complaints of breaches of these provisions; publishing and reviewing the code of ethical conduct for members; parliamentary powers, rights and immunities; standing rules and orders about the conduct of business by, and the practices and procedures of, the Assembly and its committees; and any other matters for which the committee is given responsibility under standing orders.

With respect to the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Committee, this committee is being retained with the current complement of seven members. However, it is the government’s intention to appoint a non-government member as chair of this committee. The new parliamentary committee system will ensure the highest standards of parliamentary scrutiny of the executive, of the operation of the parliament and of the conduct of members.

Beyond the parliamentary committee system, the bill also inserts the newly titled position of Manager of Opposition Business as an office holder to which an additional salary can be paid, and makes provision for committee chairs to receive an increase to the additional salaries they currently receive. This will give due recognition to the additional responsibilities of these positions and is in line with the bipartisan recommendation of the Committee System Review Committee. The amount of the additional salaries will be determined by the Governor in Council and will be made public through the Queensland Government Gazette and the Members’ Entitlements Handbook . The bill also includes amendments to implement government responses to other parliamentary committee reports.

The government’s response to Report No. 109 of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee supported a recommendation to combine a register of written waivers by members to rewards of holding a public appointment, required to be maintained by the Speaker, with the Register of Members’ Interests, maintained by the Clerk of the Parliament. The bill amends the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 to implement this commitment.

Further, the bill implements the government’s response to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee’s Report No. 42 to amend the Legislative Standards Act 1992 to require that all subordinate legislation be accompanied by an explanatory note. While this requirement has already been implemented by the government administratively, the legislative amendments are now proposed to enshrine them in law. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Horan, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.LegAssembly: Body Corporate & Community Management & Other Legislation A’ment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 971, on motion of Mr Lawlor--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body:
Dr DOUGLAS (Gaven--LNP)
(8.07 pm): There has been both great anxiety and anticipation of this legislation by thousands of unit owners across our state, our cities, especially on the Gold Coast, and even in my electorate of Gaven. To quote the most recent report of the Unit Owners Association of Queensland--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Unit living must remain sustainable if community living is to thrive well into the future.

If the status quo remains, the costs of unit living will continue to grow well beyond the reach of ordinary homeowners who may wish to live a unit lifestyle and leave a lighter footprint on our environment.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The former minister is correct when he says in his second reading speech--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We have a problem in the marketplace. It needs to be fixed.
XML.Hansard-Body: The former minister is here tonight. His problem is that he vacillated for too long whilst unit owners were caught in this no-man’s land which correctly the minister has described as an untenable situation where ‘they cannot afford the increased fees but cannot afford to sell at fire sale rates’. Add this to the worst returns in 20 years for those on fixed incomes as either full or part self-funded retirees or pensioners and a person’s home is often their only or, for some, their major asset--that is, a lifetime investment.

Whilst noting the severity in proportionate terms for those on low or fixed incomes, what the government has done is to delay this bill unnecessarily to almost maximise the pain of these very vulnerable groups. This is grossly unfair and unconscionable. The incorrect perception seems to be that those unit residents are all old, they are all childless with no dependants and they mainly vote against the Labor Party. There is nothing further from the truth. This is the answer to those false assumptions: on the Gold Coast it must be presumed, as it is the minister’s home city, that he has incorrectly decided that the impact of the QCAT adjustment to contribution schedules in 2008-09 which led to this current debacle is mainly on the high-end, mainly Surfers Paradise, Southport, Broadbeach, Burleigh and Coolangatta high-rise owners. That is wrong. Many owners beyond those boundaries have been impacted. They have all just endured a dreadful Christmas, which was compounded by higher water, electricity and gas charges. New land tax charges by the state government and differential ratings by local councils have only added to the misery of very upwardly rising body corporate charges for individual owners.

The shadow minister, inclusive of the minister, has explained the impacts of the Centrepoint case in the Court of Appeal. That case clearly magnified the significance of the lot entitlement schedules, those being the contribution component and the interest component. The impact of the Court of Appeal case was on the equity end of the contribution schedule. Of course, a small group of owners had a great victory, which they would all agree was fair, and the court agreed with it. Sadly, the vast majority of owners were bitterly disappointed and the change has been that the contribution schedule lot entitlement was ratcheted up massively.

What was not said was that when owners purchased they did know what they were buying into and the costs were clearly explained, or so they thought. Those who now claim that a legitimate challenge to that formula is reasonable would be equally inferring that those who agreed to a lower contribution based on a different lot had a lesser entitlement for fairness, firstly, because they lost by virtue of the Court of Appeal deciding mainly in the penthouse owners’ favour. Secondly, the law has to be equitable and this issue of equity seems to blunt the definition that some are more equal than others. Thirdly, where people live in communities where costs must be shared, does an external party really have the right to change one portion of a significant agreement without giving all others an equal right to having all the agreements looked at and maybe changed? If this were truly to occur, there would be anarchy.

In this bill, the amendment that is critical is that which limits adjustments of contribution schedules for entitlements and provides for revisions for those schemes that have been the subject of contribution schedule orders. Of course, that will be a massive relief for those currently facing costs that they never expected or budgeted for. For those who thought they had a major win and a big annual cash saving, their hopes were dashed and they will be very unhappy. This problem was always going to be about winners and losers. Essentially, there were too many losers and too few winners, as the law stood after the successful appeal. Now it would seem that everyone becomes a loser, so go figure that one.

A few other amendments need discussion and I will address those before the completion of my speech. What has not been said by the minister, although the shadow minister has alluded to it, is that the member for Southport enthusiastically supported the previous changes in the legislation that subsequently led to the QCAT appeals. While his speech has been quoted already, I will refer to it. The former minister, who is now the Minister for Energy and DERM, championed the changes. Certainly the quote is as was stated by the former minister, that is--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The guiding principle for both setting and adjusting the contributions schedule is that it involves the equitable sharing of the costs of operating and maintaining the common property. These costs should be borne in proportion to the benefit, not in proportion to the unit’s value.
XML.Hansard-Body: The minister went on to speak about the fact that you pay in proportion to what you use. He said that the central tenet of the bill was to make things simpler and fairer for all Queensland. He talked about safeguarding futures. How wrong he was. The former minister, the member for Southport, said that he supported the minister’s stance. He said that he supported the BCCM and Other Legislation Amendment Bill and he congratulated the minister and his staff for the important bill, which he commended to the House. It is no wonder that QCAT made the decisions that it did. What does that say about a lack of foresight, sowing the seeds of one’s own destruction and that truism, taught to our children, to always consider the consequences of your actions?
There are more than a few red flags here and they were apparent very soon after the BCCM Act 1997 was enacted. Critically, in his second reading speech the former minister stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: .... the new module will potentially affect 12,000 community titles schemes in Queensland, which represents almost one-third of community titles schemes in Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is a very big group and it is growing. Secondly, the speech stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bill will introduce a new and more flexible system of contribution schedule lot entitlements, including a new relativity principle aimed ...’
XML.Hansard-Body: That corrects the anomaly generated in the 1997 BCCM Act where the two lot entitlement schedules, the contribution and interest schedules, were introduced, but it leaves the window open for the challenge to the equity rules on the contribution schedule, which all now claim was apparent. I put it to the House that it was very clear on the basis of available evidence at the time--that is, schedule lot entitlement distributions were entitled to be adjusted but the owners had to apply to do so. That problem was apparent at the time and yet we were all allowed to blunder on. What is extraordinary is that it took so long for 120 applicants to get a QCAT ruling and even longer for this hapless Labor government to take action.

Thirdly, and most tellingly in the case of this bill, there has been an appalling lack of stakeholder consultation and open disclosure at a time when people’s lives and homes are at stake. We are all in the same jungle and we must talk to one another to ensure that we all survive. This lack of transparency is shocking and it should be a big wake-up call. There is a wide body of evidence that this government and the minister pressed on when most were urging caution. Too many people are hurting and those who have just had what they believe was a very justified victory are feeling friendless--
Mr Lawlor interjected.

Dr DOUGLAS: The member should listen--bereft and unprotected by the judiciary. It is not the court system nor our system. It is a recklessness and a failure to look for red flags. It is legislators who see only green flags, even though they are paid to be cautious and govern for all.

The bill changes disclosure requirements for developers to explain contribution and interest entitlements, to have the explanation form as part of the community management form and to attach both to the contract of sale, which collectively would seem to say that buyer beware remains but if that fails then we will have the risk transferred back to the developers. It is no wonder that in Australia we are short over $100 billion homes, that currently on the Gold Coast housing starts are 50 per cent of what they were in 2007 and that builders in my electorate of Gaven are queuing in foodbank lines for emergency food supplies. At Christmas, at the Nerang community centre 113 families lined up for food.

To attempt to solve every problem by transferring responsibility excessively back to the supplier leads to less choice, less stock, inferior quality and higher cost. If this is the Labor solution to everything, as appears to be the case, then why would anyone support such nonsense? This body corporate bill has prompted many in my electorate to contact me regarding many other issues that are just as difficult and problematic. One constant problem is that of the owner of a unit in a small complex who does not really need a body corporate with a contracted unit manager, although many such complexes have them. Businesses are charging small lot owners exorbitant fees for very minor services, with large mark-ups for things such as pool maintenance, lawn mowing and just being there. The management rights are on sold, but really it is simply an on-site owner who performs few of the services. The owners could save themselves a fortune by not having such people around, yet they are paying monthly fees. None of those problems are represented in the bill.

It behoves the new minister to get a grasp of the whole area. The government needs to widely consult stakeholders and try to understand the broader problems. That needs to be done for all of the problems, and there are so many of them. To shamefully try to push the current issue through is a forlorn hope that will do no-one justice. Indeed, it may do little to address some of the dreadful injustices that have occurred. Basically, it is both cavalier and insensitive. If we want sustainable communities and sustainable jobs, then a good start can be made by looking at very reasonable cost structures for unit and community title dwellers in Queensland. If one adds a policy of carefully thinking through legislative changes for home owners, then one critical part of individual Queenslander’s lives will be changed for the better. Interestingly, the case that drew everyone’s attention was the Centrepoint case. If all we do is put consumers at the centre of all of our legislative deliberations and keep pointing both our energies and ourselves at resolving their problems, this current problem, for example, would never have occurred.

This bill needs extensive changes to make it worthwhile. I would urge the minister and members of the Labor Party to embrace the changes suggested by the shadow minister. They will lead to peace and harmony in an area where there has been much unhappiness. Lot entitlements should be based on both the equality principle and the relativity principle, but they vary so much. Critically, the Queensland Law Society is quite on track and quite right when it states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... there needs to be an appropriate balance struck between fairness for lot owners holistically and the comfort for individuals brought about by certainty.
XML.Hansard-Body: If this bill does not achieve that objective then it is as bad as the 2003 bill, which Labor now wants to reverse. In essence, this bill punishes the majority who have spent time and money to reach equity and now see that trashed. Where is the fairness in that? The original decision was a vote grab, as is this reversal. There are 39,000 schemes in Queensland covering 364,000 lots. This bill is about affordability for whom?

Hansard-Body.A: (Mermaid Beach--LNP) (8.20 pm): I rise tonight to speak on the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. From the outset I would like to say that this bill is acknowledgement from the government itself that it is unfit to legislate in Queensland. This bill is a classic Beattie-Bligh backflip on the amending legislation that it brought to this House in 2003. It has caused considerable community angst, pitting fellow community living dwellers against each other. I would like to congratulate my colleague the shadow minister for small business, job creation, fair trading and industrial relations and shadow minister for women on her succinct and informative contribution to the debate to explain to the people of Queensland why we should not let this Bligh Labor government govern Queensland.

XML.Hansard-Body: The basic principle in this debate is who should pay more and who should pay less. If one party in the community living entity pays more for activity and services in that entity then, by definition, another party will pay less. It is a complete abrogation of this government’s responsibility to bring in legislation that should be effective and that specifically addresses the issue when it failed dismally to get it right with the legislation that it passed through this House in 2003. Now it is saying, ‘We got it wrong in 2003. Will you support us to backflip and get it right in 2011?’ What a lot of nonsense! It is an absolute indictment of Minister Stephen Robertson, who pushed the 2003 legislation through, and it is an incredible ‘give yourself an upper cut’ self-blow to then Minister Lawlor, who said in 2003 how wonderful that legislation was only to introduce rectifying legislation in 2010. That legislation was to rectify the rectifying legislation that then Minister Lawlor thought was so rectifying. It sounds like a pile of rectum rectification to me!

I have had meeting after meeting with unit owners on both sides of the argument and can see that both have significant reasons for their position. My shadow cabinet colleagues, the shadow minister for fair trading and members of the opposition see that there has not been enough consideration of the unit owners that this legislation will adversely affect. The Community Titles Institute of Queensland believes that 21,500 lots will be directly affected by these changes.

Today the LNP will be voting against this bill because we believe that, yet again, these are Labor Party amendments that are ad hoc and have not been researched enough to be effective in a growing industry of community living. This industry--
Mr Ryan: How many pensioners own units in Mermaid Beach?
Mr STEVENS: Heaps. I take the interjection from the member for Morayfield. There are a lot of community living titles in Mermaid Beach.

The industry is growing at an amazing rate, with community living--whether it is unit complexes, townhouses or stand-alone properties in a gated community--becoming the people’s choice and a very popular form of living accommodation. The reality is that the 1997 legislation is now outdated and needs to be reworked from the ground up. The premise that the developer should set the lot entitlements gives no recognition to the fact that it will be the entity’s own community that will endure the living conditions for perhaps many decades ahead. It is that community that is expected to live in harmony on the same piece of ground shared in ownership under the current flawed legislation.

It is sometimes far too tempting for a developer to set lot entitlements that are advantageous to their own financial needs and not to address the long-term ramifications of their decisions on unit dwellers. For instance, if a developer wanted to live in a penthouse of an apartment building, he could write the lot entitlement down for the penthouse to favour his own financial position and force the lower unit owners to pay more than what is fair and equitable. Alternatively, if a developer wanted to--
Mr Lawlor: Everyone goes in with their eyes open. Everyone can check the lot entitlements on the body corporate records. Everyone goes in with their eyes open.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order!

Mr STEVENS: Thank you for your protection, Madam Deputy Speaker. It really is quite unbelievable that a member could come forward with the comment ‘everyone goes in with their eyes open’ and therefore it is acceptable. It is not fair and it is not acceptable, but they are in there with their eyes open! On very many occasions there are people in our society who are not protected by just having their eyes open. I am sure the member for Southport thinks a caveat emptor world is wonderful from a solicitor’s point of view, where everyone has to look after themselves, but that is what governments are supposed to do. That is why we have Fair Trading. That is why the minister is responsible for Fair Trading. We have to put in checks and balances that protect people in our society who are not capable of doing that themselves--and there are many of them. For the minister to say that they should have their eyes open is a complete abrogation of his responsibility to the unit dwellers and people in community living in the electorate of Southport whom he is supposed to represent.

The 2003 legislation recognised the conundrum of the 1997 legislation but has obviously failed to address it correctly, hence this ad hoc and misguided attempt at rectification in the House today. Issues such as the developer setting long lease periods for management rights to the entity seem a terrible impost on future communities living in the entity when the developer has grabbed his cash and run, leaving residents and QCAT, funded by the taxpayers of Queensland, to sort out problems created by this failed legislation. For instance, what would be wrong with the initial term of lease of management rights on developed property being limited to three years, until the community had established itself in the premises and would be then best placed to set its own lease management period?

Community living should be totally about the community making the best decisions for its own community as a whole. That is why bodies corporate are charged with decision making and direction taking on behalf of their community. A complete review of body corporate legislation by the next government in Queensland would demonstrate to the thousands of body corporate dwellers a can-do approach to address industry concerns.

The objective of this bill is to amend the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997 by creating and introducing a new lot entitlements system. The new lot entitlements system will consist of two guiding principles for the setting of contribution schedule lot entitlements and a ‘limited ability’ to adjust contribution schedule lot entitlements. In regard to community titles schemes established before this piece of legislation was developed, there is a chance for lot owners to have the opportunity to revert the contribution schedule lot entitlements for every lot in a scheme to their original setting prior to any adjustment order already in place. According to the government’s explanatory notes, the second objective of the bill is to simplify the management arrangements for residential community titles schemes that only have two lots.

Community living is the fastest growing form of housing and accommodation arrangements in Queensland, with many people choosing to live in body corporate managed complexes and unit blocks. There are 380,000-odd body corporate management groups in Queensland which means there could be up to a million Queenslanders who in some form will be affected by this legislation.
Mr Lawlor: That’s not right.

Mr STEVENS: One major concern is the retrospective nature of this piece of legislation which will have significant changes and regulations imposed on unit owners and which will have a significant effect on people who have invested in property in good faith under the laws of Queensland. I take the interjection from the member for Southport who said that it is not right. It was he who said that the 2003 legislation was right and, hello, in 2011 says it is wrong. So does the former minister who introduced the legislation know if it is right or wrong? Is he Yin or Yang?

This Bligh government is now sanctioning a loss of financial position to some property investors after 2003 through this legislation, and former Minister Lawlor and current Minister Lucas should hang their heads in shame. The history of this legislation goes back to the Building Units and Group Titles Act 1980, which introduced a single schedule of lot entitlements for community titles schemes. From this original piece of legislation, the Body Corporate and Community Management Act was introduced in 1997 and brought in two different types of lot entitlements schedules--a contribution schedule and an interest schedule. The majority of body corporate charges are determined by each lot’s contributor schedule lot entitlements.

Amendments to the Body Corporate and Community Management Act in 2003 were introduced by the Labor government to change the legislation where one set of body corporate fees were required for each unit or property. This is the system that the Labor Party wants to change in the present bill before the House. In 2006-07 there was a decision to review the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 2003, and this review recognised the need for the simplification of management arrangements for residential communities.

The proposed amendments attempt to ensure that there is an introduction of a new framework for the establishment and management of residential two-lot schemes. It will be called specified two-lot schemes module, which will manage the arrangements around two-lot schemes. All contribution schedule lot entitlements are to be fair and equitable, but we can see that this will not be the case with these amendments. The contribution schedule lot entitlements will still be based on the equality principle which will be equal under all circumstances or the relativity principle where there must be a relationship between lots by reference to one or more relevant factors. The two-lot schemes module can only apply if there is a written agreement between the owners of the lots called a ‘lot owner agreement’.

It is stated in the notes and required under the amendments of the bill that a body corporate for a two-lot scheme ‘will not have a body corporate committee, hold general meetings or be required to conduct a poll or cast a vote’ and can authorise or nominate a person to act in body corporate matters. Cost to government will apparently be none, but surely there are financial outlays by government because of more cases going through the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal. For this government, all disputes are heading towards QCAT determination, whether it be racing appeals, body corporates et cetera.
Dr Douglas: Neighbourhood disputes.

Mr STEVENS: Neighbourhood disputes--anything is going to QCAT. I can only see logjams for hearing dates and rivers of public money flowing to QCAT to try to keep up with poor Labor Party financial mismanagement. The Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal has been set up as a one-stop shop to deal with a variety of disputes and conflicts and, as we know, has a very heavy workload already and a backlog that needs government support to fix. With this piece of legislation there will be more community living residents who will need to utilise the services of QCAT.

There is potential for a breach of fundamental principles which I have major concerns with. The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee highlighted this in its Legislation Alert No. 1 of 2011. In the words of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee report, clause 5 may be inconsistent with principles of natural justice as it may allow a decision to be made based on an irrelevant consideration. Clause 5 also inserts a new section which brings in schemes introduced after commencement of the bill, the equity principle and relativity principle. With the relativity principle, this allows for an unequal contribution scheme.
Mr Wilson: You didn’t write this speech.

Mr STEVENS: Trust me. I’m a politician. Again, in regard to rights and liberties of individuals, clauses 7, 8, 12, 21 and 41 are of major concern. These are significant clauses that the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee has great trepidation and concerns about and which may breach fundamental legislative requirements.

Clause 8 in particular removes the right of some lot owners’ ability to apply for adjustment of their contribution schedule lot entitlements. This may deny lot owners their rights regarding the adjustment changes and processes. This is the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee saying that this is flawed legislation. They agree entirely with the LNP. A bipartisan committee says that what this group of people called the Labor Party in government are trying to do is railroad legislation that does not comply with and does not take into account the cares and concerns and the legal requirements of what is expected of a properly constituted government in Queensland.

Clause 21 looks at the requirement that if you fail to comply with continuing and future contravention notices then the penalty will be 20 penalty units. Clause 41 relates to body corporates failing to lodge requests to record new community management statements incorporating change to contribution schedule lot entitlements, with the penalty being up to $10,000. This, according to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee, may affect the rights and liberties of all lot owners. This is what an independent committee is saying.

New section 379 is also of concern to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee in regard to the rights and liberties of lot owners. This section has a sunset clause on motions for reversion of three years from commencement. It would be prospective in operation, taking property interests to a retrospective point in time prior to all or any adjustments of the original contribution scheme lot entitlements. This, I believe, is very significant and will definitely impinge on lot owners’ rights.

Clause 4 amends section 46, which relates to lot entitlements of community titles schemes after the beginning of the subsection relating to the contribution schedule principle and the interest schedule principle. The insertion of a new section establishes the equality principle and the relativity principle for deciding lot entitlements for community titles schemes. This section sets out relevant factors for the use of the relativity principle.
Mr Wilson: What does that mean?

Mr STEVENS: I am pleased to explain in very simple terms to members of the government what it all means. Developers are the ones that can choose which principles apply, either the relativity or equality principle, and therefore which relevant factors work out the contribution lot entitlements.

Clause 5 also introduces a new section which establishes the market value principle as the deciding principle for calculating interest schedule lot entitlements for lots included in a community titles scheme.

With the recent flooding events in Queensland, I would like to raise the point that there is no obligation on body corporates to insure their complexes for flood cover. It seems that insurance companies have abrogated their responsibilities in this area as well.

The insurance that is required by law is basic building cover. I believe that this is an issue that needs to be looked into and that will require future legislative changes to the insurance industry. If the properties are stand-alone and do not share walls, each individual property owner can take out flood insurance separately, but I do believe that most property owners in complexes presumed that they would be covered. The insurance system needs an overhaul so information that is clear and concise is disseminated to the consumer.

In conclusion, I am amazed that the Labor Party wants to change the law yet again--back to what the original piece of legislation was. To make changes in this muddled and reactive manner are symptomatic of a government in disarray, with incompetent ministers guiding the passage of important legislation through this House. If ever there was a sound recommendation for new and rigid scrutiny of legislation to be addressed in this House then this abominable piece of legislative handiwork by a dysfunctional Labor Party government is it.

One gets the cynical impression that this ill-founded legislation is based on political survival instincts rather than reasoned logic and fair decision making. It is to be hoped that all Queenslanders savour the cost of the 2003 and 2011 legislation on people’s lives in community living abodes and kick out this incompetent government at the first opportunity.

Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP)
(8.40 pm): I rise to support the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I want to focus on two particular elements. The first is the simplified process for dealing with bodies corporate for duplexes. In my electorate duplexes are common and becoming more common. Some of that is as a result of the Minister for Community Services and Housing’s department providing accommodation more suitable for older people who are looking for smaller accommodation.

Some of the new estates in my electorate are providing two- and three-bedroom accommodation units that are affordable. They are being provided through this duplex model. They are often very well done. They are often done on corners. People do not even realise they are duplexes because they have two street entrances. They have proven very successful in places like Holmview. I support this simplified model of administering the body corporate issues that arise in those circumstances.

I have a concern that I want to put on the record. It is dealt with in clauses 27 and 28 of this bill. This legislation puts a much greater onus on the seller of units and particularly the developer of units in terms of providing purchasers with information about what they are buying and moving into. I do support that principle. People need to know what they are getting when they move into these facilities. We need to ensure that there is some certainty.

Part of the problem I have in my electorate is an historical one. Developers of large townhouse developments, particularly in Edens Landing, have traditionally put in place a body corporate scheme and a contract for an on-site manager. That on-site management contract often has escalation clauses in it which mean the manager’s contract continues to escalate over time. I understand that those developers often sell that contract to a person who buys in. In the past that has made it difficult for some of my constituents to ascertain what it is they are purchasing when they move in. Because those management contracts continue to escalate their body corporate fees continue to escalate, and that puts significant pressure on their ownership.

For those residents in Edens Landing, I have sought the assistance of the Commissioner of Body Corporate and Community Management. The commissioner was very helpful in trying to resolve the matter. Unfortunately, these issues of escalating costs were not evident when they purchased. I think we need to ensure that when people are purchasing into these body corporate and community management schemes they are aware of what they are purchasing. Not only should they know the cost they are facing now; they should also have the chance to make a call on whether the escalating costs as time goes on will stay within their budget. The last thing we want to see is people who are purchasing into schemes put into a position where they are priced out and have no option but to sell what often is the greatest investment of their life. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms CROFT (Broadwater--ALP)
(8.44 pm): I rise in support of the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. Firstly, I begin by acknowledging the work put into the development of this bill by the former minister for fair trading, the Hon. Peter Lawlor. The member for Southport worked with great determination to have the inequities of the lot entitlements system under the current legislation dealt with for many people living in units right across the state. He is to be commended for all his efforts.
Mr Ryan: It is his legacy.
Ms CROFT: It is his legacy. He did a fantastic job. I know that it was No. 1 on his priority list. He should be very proud that this bill is before the House tonight.

The changes that are before us in the bill being debated tonight are, of course, the result of extensive consultation and review. The bill has two objectives that will deliver better outcomes for many of my constituents living in residential community titles schemes. I note that the LNP are not supporting the bill and will be voting against it. This is a great shame for many of their constituents, I believe.

This bill provides a more equitable arrangement for unit owners, many of whom are pensioners on fixed incomes or mum and dad investors. I think the LNP should be ashamed that it is not supporting people living in those units, particularly on the Gold Coast where there are many people who have had inequitable arrangements. I am very surprised that the LNP are not supporting this bill.

The bill provides for a new lot entitlements system. There will be now two principles for setting a contribution schedule lot entitlements and a limited ability to adjust contribution schedule lot entitlements. In addition, the bill establishes a far more simplified management arrangement for residential community titles schemes containing only two lots. This is achieved by a new regulation that will simplify and improve the day-to-day management of residential two-lot schemes.

Under the current lot entitlements scheme, owners of typically larger units have applied to have their contribution schedule lot entitlements and therefore their body corporate fees reduced. This has resulted in owners of smaller units subsidising common property maintenance expenses for owners of larger units. That is what the opposition thinks is a fair arrangement. In many cases, the owners of smaller units whose lot entitlements and body corporate fees have increased now struggle to pay their share of body corporate fees.

The bill amends the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997 by providing lot owners in community titles schemes established prior to the commencement of the bill with an opportunity to revert the contribution schedule lot entitlements for each and every lot in the scheme to their original settings prior to any and all adjustment orders. For community titles schemes established before and after the commencement of the bill, any future adjustments of contribution schedule lot entitlements will be limited to very particular circumstances.

As currently provided, two or more lot owners can agree to redistribute the contribution schedule lot entitlements amongst themselves. Lot owners will be able to adjust contribution schedule lot entitlements if it is agreed upon by all lot owners in a scheme through a resolution without dissent. Alternatively, a specialist adjudicator or the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal can make an order to adjust the contribution schedule lot entitlements if they are not set in accordance with the principle applying to contribution schedule lot entitlements--that is, the principle stated on the scheme’s community management statement. Limiting the ability to adjust contribution schedule lot entitlements into the future provides certainty for lot owners.

As I have mentioned, this bill makes life easier for residents who live in specified two-lot schemes. The new management process encourages the owners to self-manage. Decisions of the two-lot scheme owners will be made by a written agreement and will not require a body corporate committee or the need to hold meetings and no-one will be required to cast a vote regarding a matter. For many reasons, the owner of a property may not reside in or close to the two-lot scheme property they own and, when decisions are made about matters that can quite easily be managed, through the changes in this bill an owner can authorise a person to act for the owner in body corporate matters.

The bill also provides for owners to agree on how they may choose to fund body corporate expenses without having to use the concept of levying contributions. These changes encourage more sensible and workable outcomes for people living in close proximity to one another, encouraging greater and more open communication and consideration for one another. Whilst it is inevitable that owners or occupiers may not always agree, the bill provides that, instead of requiring the body corporate to issue a contravention notice where a lot owner or occupier does not comply with the by-laws, which for a two-lot scheme requires the two owners to agree to issue the notice under the new regulation module, an owner can give the owner or occupier of the other lot a written notice for contravening the by-laws. The process includes the provision that a lot owner can start enforcement proceedings with the Office of the Commissioner for Body Corporate and Community Management or the Magistrates Court.

More and more people are choosing to live in unit or community living developments and it is really important for people when buying into a community titles scheme or if they are selling their property in a community titles scheme to exercise due diligence. It is important that the applicable principle being used to determine the lot entitlements and the body corporate fees for a property are disclosed. This bill enhances disclosure requirements, ensuring that protection is provided for consumers when considering buying or selling a property in a body corporate scheme. I am very pleased that the Bligh government has introduced this bill that will fix a problem that has affected many people who are struggling to pay body corporate fees that have increased significantly following applications to adjust the contribution schedule lot entitlements of schemes around the state. I commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Keppel--ALP) (8.51 pm): My original basis for speaking to the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill was to deal specifically with the specified two-lot schemes module. But after listening to the diatribe from various members of the LNP, I thought it might be salutary to explore the whole history of units in Queensland. The original types of units were actually companies and if a person wanted to buy a unit when they subdivided the air above a piece of ground they had to buy shares in a company. There was a difficulty with that because they became a shareholder and they were subject to the Companies Act, which imposed a lot of different obligations on various people within the scheme. In 1980 we got the Building Units and Group Titles Act. That was never a really full answer, but it endeavoured to answer some of the problems that had arisen by putting in place a very specific scheme to deal with the subdivision of air, the subdivision of blocks that were built above two or three storeys.

XML.Hansard-Body: I do not know who wrote the speeches for the member for Currumbin, the member for Mermaid Beach and the member for Gaven, but I would have thought that before they wrote it they might have had a look at the Parliamentary Library brief on the new and more flexible system. It is very instructive and it gives the lie to some of the comments that have been made. After the 1980 act--and it was variously--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! I did not quite catch that. I thought you just might have used an unparliamentary expression, member for Keppel.
Mr HOOLIHAN: No, I did not. I was using the vernacular ‘gives the lie to’.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: No. The word is unparliamentary and I would ask you to withdraw.

Mr HOOLIHAN: It gives the untruth to, if we want the vernacular, but that obviously was never the English application. The Building Units and Group Titles Act probably caused as many problems as it solved. In 1997 the act was amended and we heard the story about how great that amendment was. It was again amended in 2003. For the benefit of those people opposite who do not have any knowledge of the doctrine of the separation of powers, they should take into account that the 2003 legislation, which was enacted by this parliament, was in fact determined to have some defects by that other branch of government under the doctrine of separation of powers--the judiciary. There was a 2004 case and it made decisions in relation to 2003 which said that there had to be a different approach to it. We heard about the 2007 amendment, and that really gave the jurisdiction the right of application to QCAT as against the District Court. I believe that, ultimately, QCAT will provide a lot of reasonably inexpensive results for people who go to it.

That notwithstanding, as a result of the 2004 Centrepoint case--that was the decision in relation to the application of the 2003 legislation--it was then followed through and it was reviewed. There have been a number of ministers. First off, the member for Albert was the minister who initiated the original discussion paper. We then had the member for Southport as the then minister and we have the current minister. This bill seeks to address the mischief which has arisen by virtue of the act as it presently stands. We have heard claims about suddenly raising the fees for body corporate lots to a massive amount because people owned big areas. I do not know whether people believe in the word ‘equity’, but I would have thought that if one has such a large area and they want to be equitable they should pay a rateable proportion according to the area that they own. That is just common sense and probably a true exposition of the law of the land, but the LNP does not want to look at that. That would encourage it to support people other than those people who it would look to for large amounts of money or major financial support. Therefore, we sit here and we hear all of the bleating about the amendments to the act in the bill which is now before the House.

I support this bill wholeheartedly after having practised law for 25 years and grappled with the difficulties that were experienced by very many lawyers in the application of the original body corporate legislation. However, the main point that I wanted to deal with related to the specified two-lot schemes module. With 12,000 community title schemes consisting of two lots in Queensland, this module will really be welcomed by many constituents right throughout Queensland, because it is becoming a favoured way of increasing the ability of having two living areas on one block of land. The formal arrangements provided by the existing regulations modules are often impractical for residential two-lot schemes, and most of us know them as duplexes.
