The new regulation module will provide more appropriate requirements for the management of body corporates for residential community titles schemes containing only two lots and the decision-making framework for owners of those schemes to which the new model applies will no longer require body corporate meetings to be held. It seems rather pointless when two people live side by side and they need a formal meeting to decide matters which they should be able to agree between themselves. Instead, owners of two-lot schemes to which the module applies will be able to make decisions about body corporate matters in writing by a lot owner agreement. Simpler financial arrangements will also be provided for residential two-lot schemes under the new regulation module, including the ability for lot owners to manage their shared expenses without the need for an administrative or sinking fund. If we go back to those larger schemes to which the act applies, that is the real rub about contributions according to equity, particularly in relation to the sinking fund.

A more practical approach to enforcing by-laws in residential two-lot schemes, to which the new module applies, will also be introduced. Instead of requiring the body corporate to issue a contravention notice where a lot owner or occupier does not comply with the by-laws, which for two-lot schemes requires the two owners to agree to issue the notice, under the new regulation module an owner can give the owner or occupier of the other lot a written notice for contravening the by-laws. The specified two-lot schemes module will make the day-to-day management of a body corporate simpler and less onerous for owners of residential two-lot schemes.

The other provisions of the legislation will make it more equitable for the many owners of small residential units in very large building schemes where they are presently at the mercy of people who can bring an application to reduce their contributions per lot and just lump the costs for their lot onto the owners of smaller lots.

All in all, I believe that the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill will provide a more equitable approach to contributions to lot entitlements. I would like to thank the minister and previous ministers for bringing the bill before the House. I commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Coomera--LNP) (9.00 pm): I rise to contribute to the debate on the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010, which was introduced into the House in November 2010. The bill amends the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997, the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal Regulation 2009 and the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal Rules 2009. The main objectives of the bill are to amend the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997, among other things to provide a new lot entitlements system to limit the ability to adjust contribution schedule lot entitlements and to give owners in existing schemes a right to reverse previously adjusted contribution schedule lot entitlements to their original position, allegedly to add some certainty to lot owners. I would argue that this legislation is only going to further confuse matters and create more uncertainty for many owners of lots.

XML.Hansard-Body: As the member for Currumbin indicated in her outstanding contribution to this debate, community titles schemes take many forms. I would guess that my electorate of Coomera would have more than most of the other electorates represented by members in this House. Lot entitlements are used to determine how costs and interest in a community titles scheme are divided between owners and the voting rights of owners in certain circumstances. This brings me to the point of my contribution in this debate. Numerous individuals have come to me as their local member to discuss inequities that they see in their individual schemes versus schemes around them. As the member for Mermaid Beach said, the issue is about who should pay more and who should pay less.

A classic example where the lot entitlements were determined by the developer is one case that I have been involved in. It came to light because new owners moved into a property in a community adjacent to one that they had just vacated. The matter came to light because they could not believe the difference in their rates notice versus the rates for their previous property. This particular development has been in place for something like six or seven years. No-one had raised the issue in the past, but it came to light. These people made inquiries and they referred the matter to me. We had some discussions about it and it was determined that, in dividing the lot entitlements among the various properties, the suggestion was that the developer would benefit either himself or others by adjusting the lot entitlements to ensure that particular properties within the overall complex would pay far less in not only their rates but also their body corporate fees and so forth.

This legislation starts to get very messy for people who are in a position where they have already found that there is an inequity. Everybody agrees that the owners of properties in this particular area have been, for all of the years that the development has been in place, paying too much in every respect versus the owners of other properties within the precinct. So the change is made and agreed to by all of those in the development and they go along with them for some time.

Then along comes this legislation and we see that all of those inequities that have been corrected in the past can now be reversed. So we have a situation where, under this new legislation, we can change everything back to the inequitable position that existed before. This is just one small example of what is wrong with this legislation. As I outlined, once this legislation is approved there are going to be more problems for property owners who have already been through the process of redressing the inequities. Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP)
(9.23 pm): I rise to speak to the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill. Community titles schemes have existed for many years in both commercial and residential forms. With regard to the latter, in our state steadily rising population figures have inevitably led to denser housing arrangements. A rightful desire for homeownership has seen more and more Queenslanders become owners of lots in community titles schemes, automatically making them members of bodies corporate. Such schemes involve the collective ownership and management of shared property and body corporate assets. It has become more important than ever to ensure that affordable housing options are available to Queenslanders. More than might be expected, body corporate fees can be a crucial factor in making a decision that touches the lives of so many Queenslanders, which is, ‘Where will I call home?’

This bill seeks to make amendments to the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997, which exists as the legislative authority on the establishment and administration of community titles schemes in Queensland. These amendments come on the back of an initial amending bill introduced by Labor in 2003. Under the BCCM Act, every community titles scheme has a community management statement. The community management statement contains two schedules that are used to calculate lot entitlements: the contribution schedule and the interest schedule. The contribution schedule is used to calculate a lot owner’s share of most body corporate expenses, as well as the value of a lot owner’s vote for an ordinary resolution. The interest schedule is used to calculate a lot owner’s share of common property and body corporate assets upon termination of the community titles scheme, as well as each lot owner’s share of the unimproved value of schemed land for rates calculation.

The primary focus of the bill before the House is to make significant changes to several aspects of the contribution schedule. Where a lot owner’s share of most body corporate expenses is calculated, the principle for doing so under section 48 of the BCCM Act is to ensure that shares are equal, except to the extent that it is just inequitable in the circumstances for them to be equal.

The inclusion of the equality principle was a cornerstone of Labor’s 2003 amendments, which were unanimously supported at the time. For example, let us consider a community titles scheme containing a combination of residential and commercial lots. It would be unfair to ask the lot owner of a one-bedroom apartment to share the same body corporate, maintenance and utilities costs as a bustling restaurant downstairs. In such circumstances, it is only right that the lot owner of a restaurant pays a greater share than would be deemed equal.

The BCCM Act allows for several ways in which contribution schedules may be adjusted. Applications for an adjustment process are incredibly thorough, often costing anywhere between $10,000 and $20,000 for those seeking an adjustment order. Following the 2003 amendments, adjustment orders must be made with regard to the equality principle. However, this has led to circumstances where, to use the previous example, the one-bedroom apartment owner might have to take on an increased share of the body corporate expenses because of an adjustment in the restaurant owner’s favour. Certainly this is an extreme example. However, it appears that the former minister considers it to be the norm.

Proposed section 379 of the bill allows an adversely affected lot owner to put forward a proposal to the body corporate to revert an adjusted contribution schedule of the scheme to reflect that which existed before the adjustment order was made. Under the bill a single lot owner has the power to compel the body corporate to pass a resolution to revert a contribution schedule lot entitlement to its original setting. All it takes is one person to undo a thorough assessment of what was deemed a just and equitable scheme as a whole. I support the proposition that a schedule lot entitlement ought to be as fair and certain as possible for lot owners. However, I cannot support section 379. I cannot see what is fair about allowing one person to compel a group for the sake of individual interest. I cannot see what is appealing about certainty when it ensures unfairness. Section 379 is an overreaction, failing to strike a balance between fairness and certainty for all lot owners.

For new community titles schemes, amendments to section 46 are proposed to govern the setting of contribution and interest schedule lot entitlements. With regards to contribution schedule lot entitlements, the equality principle is retained. However, scheme developers will have the option to apply either that or a proposed new relativity principle. Under the relativity principle, it will be a requirement that contribution schedule lot entitlements demonstrate the relationship between the lots by reference to a list of particular relevant factors, being how the community titles scheme is structured; the nature, features and characteristics of the lots; the purposes for which the lots are used; the impact the lots may have on costs of maintaining the common property; and the market value of the costs.

An assessment based on the market value of the lots has attracted criticism upon consultation with several notable bodies including the Queensland Law Society and the Australian College of Community Association Lawyers. The QLS considers that an assessment based on market value is problematic and leads to unfairness, especially since the term ‘market value’ is left undefined. On its face, the bill would mean that the body corporate fees would be apportioned according to a lot’s market value irrespective of size. While a market value assessment may be appropriate for calculating interest schedule lot entitlements, its application to contribution schedule lot entitlements is flawed.

Labor’s proposed amendments to the governing principles of lot entitlements seek to introduce greater fairness and certainty for members of bodies corporate with regard to the management of lot entitlements. No-one in the LNP would deny that this is an admirable goal. Put simply, though, this bill fails to achieve this objective. It is impossible to expect the setting of lot entitlements to please every single lot owner. However, this bill will not make it any easier for lot owners and bodies corporate alike, nor will it make it any better. It encourages conflict between people who must live within close proximity of each other.

The LNP supports fair and equitable contributions, but this is not achieved by this politically motivated bill, which only serves to protect the member for Southport and not the thousands of unit owners who bought into schemes under the existing legislation.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (9.30 pm): I rise to contribute to the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. Unit living in communities where there are community titles schemes is becoming more common state-wide. In my electorate of Redcliffe, unit living is becoming increasingly prevalent. Our skyline is dotted with increasing numbers of high-rise apartment blocks. Their increase has been controversial and a point of much discussion on the Redcliffe Peninsula. They are, however, here to stay and an ever-increasing number of people are finding them a convenient lifestyle choice. Those with heavy work commitments or seniors living in a community find that having access to a pool, a gym or gardens without the burden of responsibility for their upkeep is an inducement into this type of lifestyle.

The workings of a body corporate, with many different points of view, can be a shock for new unit owners. This bill will ensure fairness for all unit owners particularly regarding their body corporate fees. This bill amends the 1997 Body Corporate and Community Management Act. Specifically, the part that introduced the ability to allow lot owners in all body corporate schemes to adjust the contributions to a scheme’s contribution schedule and interest schedule is to be amended.

With the passing of the 1997 Body Corporate and Community Management Act, there have been significant adjustments to some contribution schedules and interest schedules to the detriment of some lot owners as they have placed huge financial burdens on them. For example, a retiring couple may have bought a $400,000 ground-floor unit in a new 12-storey building. Their body corporate fees may only be a third of those of the owners of the penthouse on the 12th floor costing $1.5 million because they make no use of the lifts and other expensive amenities that those on higher floors use daily and thus increase the cost of maintenance of the lots on the higher floors. Under the 1997 act, the lot owners of the penthouse could make a case that all units should pay an equal share of body corporate fees so that the body corporate fees are significantly reduced for them but the retired couple on the ground floor suddenly find their body corporate fees have doubled. They are now paying the same share of the lift maintenance fees and the other amenities as those on the higher floors but they never use the lift and they do not have the benefits of the views that the more expensive units have. This bill reverses this in cases where some lot owners have been burdened with large increases in body corporate fees as a result of changes made to the scheme’s contribution schedule or interest schedule by other lot owners.

This bill also provides appropriate and flexible principles for setting contribution schedule lot entitlements. Both the equality and relativity principles ensure that all issues from lot value, characteristics and impact of each lot on the cost of maintaining the common property are among the issues to be considered when setting contribution schedule lot entitlements. If the contribution schedule lot entitlements are not set with regard to these principles after this bill becomes legislation, lot owners have recourse to QCAT.

I believe these amendments will, indeed, be advantageous to many of my constituents who have bought units for the first time over the past 10 years and have been caught by these changes in the amount of body corporate fees they have to pay. This bill also separates the management of duplexes from the management of multiunit communities to make the day-to-day management less complex through the use of a new regulation module. This is a well-targeted bill that will make duplex and unit living much easier and will allow lot owners to enjoy the lifestyle they have paid for. It is about fairness and better management. I thank the minister for his crafting of this bill. I commend the bill to the House.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mount Ommaney--ALP) (9.36 pm): I rise in support of the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. Community or unit living is an increasingly popular lifestyle and accommodation choice, particularly for our seniors in the Mount Ommaney electorate. During the devastating floods this year, I was approached by residents of the Westlake Villas units. Most of the residents in this complex were flooded and there were angry meetings between residents and body corporate members, who were blamed for not obtaining adequate flood insurance for the complex. I walked around the complex and spoke to many residents. Some advised that they thought the body corporate should have covered their building structure because they were not able to get this insurance; they could only obtain contents insurance. After I provided residents with information regarding the Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997 and various agents to contact for help, there were still some ambiguities in relation to who is responsible with regard to particular insurance companies. This example raised some of the likely matters that can become complex with bodies corporate.

XML.Hansard-Body: In relation to this bill, when entering into a contract of sale for a lot in a community titles scheme both parties--the buyer and the seller--must exercise their due diligence. This bill introduces enhanced disclosure requirements around the applicable principle applying to the distribution of lot entitlements and around body corporate fees. The enhanced disclosure requirements will incorporate contracts for the sale of lots in community titles schemes and a scheme’s community management statement.

The Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997 currently requires a disclosure statement to be given to a proposed buyer by a seller before the buyer enters into a contract to buy the lot. A disclosure statement contains essential information about a body corporate including the amount of annual contributions currently set by the body corporate and payable by the lot owner. The amendments to the act will require the disclosure statement to be accompanied by a copy of the community management statement for the scheme. Further, a scheme’s community management statement must state the principle applied to the distribution of the lot entitlements. The termination of a contract for the sale of a lot in a scheme will be provided where there is inaccuracy of disclosure.
Consumer protection for owners and intending buyers of lots in community titles schemes is a fundamental objective of the act. This amendment enhances that objective. I commend the bill to the House.

Ms GRACE (Brisbane Central--ALP) (9.39 pm): I rise in support of the Body Corporate and Community Management and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The Body Corporate and Community Management Act 1997 currently allows either the Queensland Civil and Administrative Tribunal or a specialist adjudicator upon application by a lot owner to adjust a community titles scheme’s contribution schedule lot entitlement. Contribution schedule lot entitlements have sometimes had significant adjustments which have resulted in many lot owners being unable to pay their share of body corporate expenses. This has had significant impact on a lot of unit owners who live in my electorate.

Unfortunately, living in a unit, which many have chosen to do for a number of reasons--be it a change of lifestyle, be it for retirement, be it for the ease by which you can get around the city and avoid travel--is slowly becoming very expensive, particularly when combined with the recent increases that were introduced by the Brisbane City Council--may I say in a very sneaky manner--in the last budget which saw massive rate increases for unit owners in my electorate, sometimes up to 300, 400 and 500 per cent. It has been an incredible increase which is making living in a unit unviable and very expensive for unit owners.

I really cannot see the justification for these increases. These buildings sometimes contain 100 and 200 units. They are probably on a block of land the size of maybe two or three ordinary house blocks. You collect rates from 100 or 200 units, yet you have one place to go to collect bins, one input for water and one output for sewerage. Compare that to the services provided to 100 or 200 houses in a suburb where there is some distance between houses. That is quite different from a high-tower unit block, where there is no requirement for those services to be delivered along a lengthy road. There is a big difference between a unit dwelling and a house dwelling, and there are economies of scale of 100 or 200 units being built on a block compared to 100 or 200 houses in a suburb. There is a big difference in the amount of land that it takes.
Mr Sorensen interjected.

Ms GRACE: No. The member for Hervey Bay says you can fit 100 or 200 houses on the same block as 100 or 200 units! Lord help us. He was the mayor of Hervey Bay. Lord only knows what they were building up there.

I acknowledge the excellent e-research done by the Queensland Parliamentary Library on this bill. It is a good document. I refer members opposite to it. They should read it so they can understand what this bill is about. When I was elected back in 2007, this was one of the first issues raised with me. It was a concern shared by me and in particular by the member for Stafford, the current minister, and by the member for Southport. Clearly there was a problem in the marketplace that needed to be addressed--and I admit that this is a complex issue to address, because inevitably in addressing this issue there will be gains and there will be losses.

Importantly, there has been no single cause of the problem but a series of events and decisions over a long period of time dating back to 1997, when there was a clear failure to fully appreciate the transitional implications arising from the enactment of the BCCM Act, all combining to bring about a problem we are addressing via this bill. Problems also commenced following the well-known Court of Appeal decision in what is commonly known as the Centrepoint or Fischer case which was handed down on 25 June 2004.
Mr Lucas: Frequently discussed at the Wynnum IGA.

Ms GRACE: Frequently discussed at the Wynnum IGA. It was a decision of a block of units located at Spring Hill in my electorate. Following this and the issues that had been continually raised, the government released a discussion paper back in December 2008. That discussion paper was entitled Sharing expenses in community titles schemes . It included a number of scenarios and options, and there were many submissions covering many issues. There have been opposing views from those who have gained by the Centrepoint decision and of course from the many who have been severely disadvantaged by the use of the legal precedent. In this particular court case, there are no doubt winners and losers when it comes to lot entitlements.

Larger penthouses and one-level unit owners have had their annual body corporate fees reduced, and this has been at the cost of smaller unit owners, whose fees have often increased substantially. I know of one inner-city complex where a very large unit owner’s body corporate fees reduced to a quarter of what they were paying when they bought the unit with their eyes open, knowing that that was their body corporate fee. Following a decision, their body corporate fee reduced to a quarter, and the smaller unit owners had their fees doubled or more. In some cases, the smaller unit owners were paying 50 per cent of the equivalent amount of body corporate fees paid by the larger penthouses or one-level unit. Clearly this has placed great financial stress on people who also did their due diligence and had their eyes open when they bought their unit. This decision is impacting upon their ability to remain living in a unit which they considered affordable when they purchased it.

Not only did they find they were up for these additional expenses through a court decision; it invariably affected the value of their property because body corporate fees are a major consideration when someone buys a unit. I want to place on the record my thanks to many of my constituents who have raised this issue from both sides of the argument--those who believe the Centrepoint decision is fair and those who are pleading to have this bill enacted as soon as possible. I acknowledge that this is a complex issue but it is one that needs addressing, and I believe we have found the best solution possible.

The amount raised necessary to meet body corporate expenses usually represents 100 per cent. Inevitably, when one amount is lowered then someone else picks up that amount. From the many examples of adjustments brought to my attention, I can honestly say that the majority of unit owners in a complex have been disadvantaged when compared to the minority few gaining greatly from a reduction in their fees. The bill provides the ability to revert to previous contribution schedule lot entitlements and will only apply to existing community titles schemes and in relation to an order of the court, tribunal or specialist adjudicator that was made before the commencement of this bill.

A lot owner adversely affected by an adjustment order--that is, the fees increased due to the order given by the tribunal or the court--may submit a motion to the body corporate or the body corporate committee proposing the adjustment of the contribution schedule for the scheme to reflect the contribution schedule before any and all adjustment orders. However, there are limitations on the ability to propose such a motion. It is not available to an owner of a lot after an adjustment order was made or who becomes the owner of a lot after the relevant provisions in this bill commence. Also, the ability to submit such a motion will cease three years after this bill is enacted. Therefore, there is a time frame that affected unit owners must act within and the right for this motion no longer exists after three years. So there is a window of opportunity here for people who believe they have been adversely affected by these decisions to move a motion in the body corporate or body corporate committee to revert.

The body corporate or the body corporate committee must then deal with any such motion, and there are provisions in the bill about the manner in which the decision is to apply in such circumstances. There is quite a comprehensive flow chart that has been put together by the department to assist in the process, and I am very eager to help people who live in units in my electorate who want to move a motion, to give them the tools to enable them to do exactly what is required by the legislation and also to give bodies corporate the tools they need to take the actions they must take.

The bill also proposes two important principles--the equality principle and the new relativity principle--to determine the setting of contribution schedule lot entitlements. This aims to set out a process for how these entitlements are going to be worked out by applying two principles which must be open, transparent and advised to people when they are buying units. The bill provides that contribution schedule lot entitlements must be set in accordance with the equality principle--that is, contribution schedule lot entitlements are set equal except to the extent to which it is just and equitable for them not to be equal--or the relativity principle, where there must be a demonstrated relationship between the lots by reference to one or more prescribed relevant factors.

Lot owners in community titles schemes established prior to and after the commencement of this bill will be able to adjust contribution schedule lot entitlements if it is unanimously agreed by all lot owners through a resolution without dissent of the body corporate. I notice that the member for Currumbin actually brought to the attention of the House a situation where all the lot owners were in agreement that the lot entitlement should be amended in a particular way. This bill will enable them to do that. There is no hindrance, where there is agreement and no dissent, to the body corporate adjusting those lot entitlements to reflect the desire of members of that body corporate.

For a community titles scheme established after the commencement of the bill, where a lot owner believes the contribution schedule lot entitlements are not set in accordance with the contribution schedule principle applying to contribution schedule lot entitlements, they may seek an order of a specialist adjudicator or QCAT to adjust the contribution schedule lot entitlements. An application has to be made and they have to apply whatever principle was applied when the lot was established. The order must only be in accordance with the contribution schedule principle which already applies to the contribution schedule lot entitlements.

The bill also provides that interest schedule lot entitlements--that is different to contribution schedule lot entitlements; it appears to be a principle that those opposite do not understand--must reflect the respective market values of the lots, except to the extent to which it is just and equitable in the circumstances for the individual lot entitlements to not reflect the respective market value of the lots. I am sure that those opposite have no understanding of the difference between contribution and interest schedule lot entitlements. With an interest schedule lot entitlement the lot owner has a share of the common property. The lot owner’s interest on termination of the scheme includes their share in the body corporate assets. There is a difference between contributing to the running costs and the interest schedule, where they actually have a share in common property and in the costs of the assets. That is a completely different kettle of fish.

The member for Currumbin is exactly right: they have absolutely no idea. They must apply the market value. I would like to hear the explanation of what the alternative would be. If members understood the extreme differences between the two they would understand why the legislation is written in this manner.

The current provisions of the act providing the ability to seek an adjustment of interest schedule lot entitlements will continue to be available for all schemes after the commencement of the bill. These changes to the bill will ensure that there is as much certainty around body corporate costs as possible, as well as providing more appropriate principles for setting contribution schedule lot entitlements.

I congratulate the current minister for bringing this bill to the House. I have many constituents out there waiting to hear that this bill is being debated and that it passes through this House. I also congratulate the previous minister, the member for Southport, Peter Lawlor, who did an excellent job in going through all of the complex issues in relation to this matter. The member for Southport has been a strong advocate for ensuring that this matter does not continue in the complex way it is at the moment, that the majority of unit owners who are being disadvantaged do not continue to be disadvantaged and that the legislation is brought before the House as soon as possible so it can address the issue that I have spoken about tonight.

The member for Southport has done a sterling job. I place on record my congratulations for the hard work that he has done in relation to ensuring that this bill brings about a solution which, although complex and may not suit everybody and may not necessarily address all of the complex issues that we have discussed tonight, goes a long way to reverting to what people had when they first bought units and therefore having the disadvantage removed.

If those opposite understood this bill, if those opposite spoke to those unit owners, if those opposite realised the number of people who have been disadvantaged not only by the decisions of the courts in increasing their expenses but also by the increases in rates that they have had to endure because of the previous Lord Mayor of Brisbane, the candidate for Ashgrove--this has affected people who live in the Brisbane Central electorate but also people in other electorates--we would not need to apply a lot of the changes that are proposed. I believe it is a necessary step. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Ms Grace, adjourned.
Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (9.56 pm): I move--

Hansard-Body.A: (Glass House--LNP) (9.56 pm): This week in Glass House we have seen yet more frustrating examples of this toxic and tired Bligh Labor government and its unwillingness to stand up to its federal counterparts. On 23 March my office received a response from the Premier to a request I made on 9 February. My request was pretty simple. Given that Grigor Bridge at Conondale had been considerably damaged during the January floods, would the Premier give consideration to replacing it as part of the flood reconstruction?

XML.Hansard-Body: To me and my constituents in Conondale, the request seemed reasonable. Transport and Main Roads persist in throwing good money after bad repairing the bridge, instead of completely replacing it. Yes, in the short term the cost is less, but over the long run the repair bills start adding up and they will certainly swamp the $18 million price tag for replacing the decrepit timber structure with a modern flood proof concrete formation. But it was the same old tired response from the Premier. TMR would ‘redesign and reconstruct the side track that was washed away during the flood’ and ‘carry out further repairs to Grigor Bridge’, repairs that are expected to take up to eight months. It was not the answer that I or the people of Conondale sought, but it was the answer that we expected.

The news is the same for the people of Beerwah, Glasshouse Mountains and Bells Creek. Following a tragic double fatality at the notorious Bells Creek interchange on the Bruce Highway, I wrote to the federal Minister for Infrastructure, Anthony Albanese, pleading that the interchange upgrades not be delayed because of the flood recovery. The minister’s response sounded as tired as the Premier’s--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the deferral of construction works on a number of Nation Building projects, including the Caboolture and Caloundra upgrade, was necessary to free up funding and skilled workers to ensure there is a capacity for the rebuilding of essential infrastructure.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The deferral of funding for projects on the Bruce Highway will delay the commencement of works by two to three years.
XML.Hansard-Body: As I said when the delay was first announced, this is heaping tragedy upon tragedy. Yes, the floods were tragic, and the reconstruction a priority, but why do important safety upgrades such as this interchange improvement need to suffer? How many more will die during the two to three year delay? It is just not good enough.

To conclude the disappointment for the constituents of Glass House, just yesterday I received formal communication from the Minister for Energy and Water Utilities confirming that he has decided to make the designation for certain land to become community infrastructure under the Sustainable Planning Act 2009, guaranteeing that Energex’s planned SunCoast power project along Eudlo Creek will proceed.

There was no mention of a species management plan to protect the platypus community. There was no mention of Energex’s appalling record of community consultation--a record that saw the biggest stakeholder, the Sunshine Coast Grammar School, only formally briefed last Tuesday. There was no mention of the alternative options--alternatives that would have had far less social and environmental impact. The common thread across these three examples is the lazy approach of this tired Bligh Labor government. It is time for a change. It is time for energy, vision and leadership for all of Queensland. Campbell Newman and the LNP team stand ready to provide this change for Queensland.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Health) (9.59 pm): I am looking for TransLink to give Samford commuters a hand. The biggest public transport project in the north-western suburbs of Brisbane is going full steam ahead: a major redevelopment of the Ferny Grove Railway Station and precinct is underway. This $100 million state government initiative has been brought forward four years to help tackle congestion on our busy roads. I have been campaigning for this project for many years and it is fantastic to see it now taking shape. What will be created is a major public transport hub for the north-western suburbs that involves duplicating the track from Keperra to Ferny Grove, a major upgrade of the station, an expansion of the car park to approximately 1,000 places, and a major bus interchange for the TransLink services from Samford, Upper Kedron and Ferny Hills. I am delighted that with community support I have also been successful in ensuring that a new Ferny Grove Tavern can be built on the site.

XML.Hansard-Body: The big challenge for QR is how to manage all of this construction work over the next 12 months or so while at the same time having as many car parks as possible available for commuters every day. The number of car parks unavoidably will vary significantly during construction. At the moment, capacity has increased from about 600 to 750. However, later in the year this will be significantly reduced. Many Samford residents already park at Ferny Grove station and catch the train to the city. I believe that TransLink could help them out. I am calling on TransLink to provide assistance by temporarily waiving, for a limited period of time, the fares for bus travel on the Samford bus when the car park capacity is significantly reduced later in the year. This would encourage more commuters to use the bus and would take a lot of pressure off the car park when its capacity has been unavoidably reduced by the construction work on site. It may also encourage greater use of public transport longer term.

I know that this is a fairly unusual step to take. However, I believe it is a simple and practical way to ensure that, for the limited time that construction work designed to expand the car park actually significantly reduces its capacity, QR and TransLink work together to ensure that commuters keep using public transport and help tackle traffic congestion. Sometimes exceptional circumstances call for exceptional solutions.

Hansard-Body.A: (Mirani--LNP) (10.02 pm): Today, as every other day, thousands of families were confronted with a different routine and challenge--a lifestyle dedicated to autism. All across our state there are parents struggling to get or deal with a diagnosis of non-communicative or difficult behaviour. There are families trying to control runaways, confused behaviour and challenging responses. The craving of every parent--reciprocated affection--is noticeably missing, yet these families continue to love their children and provide the best possible lives for them as they deal with autism spectrum disorders. There are many success stories, as we see by the adults who still deal with the disorder as they continue to participate in our society. The effects of autism are felt far and wide, as our teachers, carers and health professionals know. Yet we still do not have an accurate idea of the prevalence of autism across the state because this Bligh government still has not completed the fundamental simple task of mapping it.

XML.Hansard-Body: This month is Autism Month. It is a month to praise the work of families who help children develop through their autism. It is a time to recognise the achievements of those who have made so much of themselves while dealing with the disorder. It is an occasion to congratulate the work of doctors, therapists, teachers and specialists as they work to help our children receive the earliest possible treatment. Early intervention is essential in autism and needs to be a priority. Too many parents in this state have stories of being flicked from one government department to another, watching their children grow more and more into the disorder because early intervention services are not receiving enough support. I commend the work of our many carers, families and professionals who work to make the world so much better for people with autism.

Hansard-Body.A: (Toowoomba North--ALP) (10.04 pm): I want to speak on a number of matters that have happened in Toowoomba in the last week. Firstly, the government announced with the federal government an amount of $15.4 million from the disaster relief fund to the Toowoomba Regional Council. This was advance funding provided by both the state and the federal governments which will of course stimulate the Toowoomba economy. This will enable the Toowoomba Regional Council to confidently continue with the recovery work, particularly with respect to public infrastructure, local repairs and replacement of roads and bridges. Councils needed to supply their damage lists and signed funding agreements, which was eventually done by the Toowoomba Regional Council.

XML.Hansard-Body: It is of interest that about 80 per cent of the amount received will be spent on roadwork. The government’s priority is the rebuilding of Queensland, and last week’s payment shows that we are dedicated to getting on with that job. I want to acknowledge the fact that the Prime Minister was in Toowoomba today and also acknowledge that this is her third visit to Toowoomba since the floods. We appreciate her commitment to our area.

Secondly, I want to mention last week’s opening by Minister Struthers of the new YWCA units at Mary Street. A $3.8 million contribution from the state government will provide 23 new affordable housing units which will provide safe and appropriate accommodation for people in need. They are very adaptable so that people with specific needs can access them. They are named the Hofmann and Wadley Wings after two former local presidents of the YWCA. Aileen Wadley began the tradition of providing affordable housing in 1945 and Margaret Hofmann raised the funds in 1971 for additional units. Therefore, it was appropriate that these new buildings recognise their past extremely worthwhile contributions. I am very pleased that this project has come to an end. It required a great deal of work from the previous minister, Mr Schwarten, as well as the current minister, Minister Struthers, and I thank them both for their efforts in this regard.

Thirdly, adults with a disability on the Darling Downs have better access to better services with the opening of the new Endeavour Foundation centre in Toowoomba. The minister, Mr Pitt, opened the Endeavour Foundation’s Learning and Lifestyle Centre after the state government contributed $500,000 towards the new centre. Staff will deliver services and support to more than 140 local adults with a disability. They will provide training in literacy and numeracy, computer skills, money handling, road safety, health, physical activity and craft.

Mrs SULLIVAN (Pumicestone--ALP) (10.11 pm): As we all know, two things in life are certain: death and taxes. I can predict with absolute certainty that many Queenslanders will die this year from a host of natural causes, illnesses, trauma, cancer and old age. Virtually all of the families of these people will find themselves at a funeral business at some stage to make decisions about the funeral arrangements. It is an important decision for people to be making at a time of great personal loss. They may be encouraged to spend vast amounts of money as a final tribute. I can also safely predict that most, if not all, of these families will be offered a funeral package that has changed little in the past 100 years.

It should not surprise honourable members that the funeral business, which can charge high prices for what are fairly simple items, is a highly lucrative one. For example, take the coffin, which will be used very briefly before being burnt or buried. It has no special or magical properties. It is just a fancy painted or stained box made of particle board, MDF or chipboard. Some coffins are made with precious timbers on order. Some are made locally, but I am advised that a growing number are cheap imports.

The pace of change in the funeral industry is slow. In fact, an article last year in the Economist titled ‘Exit strategies’ described burial rites in most of the modern worlds as an expensive relic of the 19th century. The article notes the findings from a South Australian study that burying a body, still the first preference for many Australians, releases a cocktail of formaldehyde and other chemicals into the soil and the surrounding watertable. Many of the drugs we take to preserve life are released in the decomposition process and some compounds never break down.

Cremating was introduced in major cities and towns as an option to avoid these risks and to reduce the demand for more land for cemeteries. However, cremation has its own problems. The UK government has recently introduced regulations to require crematoria to fit control equipment to cut their toxic mercury emissions by half by 2012. The introduction of those regulations follows the discovery that up to 16 per cent of all mercury emitted in that country was from crematoria because of the fillings in teeth. Other countries are following the UK’s example.

Honourable members will be pleased to note that a new inquiry by the Environment and Resources Committee will be examining this issue as well as other aspects of burials and cremations and related land use issues. We are taking submissions until 20 April. We are not seeking to interfere in religious practices, nor are we seeking to dictate to anyone how they should deal with their departed loved ones. However, we are interested in seeing the funeral industry lift its game. We would like to see more choices with less expense, less wastage of resources, fewer chemicals and lower overall impact on our natural environment.

Every farmer and every producer in Queensland is aware of the impacts that their activities have on the environment. I am sure that the vast majority are keen to minimise their impacts if they can. Usually the law says they have no choice. The funeral industry should be no different. If there are ways that it can reduce its harmful effects, it should try to do so. This government and the community are making enormous improvements to reduce our use of resources and to minimise waste. I trust that every member will support the work of my committee to find better choices for the state’s funeral industry--an industry that ultimately affects every Queenslander.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (10.14 pm): This afternoon a very distressed Sunshine Coast resident contacted me regarding the end-of-life care his wife is receiving. I understand his elderly wife is and has been a resident of a Sunshine Coast nursing home for some time. She is a diagnosed palliative care patient with cancer and a muscle-wasting disease and is suffering significant pain and distress. I also understand that the woman has pleaded with her doctor not to let her suffer and die in pain. I understand that the doctor has refused to authorise a syringe driver to improve her pain management, claiming that a patient should enjoy their last stages of life. The husband has told me that he and the rest of his family are all very angry that the attending doctor will not administer enough pain relief to relieve his wife’s suffering, even if the result is to accelerate her death. This is what the woman has told her family she wants.

This woman was a registered nurse working in the aged-care industry and she was assured by her family that they would not let her die in pain. Yet the husband tells me that the attending doctor is not prepared to rely on the amended Queensland law, commonly known as the rights of the terminally ill amendment, which allows a doctor to administer whatever medication is necessary to relieve the pain and suffering in a terminally ill person, even if a secondary effect of the drugs is to shorten the patient’s life. I understand situations such as this are occurring regularly. There have been two in the past week that I know of on the Sunshine Coast.

When people face such a terrible end--dying in agony watched by their distressed families--it is no wonder that more and more Queenslanders are calling for voluntary euthanasia laws in Queensland. I believe that this government and the Queensland branch of the Australian Medical Association have a responsibility to remind all Queensland doctors of the rights of the terminally ill amendment, which I introduced into the parliament some time ago, which allows people to die without pain and with dignity.

No Queenslander should die in pain. The RSPCA would not allow animals to suffer like this person is suffering at the moment. Maybe the next time I am approached by a family in similar circumstances I should approach the RSPCA, with the support of the patient’s family, and then we will see what the government and the Queensland doctors have to say about the way some Queenslanders are being treated at the moment.

Hansard-Body.A: (Ipswich West--ALP) (10.17 pm): Tonight I want to advise the House of an education graduation ceremony that I attended last week. It is a little bit unusual: it was at the Borallon Correctional Centre, which is in my electorate. I am a constant visitor to the centre and support a lot of the programs they have in place there.

XML.Hansard-Body: The general manager of Borallon Correctional Centre, Scott McNairn, in the short time that he has been there, which has been only a couple of years, has done an amazing job in turning around some of the prisoners in that particular facility. Last week we saw prisoners graduating from literacy and numeracy level III and computer aided drafting courses. We saw a number of prisoners graduating with a certificate II in furniture making and as part of that program they are building doll’s houses, which are going to be used at the local children’s hospital. These were outstanding items that I took the time to view. There were also graduations in certificate II in hospitality and graduations in certificate I in IT.

I think what is better about this particular facility than most others in relation to prison reform is that about 40 inmates have taken part. On graduation day, the parents of the prisoners enter the facility and are there to support their loved ones as they graduate. I take the opportunity to speak to every one of these family members before the inmates come in and I can tell members that, even though our prison population is largely illiterate and highly undereducated, it is amazing to see how proud not only the parents are but also the offenders are in relation to achieving simple tasks and simple certificates, such as certificate I or certificate II.

Borallon Correctional Centre is also well known for a number of other things that it is doing at the moment. I think every member would be aware of the Pups in Prison program. As part of that program, prisoners train pups to work as assistance dogs for people with disabilities. This program is aimed at reducing reoffending behaviour and it also helps prisoners to develop their reading, writing and communication skills through the upkeep of a daily diary. I will be at the prison again next month for Pups in Prison. If any other members would like to come out on the day, they are welcome to come along and see these pups. They are absolutely fantastic.

As well, there is the Shakespeare in prison program. Last year, they showed Macbeth. It was absolutely outstanding to see some of the prisoners who were able to learn, understand and recite those lines of Macbeth. Anybody who knows Macbeth would know that the play has a number of long orations, and for the prisoners to recite them is an amazing feat on its own.

They are also doing the regular NAIDOC festivities. As members would imagine, the prison population includes a number of Indigenous persons. This year they are also looking at trying to help our Islander offenders as well. All in all, congratulations to the Serco facility at Borallon. Well done and hopefully there are many more.

Hansard-Body.A: (Hervey Bay--LNP) (10.20 pm): I rise to speak to the House about Mrs Michelle Guy, who is a retired constituent living in Hervey Bay. Michelle broke her finger quite severely and needed to have a knuckle replacement. Mrs Guy was booked in for surgery on 18 March 2011 at a hospital in Brisbane. She arrived at 6.30 in the morning and waited for six hours, only for somebody to come out and say that her surgery had been cancelled. The reason? Because her finger surgery was not urgent, she was last on the list and the doctors had run out of time.

XML.Hansard-Body: There was an enormous amount of organisation undertaken for Mr and Mrs Guy to go from Hervey Bay to Brisbane. I would like to talk about the cost involved and the reimbursement due to this cancellation. Surgery cancellations and rebates for country patients show a great disparity. Mr and Mrs Guy made the trip to Brisbane the night before the surgery. They organised accommodation and drove to Brisbane. They had booked a B&B which was four minutes from the hospital at $135 a night for the two-night stay. They thought that was the better option as the parking at the hospital was $26 a day. What disappointed Mrs Guy was that she only got $30 back for the accommodation and $86.10 for the fuel for her trip, a total of $116.10.

Mrs Guy is a very kind lady. She did not mind so much about the cancellation of the surgery. She said that she understood priorities. She and her husband have to do it all again, though. She still has a very bad finger and she believes that she has been hard done by, and I agree with her. Mrs Guy was more concerned about other elderly patients travelling to Brisbane only to be told that their surgery had been cancelled.

Travel and accommodation are very expensive for these pensioners. I have had a number of people come to my office and complain about travelling to Brisbane for surgery only to be told that their operation had been cancelled. I just wish that some consideration could be given to people, especially the elderly, who have travelled long distances to get medical treatment in Brisbane.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Mayfield State School Amateur Swim Club; Carina Men’s Shed
XML.Hansard-Body:
Mr KILBURN (Chatsworth--ALP)
(10.22 pm): I was very happy last Friday to attend the Mayfield State School Amateur Swim Club, better known as the Mayfield Marlins, to receive a cheque for $1,246 as a donation to the Premier’s Disaster Relief Appeal. Upon seeing the needs of the victims of the recent Queensland floods and Cyclone Yasi, the Mayfield Marlins swim captains, Lauren Hocking, Daniel Bottesini, Emily Caputo and Josh McKee, decided to arrange a swimathon to raise funds. They organised the event, arranged sponsorship and, along with other members of the Mayfield Marlins swim club, swam their hearts out to raise the $1,246. I would also like to thank the parents and volunteers, including the Mayfield Marlins president, Donna Ricca, for their support for this obviously very worthy cause. I can assure all the members of the Mayfield Marlins swim club and their supporters that the money has been passed on to the Premier’s appeal and will go a long way to help support victims of the disasters which affected so much of Queensland earlier this year.
Another example of the great community spirit in my electorate of Chatsworth is the members of the Carina Men’s Shed group.
Ms Farmer: Hear, hear!

Mr KILBURN: I acknowledge the support from the member for Bulimba. The Carina Men’s Shed group president, George Hickey, Mal Wier and their team recently took on the task of building 50 nest boxes for mahogany gliders that were severely affected by Cyclone Yasi. They are an endangered species of glider. They live in the Tully area, an area I am very familiar with. The effect of Cyclone Yasi was to strip their habitat--all the leaves off the trees--which left them vulnerable to the weather and predators. George and Mal were the driving force in setting up the Carina Men’s Shed. They have been meeting under George’s house since they commenced. Due to the high level of support in the area for the Carina Men’s Shed and the number of men looking at joining they are quickly outgrowing their current home, and I and the member for Bulimba are working hard to try to find them a more suitable and permanent home in the Carina area.

The mahogany glider boxes were requested by the RSPCA. George and the guys at the Carina Men’s Shed took it on. I was very pleased with the level of support they received from the local Bunnings. Alison and her team at Bunnings at Cannon Hill provided all the material and the guys set about building the 50 boxes within a couple of days. I congratulate them for that. I also congratulate Bunnings for their support of that particular project. I am happy to announce that they are continuing to support the Carina Men’s Shed group into the future.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 10.25 pm.
